PREFACE
         This code of the City of Spring Valley, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance 1911, passed March 3, 2025. Ordinances
of the City adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code
to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the
City office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code
has been amended, superseded or repealed.
                     American Legal Publishing
                     Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING REVIEW FOR CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they are pending review by the
publisher, and they may not amend the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
ORDINANCE NO. 1899
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING VARIOUS PROVISIONS OF CHAPTER 15 OF THE SPRING VALLEY
CITY CODE RELATING TO DUTIES, TITLE, AND REMUNERATION OF POLICE OFFICERS
 
Background Recitals
 
WHEREAS, Title 1, Chapter 15 of the Spring Valley City Code establishes a
scheme regulating pay and benefits for the employees of the City of Spring
Valley; and
 
WHEREAS, The City of Spring Valley has the authority to amend the duties, title
and remuneration of the employees of the City of Spring Valley pursuant to the
authority granted by Section 10-4-1 of the Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/10-4-1);
and
 
WHEREAS, The Mayor and City Council of the City of Spring Valley deem it to be
in the best interests of the public health, safety, and welfare of the
residents of the City of Spring Valley to amend the duties, title and
remuneration of the police officers of the City of Spring Valley.
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF SPRING
VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AS FOLLOWS BELOW.
 
Section 1:   The findings contained in the Background Recitals to this
Ordinance are found to be true and correct and are hereby adopted as part of
this Ordinance.
 
Section 2:   The existing Subsection (I) of Section 1-15-1 of the Spring Valley
City Code is hereby deleted in its entirety and the following is hereby
substituted in its place:
 
(I) Effective retroactive to July 1, 2024, the compensation for the Chief of
Police shall be:
 
 
$108,000.00 for the first year
$110,700.00 for the second year
$113,468.00 for the third year
 
This salary is payable in equal installments bi-weekly.
 
 
Section 3:   The existing Subsection (J) of Section 1-15-1 of the Spring Valley
City Code is hereby deleted in its entirety and the following is hereby
substituted in its place:
 
(J) Effective retroactive to July 1, 2024, the compensation for the Assistant
Chief of the Police or Deputy Chief shall be:
 
 
$93,000.00 for the first year
$95,325.00 for the second year
$97,708.00 for the third year
 
This salary is payable in equal installments bi-weekly.
 
Section 4:   The existing Subsection (K) of Section 1-15-1 of the Spring Valley
City Code is hereby deleted in its entirety and the following is hereby
substituted in its place:
 
(K) Effective retroactive to July 1, 2024, the compensation for the Sergeant of
the Police shall be:
 
 
$88,000.00 for the first year
$90,200.00 for the second year
$92,455.00 for the third year
 
This salary is payable in equal installments bi-weekly.
 
Section 5: The existing Subsections (A) through (F) of Section 1-15-2 of the
Spring Valley City Code is hereby deleted in its entirety and the following is
hereby substituted in its place:
 
Benefits for members of the Police Department shall be as follows:
 
(A)   Health Insurance: All full-time employees shall be eligible for the
City's group health insurance program on the first day of hire. The Union
agrees the City retains the right to change health insurance providers,
administrators or to otherwise provide for health and welfare coverage (e.g.,
self-insurance) as long as the level of covered benefits and care remains
substantially the same.
 
The City reserves the right to maintain or institute cost containment measures
relative to insurance coverage as long as the basic level of coverage remains
substantially similar.
 
The City agrees to continue to provide health insurance coverage plan for the
employee and their qualifying dependents, for the life of this contract, at no
cost to the employee.
 
All costs for health care, vision, and dental insurance shall be paid by the
employee during any period the employee is on leave, without pay; on suspension
without pay; on unauthorized leave; or is participating in any unlawful work
stoppage.
 
No employee shall be entitled to a cash payment in lieu of health care
insurance coverage.
 
Retirees of the City, under age 65, shall be eligible for continued
participation in the City's health care plan, upon payment of all the costs
thereof by the employee. In addition, the City complies with those provisions
of the federal Consolidated Omnibus Reconciliation Act of 1986 (COBRA) relating
to the extension of group health care plan coverage upon termination of
employment by the City.
 
The City retains the right to change insurance plan(s), benefit(s), provider
(s), carrier(s), third party administrator(s), or to self-insure for the
provision of health, dental, and/or life insurance benefits, and the City
further reserves its right to institute, maintain and change cost containment,
benefits and other provisions of the plan(s), all as it may determine in its
sole discretion to be necessary or beneficial to the needs of the City. The
City will notify plan participants of any changes to the health insurance
program, and will bargain over the effects of any such changes upon request by
the Union.
 
(B)   Vacation: Vacation leave shall be earned beginning with the first date of
employment as a bargaining unit member under the conditions hereinafter stated.
No employee shall be permitted to use vacation time for any period spent on
unauthorized leave. Vacation time may be used after ninety (90) days of
continuous employment.
 
Full-time Employees. Full-time employees are entitled to paid vacation leave
time according to the following schedule:
 
 
 
               Annual Hours
 
      Years 1-5         80 hrs per year
      Year 6-10         120 hrs per year
      Year 11-20         160 hrs per year
      Year 21-25         160 hrs + addt’l 8 vacation hours per year
      Year 26 and over      200 hrs per year
 
Scheduling. The dates for the taking of vacation leave shall be scheduled in
consultation with the Chief of Police or designee. In cases where the requested
vacation schedules of employees would adversely affect the efficient operation
of the City, vacation leave shall be granted on the basis of seniority.
 
Holiday During Vacation. City holidays which occur during the taking of an
employee's authorized vacation leave will not be counted as a day of vacation.
 
Minimum Hours. Employees may use vacation leave in units of not less than one
(1) hour, subject to the approval of the Chief of Police or his designee.
 
Termination. Upon termination, an employee shall be compensated for all earned
but unused vacation leave at his/her final rate of pay, subject to the maximum
hours of accumulation authorized.
 
Vacation Buy-Back. Accrued vacation may be taken as time off or it may be
exchanged for cash benefit under the following conditions:
 
   1. Once per year, in June or December, eligible regular full-time employees
may request up to forty (40) hours of their current available accrued vacation
benefit time.
 
   2. The vacation buy-back requested must be approved by the Chief of Police
and submitted to the payroll clerk.
 
   3. Once the vacation buy-back is approved, it will be processed at the
employee's regular rate of pay. The employee will receive a separate check for
the vacation buy-back amount.
 
   4. All requests must be approved, refer only to vacation time, and be in
increments of complete hours. Only one request per calendar year may be
submitted.
 
Maximum Vacation Accrual. Employees who fail to utilize any of their vacation
time as time off, will forfeit any remaining portion in excess of the maximum
hours of accumulation each year.
 
Thereafter, the employee will not accrue any additional vacation hours until
such time as the accrued hours go below the maximum accrual limit.
 
The only exception to the forfeiture and non-accrual of additional vacation
hours may be if the City asks an employee to forego a scheduled vacation in
connection with unanticipated staffing shortages or if an employee faces an
unexpected hardship. In such cases, the employee should seek approval from the
Chief of Police to carry over the vacation balance. The employee must also
schedule and take, such time off within the one hundred eighty (180) days
following the anniversary date beyond which the carry forward occurs, or
forfeit such time.
 
In the event an employee is ordered into work on a preapproved scheduled
vacation or personal day and that employee suffers a monetary loss, the City
agrees to reimburse the employee the entire amount lost. Receipts must be
provided to the City for actual cost and reimbursement will only be made for
actual money lost.
 
(C)   Sick Leave: Employees shall be entitled to sick leave with pay for
absences resulting from illness, injuries, accidents or other physical
incapacity, due to the officer’s own illness, or that of a spouse, civil union
partner, dependent, or parent. Sick leave with pay may be used for physical
examinations, vision, and dental work if they have provided at least one (1)
days’ notice to the Chief of Police or his designee.
 
Amount of Sick Leave. Full-time employees shall earn ten (10) sick leave days
(one hundred twenty (120) hours) per year.
 
Accumulation of Sick Leave. No employee may accrue more than nine hundred
twenty (920) hours of sick leave.
 
Computing Sick Leave. Any absence for a fraction or part of a day which is
chargeable to sick leave shall be charged in increments of not less than one
(1) hour.
 
Medical certification of the need for sick leave, in form and content
acceptable to the City, may be required whenever the Chief of Police has
reasonable suspicion that sick leave abuse may be occurring.
 
An employee, upon written request, may be granted a leave of absence without
pay or benefits for a period of up to six (6) months, subject to approval of
the Chief of Police or his designee.
 
Notification. Except in the case of an emergency, the police officer must
directly notify his or her supervisor prior to any absence from work. If a
police officer is unable to notify the supervisor, the officer shall notify the
on-duty officer-in-charge.
 
Credits for Paid Leave. An employee while on paid sick leave, vacation leave or
other leave with pay (not including Worker's Compensation) shall continue to
earn credit for sick, vacation leave, but no leave credit shall be earned by
any employee while on leave without pay.
 
(D) Personal Leave: All employees covered by this agreement shall be entitled
to receive two (2) personal days (twenty-four (24) hours) off with pay during
each calendar year. An employee desiring to take a personal day must receive
permission from the Chief of Police or his designee. The personal days provided
for in this section cannot be carried over from one calendar year to another
calendar year without prior approval of the Chief of Police or his designee.
 
(E) Holiday Pay: Police officers required to be on duty during the following
holidays shall be entitled to compensation of double time, based at the rate of
each officer's hourly rate, over and above their regular pay:
 
     New Year’s Eve         Labor Day
   New Year’s Day         Veterans Day
   President’s Day         Thanksgiving Day
   Easter               Day after Thanksgiving
   Memorial Day            Christmas Eve
   Juneteenth            Christmas Day
   Fourth of July      
   
From time-to-time, and for certain special occasions, the City's Governing Body
may, by motion, designate other days as special holidays on a one-time basis.
In the event an additional City Holiday is granted to other City employees,
Union or Non-Union, this collective bargaining unit will receive the same
hours, day, or days as City Holidays to be paid as described in this contract
for City holidays.
 
The actual calendar day of the holiday will be observed by bargaining unit
members and will not be changed to a Friday or Monday.
 
Employees scheduled to, and who actually do work, a holiday(s) will earn both
their regular rate of pay for every hour worked on the holiday as well as
double time for every hour worked on the holiday. Employees who are not
scheduled to work a holiday will receive 8 hours of regular pay.
 
(F) Union Allowance: Employees shall be reimbursed up to $600 per year for
approved uniforms following their one-year anniversary. Employees will be
responsible for the laundering, appearance, and care of the uniforms. Newly
hired police officers will be outfitted with all of the necessary duty
equipment by the City. Only approved uniform items shall be reimbursed.
Original receipts must be provided in order to obtain reimbursement.
 
The City will provide each employee a protective vest replaced in accordance
with the manufacturers' and NIJ specifications.
 
Employees are expected to wear uniforms at all times. If their existing uniform
is not suitable, they must replace the damaged items.
 
Section 6: The existing Subsections (H) through (I) of Section 1-15-2 of the
Spring Valley City Code is hereby deleted in its entirety and the following is
hereby substituted in its place:
 
(H)(1) Hours of Work: Patrol officers covered in this agreement will normally
work 12 hour shifts. Day shift shall be 0600 hours until 1800 hours and night
shift 1800 hours until 0600 hours the following day. The Chief of Police may
schedule and assign employees to flex shifts or power shifts as he determines
necessary.
Patrol officers shall work an eighty-four (84) hour pay period completed in a
fourteen (14) day cycle always beginning on a Sunday and ending on a Saturday.
These cycles will be in accordance with the pay dates of the City of Spring
Valley. Officer will be paid bi-weekly.
 
Employees may be required to work overtime.
 
Employees shall bid for shifts annually beginning in October by highest to
lowest seniority for the following calendar year. Once shifts are established
by the seniority list they will not be changed unless both parties mutually
agree to swap shifts, as long as no overtime is created, and with the approval
of the Chief of Police.
 
(H)(2) Overtime Work: Compensation for authorized overtime work shall be at the
rate of one and one-half times the employee's regular rate of pay, provided
that Officers serving as a Field Training Officer (FTO) shall receive one half
hour of overtime for every four hours actually training.
 
Employees shall be eligible to receive overtime compensation for all hours
worked and paid leave received in excess of eighty-four (84) hours during the
fourteen day pay cycle.
 
The Chief of Police or his designee shall maintain records of any overtime
worked. Employees shall report all overtime hours to the Chief of Police or his
designee.
 
(H)(3) No Pyramiding: Compensation shall not be paid more than once for the
same hours under any provision of this Ordinance.
 
(I) Vacation Selection: Vacation will be pursuant to departmental regulations
and in conformity with Section 1-15-2(B).
 
Section 7: The existing Subsection (L) of Section 1-15-2 of the Spring Valley
City Code is hereby deleted in its entirety and the following is hereby
substituted in its place:
 
(L)   Bereavement: Employees shall be entitled to three (3) paid days of
bereavement leave following the death of a family member as defined in the
Illinois Family Bereavement Leave Act. Eligible employees may take up to seven
(7) additional unpaid days off in accordance with said Act.
 
Section 8:   This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its passage and
publication in pamphlet form as provided by law.
 
   PRESENTED, PASSED, AND ADOPTED at a regular meeting of the City Council of
the City of Spring Valley, Bureau County, Illinois, on July 15, 2024, by a roll
call vote as follows:

ORDINANCE NO. 1905
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTIONS 3-7-1 AND 3-7-5 OF THE SPRING VALLEY CITY CODE
RELATING TO THE DEMOLITION AND SALVAGE OPERATIONS OF NONRESIDENTIAL BUILDINGS
 
Background Recitals
 
WHEREAS, The City of Spring Valley has previously established definitions and
regulations related to the demolition of nonresidential buildings; and
 
WHEREAS, The City of Spring Valley has the authority to amend the definitions
and regulations related to the demolition of nonresidential buildings pursuant
to the authority granted by Section 10-4-1 of the Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/10-
4-1); and
 
WHEREAS, The Mayor and City Council of the City of Spring Valley deem it to be
in the best interests of the public health, safety, and welfare of the
residents of the City of Spring Valley to amend the duties, title and
remuneration of the Economic Development Director.
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF SPRING
VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AS FOLLOWS BELOW.
 
Section 1:   The findings contained in the Background Recitals to this
Ordinance are found to be true and correct and are hereby adopted as part of
this Ordinance.
 
Section 2:   The existing Sections 3-7-1 and 3-7-5 of the Spring Valley City
Code are hereby deleted in their entirety and the following are hereby
substituted in its place:
 
3-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings
ascribed to them:
BUILDING INSPECTOR: The city of Spring Valley building inspector or his
authorized agent.
DEMOLITION: The removal, in whole or in part, of any structure or building, the
removal of demolition debris, or the installation of fill material and final
grading in connection with such removal.
DEMOLITION CONTRACTOR: Any person or firm engaged in the business
of demolition of buildings or structures by contract. (Ord. 1587, 10-27-2014)
SALVAGE OPERATIONS: The removal of valuable materials, including but not
limited to, copper, wiring, plumbing fixtures, appliances, lumber, and other
recyclable or reusable components, from a building or structure.
 
3-7-5: FEES AND PERMITS; NONRESIDENTIAL DEMOLITION; NONRESIDENTIAL SALVAGE
OPERATIONS; DEMOLITION OF RESIDENTIAL REAL PROPERTY WITH VALUE GREATER THAN
TWENTY-FIVE THOUSAND DOLLARS:
    (A)   Permits Required – Demolition: It shall be unlawful for any person to
demolish any building or structure, or any structural part thereof, that is
over four hundred (400) square feet, or connected to electric, gas, water, or
sewer lines, or has one or more party walls, without having first obtained
a demolition permit from the building inspector. Application for a permit shall
be made on a form prescribed by the building inspector.
    (B)    Permits Required – Salvage: It shall be unlawful for any person to
engage in the salvage operation—as defined in section 3-7-1 of this chapter—of
any building or structure with a value greater than ten thousand dollars, or
any structural part thereof, that is over four hundred (400) square feet, or
connected to electric, gas, water, or sewer lines, or has one or more party
walls, without having first obtained a demolition permit from the building
inspector. Application for a permit shall be made on a form prescribed by the
building inspector. Salvage operations shall be accompanied by a comprehensive
demolition plan and appropriate financial safeguards as salvage operations are
not allowed absent plans to demolish or rehabilitate the associated building.
    (C)   Expiration Of Permits: Permits for demolition shall expire sixty (60)
days after issuance. The building inspector may, upon good cause shown, extend
such date of expiration for a successive thirty (30) day period.
    (D)   Denial Of Permit: The building inspector may refuse to issue
a demolition permit when the requirements of this chapter are not met or where
a permit has already been issued for a specific property and no significant
progress has been made toward complete demolition. A permit may also be denied
when a salvage operation is not accompanied by a comprehensive demolition plan.
    (E)   Drawings Required: Applicants for a demolition permit shall provide
drawings indicating the height and location of buildings on the site, distance
from property lines and adjacent buildings, final grading, party walls,
protective canopies and such other information as may be reasonably requested
by the building inspector. The building inspector may, if he determines that
the safety of the persons or property will not be adversely affected, waive the
requirements of this subsection (E).
    (F)   Permit Fees: The building inspector shall collect fees for
all demolition permits according to the following schedule:
 
 
Estimated Cost            Fee
$1.00 to $500.00          $10.00
$500.01 to $2,000.00      $10.00 for first $500.00 plus $1.50 each additional
                          $100.00 or fraction of, to and including $2,000.00
$2,000.01 to $25,000.00   $32.50 for first $2,000.00 plus $6.00 each additional
                          $1,000.00 or fraction of, to and including $25,000.00
                          $170.00 for first $25,000.00 plus $4.50 each
$25,000.01 to $50,000.00  additional $1,000.00 or fraction of, to and including
                          $50,000.00
                          $283.00 for first $50,000.00 plus $3.00 each
$50,000.01 to $100,000.00 additional $1,000.00 or fraction of, to and including
                          $100,000.00
$100,000.01 and up        $433.00 for first $100,000.00 plus $2.50 each
                          additional $1,000.00 or fraction of
 
Section 3:   This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its passage and
publication in pamphlet form as provided by law.
 
   PRESENTED, PASSED, AND ADOPTED at a regular meeting of the City Council of
the City of Spring Valley, Bureau County, Illinois, on November 16, 2024, by a
roll call vote as follows:

ORDINANCE NO. 1907
AN ORDINANCE IMPLEMENTING A MUNICIPAL GROCERY RETAILERS’ OCCUPATION TAX AND A
MUNICIPAL GROCERY SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX
FOR THE CITY OF SPRING VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
Background Recitals
 
WHEREAS, the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, provides that the
corporate authorities of each municipality may pass all ordinances and make all
rules and regulations proper or necessary, to carry into effect the powers
granted to municipalities, with such fines or penalties as may be deemed
proper; and,
 
WHEREAS, the City of Spring Valley is a non-home rule Illinois municipality
pursuant to the Constitution of the State of Illinois of 1970, as amended; and,
 
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-24 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24)
provides that, beginning on January 1, 2026, all Illinois municipalities may
impose a tax “upon all persons engaged in the business of selling groceries at
retail in the municipality” (the “Municipal Grocery Tax”) (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24);
and,
 
WHEREAS, the Municipal Grocery Retailers’ Occupation Tax may be imposed “at the
rate of 1% of the gross receipts from these sales” (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24); and,
 
WHEREAS, any Municipal Grocery Retailers’ Occupation Tax shall be administered,
collected and enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue; and,
 
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-24 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24)
requires any municipality imposing a Municipal Grocery Retailers’ Occupation
Tax under Section 8-11-24 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24) to
also impose a Service Occupation Tax at the same rate, “upon all persons
engaged, in the municipality, in the business of making sales of service, who,
as an incident to making those sales of service, transfer groceries” as “an
incident to a sale of service” (the “Municipal Grocery Service Occupation Tax”)
(65 ILCS 5/8-11-24); and,
 
WHEREAS, any Municipal Grocery Service Occupation Tax shall be administered,
collected and enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue; and,
 
WHEREAS, the City Council believes that it is appropriate, necessary and in the
best interests of the City of Spring Valley and its residents, that the City of
Spring Valley levy a Municipal Grocery Retailers’ Occupation Tax as permitted
by Section 8-11-24 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24); and,
 
WHEREAS, the City Council believe that it is appropriate, necessary and in the
best interests of the City of Spring Valley and its residents, that the City of
Spring Valley levy a Municipal Grocery Service Occupation Tax as permitted by
Section 8-11-24 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24); and,
 
NOW, THEREFORE, be it ordained, by the City Council of the City of Spring
Valley as follows:
 
Section 1. Incorporation of Recitals. The foregoing recitals shall be and are
hereby incorporated as findings of fact as if said recitals were fully set
forth herein.
 
Section 2. Municipal Grocery Retailers’ Occupation Tax Imposed. A tax is hereby
imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling groceries at retail
in this municipality at the rate of 1% of the gross receipts from such sales
made in the course of such business while this Ordinance is in effect. The
imposition of this tax is in accordance with and subject to the provisions of
Section 8-11-24 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24).
 
Section 3. Municipal Grocery Service Occupation Tax. A tax is hereby imposed
upon all persons engaged in this municipality in the business of making sales
of service, who, as an incident to making those sales of service, transfer
groceries as an incident to a sale of service. The rate of this tax shall be
the same rate identified in Section 2, above. The imposition of this tax is in
accordance with and subject to the provisions of Section 8-11-24 of the
Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24).
 
Section 4. Illinois Department of Revenue to Administer Both Taxes. The taxes
hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident
thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Department of Revenue of the
State of Illinois. The Illinois Department of Revenue shall have full power to
administer and enforce the provisions of this Ordinance.
 
Section 5. Clerk to file Ordinance with Illinois Department of Revenue. As
required under Section 8-11-24 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-
24), the Clerk is hereby directed to file a certified copy of this Ordinance
with the Illinois Department of Revenue on or before October 1, 2025.
 
Section 6. Effective Date. The taxes imposed by this Ordinance shall take
effect on the first day of January next following the adoption and filing of
this Ordinance with the Department of Revenue, if filed on or before the
preceding October 1st.
 
Section 7. Repeal of Conflicting Provisions. All ordinances, resolutions and
policies or parts thereof, in conflict with the provisions of this Ordinance
are, to the extent of the conflict, expressly repealed on the effective date of
this Ordinance.
 
Section 8. Severability. If any provision of this Ordinance or application
thereof to any person or circumstances is ruled unconstitutional or otherwise
invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of
this Ordinance that can be given effect without the invalid application or
provision, and each invalid provision or invalid application of this Ordinance
is severable.
 
Section 9. Headings/Captions. The headings/captions identifying the various
sections and subsections of this Ordinance are for reference only and do not
define, modify, expand or limit any of the terms or provisions of the
Ordinance.
 
Section 10. Publication. The Clerk is directed by the corporate authorities to
publish this Ordinance in pamphlet form. This Ordinance shall be in full force
and effect after its passage and publication in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/1-2-
4.
 
   PRESENTED, PASSED, AND ADOPTED at a regular meeting of the City Council of
the City of Spring Valley, Bureau County, Illinois, on January 20, 2025, by a
roll call vote as follows:

ORDINANCE NO. 1908
 
AN ORDINANCE IMPLEMENTING A NON-HOME RULE MUNICIPAL RETAILERS’ OCCUPATION TAX
AND A NON-HOME RULE MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX FOR THE CITY OF SPRING
VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS
Background Recitals
 
WHEREAS, the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, provides that the
corporate authorities of each municipality may pass all ordinances and make all
rules and regulations proper or necessary, to carry into effect the powers
granted to municipalities, with such fines or penalties as may be deemed
proper; and,
 
WHEREAS, the City of Spring Valley is a non-home rule Illinois municipality
pursuant to the Constitution of the State of Illinois of 1970, as amended; and,
 
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-1.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.1)
empowers non-home rule Illinois municipalities to impose certain Municipal
Retailers’ Occupation Taxes as outlined at Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois
Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3) (the “Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers’
Occupation Tax”); and,
 
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-1.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.1)
empowers non-home rule Illinois municipalities to impose certain Municipal
Service Occupation Taxes as outlined at Section 8-11-1.4 of the Illinois
Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.4) (the “Non-Home Rule Municipal Service
Occupation Tax”); and,
 
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3)
empowers a non-home rule municipality to “impose a tax upon all persons engaged
in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than on an item of
tangible personal property which is titled and registered by an agency of this
State's Government, at retail in the municipality” based upon the “gross
receipts from such sales made in the course of such business” for “expenditure
on public infrastructure or for property tax relief or both” as defined in
Section 8-11-1.2 (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.2); and,
 
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-1.4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.4)
empowers a non-home rule municipality to “impose a tax upon all persons
engaged, in such municipality, in the business of making sales of service . . .
of the selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by such
servicemen either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of
real estate as an incident to a sale of service;” and,
 
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3)
and Section 8-11-1.4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.4)
empower the City of Spring Valley to impose the Non-Home Rule Municipal
Retailers’ Occupation Tax and the Non-Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation
Tax in 1/4% increments up to 1%; and,
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3)
requires any municipality imposing a Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers’
Occupation Tax under Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS
5/8-11-1.3) to impose a Non-Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax under
Section 8-11-1.4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.4) at “the
same rate” as the rate imposed as the Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers’
Occupation Tax being imposed; and,
 
WHEREAS, any Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers’ Occupation Tax imposed by the
City of Spring Valley under Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65
ILCS 5/8-11-1.3) shall be administered, collected and enforced by the Illinois
Department of Revenue; and,
 
WHEREAS, any Non-Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax imposed by the City
of Spring Valley under Section 8-11-1.4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS
5/8-11-1.4) shall be administered, collected and enforced by the Illinois
Department of Revenue; and,
 
WHEREAS, proceeds generated from the imposition of any Non-Home Rule Municipal
Retailers’ Occupation Tax or Non-Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax by
the City of Spring Valley must be used for “public infrastructure” or “property
tax relief,” as those terms are defined at Section 8-11-1.2 of the Illinois
Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.2); and,
 
WHEREAS, the City Council believe that it is appropriate, necessary, and in the
best interests of the City of Spring Valley and its residents, that the City of
Spring Valley levy a Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers’ Occupation Tax pursuant
to Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3) and a
Non-Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax pursuant to Section 8-11-1.4 of
the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.4) so that the City of Spring
Valley can provide property tax relief and invest in public infrastructure, as
those terms are defined at Section 8-11-1.2 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65
ILCS 5/8-11-1.2).
 
NOW, THEREFORE, be it ordained, by the City Council of Spring Valley as
follows:
 
Section 1. Incorporation of Recitals. The foregoing recitals shall be and are
hereby incorporated as findings of fact as if said recitals were fully set
forth herein.
 
Section 2. Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers’ Occupation Tax Imposed. A tax is
hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible
personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property titled or
registered with an agency of this state's government, at retail in this
municipality at the rate of 1% of the gross receipts from such sales made in
the course of such business while this Ordinance is in effect. The imposition
of this tax is in accordance with and subject to the provisions of Section 8-
11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3).
 
Section 3. Non-Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax Imposed. A tax is
hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this municipality in the business of
making sales of service, of the selling price of all tangible personal property
transferred by such serviceman as an incident to a sale of service. The rate of
this tax shall be the same rate identified in Section 2, above. The imposition
of this tax is in accordance with and subject to the provisions of Section 8-
11-1.4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.4).
 
Section 4. Illinois Department of Revenue to Administer Both Taxes. The taxes
hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident
thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Department of Revenue of the
State of Illinois. The Department of Revenue shall have full power to
administer and enforce the provisions of this Ordinance.
 
Section 5. Clerk to file Ordinance with Illinois Department of Revenue. As
required under Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-
1.3), the Clerk is hereby directed to file a certified copy of this Ordinance
with the Illinois Department of Revenue on or before April 1, 2025.
 
Section 6. Effective Date. This Ordinance shall take effect on the first day of
July next following the adoption and filing of this Ordinance with the
Department of Revenue, if filed on or before the preceding April 1st.
 
Section 7. Limitation on Use of Proceeds. The City of Spring Valley shall only
expend the proceeds generated from any tax imposed by virtue of this Ordinance
on: (a) expenditures related to “municipal roads and streets, access roads,
bridges, and sidewalks; waste disposal systems; and water and sewer line
extensions, water distribution and purification facilities, storm water
drainage and retention facilities, and sewage treatment facilities[;]” (b)
efforts to “reduce the levy for real estate taxes or avoid an increase in the
levy for real estate taxes that would otherwise have been required” by the City
of Spring Valley; or (c) any other or further permitted uses under Section 8-
11-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1) as may now or hereafter
be authorized therein.
 
Section 8. Qualified Exemption of Aviation Fuel from Both Taxes. No provision
of this Ordinance shall be interpreted to impose any tax on aviation fuel, as
defined in Section 3 of the Retailers’ Occupation Tax Act (35 ILCS 120/3),
unless the proceeds of said tax are expended for airport-related purposes, as
that term is defined in Section 6z-20.2 of the State Finance Act (30 ILCS 105/
6z-20.2), and said expenditures are made in compliance with the certification
requirements for airport-related purposes under Section 2-22 of the Retailers'
Occupation Tax Act (35 ILCS 120/2–22).
 
Section 9. Repeal of Conflicting Provisions. All ordinances, resolutions and
policies or parts thereof, in conflict with the provisions of this Ordinance
are, to the extent of the conflict, expressly repealed on the effective date of
this Ordinance.
 
Section 10. Severability. If any provision of this Ordinance or application
thereof to any person or circumstances is ruled unconstitutional or otherwise
invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of
this Ordinance that can be given effect without the invalid application or
provision, and each invalid provision or invalid application of this Ordinance
is severable.
 
Section 11. Headings/Captions. The headings/captions identifying the various
sections and subsections of this Ordinance are for reference only and do not
define, modify, expand or limit any of the terms or provisions of the
Ordinance.
 
Section 12. Publication. The Clerk is directed by the corporate authorities to
publish this Ordinance in pamphlet form. This Ordinance shall be in full force
and effect after its passage and publication in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/1-2-
4.
 
   PRESENTED, PASSED, AND ADOPTED at a regular meeting of the City Council of
the City of Spring Valley, Bureau County, Illinois, on January 20, 2025, by a
roll call vote as follows:

ORDINANCE NO. 1909
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING THE NON-HOME RULE MUNICIPAL RETAILERS’ OCCUPATION TAX AND
A NON-HOME RULE MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX ORDINANCE FOR THE CITY OF
SPRING VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS
Background Recitals
 
WHEREAS, the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, provides that the
corporate authorities of each municipality may pass all ordinances and make all
rules and regulations proper or necessary, to carry into effect the powers
granted to municipalities, with such fines or penalties as may be deemed
proper; and,
 
WHEREAS, the City of Spring Valley is a non-home rule Illinois municipality
pursuant to the Constitution of the State of Illinois of 1970, as amended; and,
 
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-1.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.1)
empowers non-home rule Illinois municipalities to impose certain Municipal
Retailers’ Occupation Taxes as outlined at Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois
Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3) (the “Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers’
Occupation Tax”); and,
 
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-1.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.1)
empowers non-home rule Illinois municipalities to impose certain Municipal
Service Occupation Taxes as outlined at Section 8-11-1.4 of the Illinois
Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.4) (the “Non-Home Rule Municipal Service
Occupation Tax”); and,
 
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3)
empowers a non-home rule municipality to “impose a tax upon all persons engaged
in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than on an item of
tangible personal property which is titled and registered by an agency of this
State's Government, at retail in the municipality” based upon the “gross
receipts from such sales made in the course of such business” for “expenditure
on public infrastructure or for property tax relief or both” as defined in
Section 8-11-1.2 (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.2); and,
 
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-1.4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.4)
empowers a non-home rule municipality to “impose a tax upon all persons
engaged, in such municipality, in the business of making sales of service . . .
of the selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by such
servicemen either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of
real estate as an incident to a sale of service;” and,
 
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3)
and Section 8-11-1.4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.4)
empower the City of Spring Valley to impose the Non-Home Rule Municipal
Retailers’ Occupation Tax and the Non-Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation
Tax in 1/4% increments up to 1%; and,
WHEREAS, Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3)
requires any municipality imposing a Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers’
Occupation Tax under Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS
5/8-11-1.3) to impose a Non-Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax under
Section 8-11-1.4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.4) at “the
same rate” as the rate imposed as the Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers’
Occupation Tax being imposed; and,
 
WHEREAS, any Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers’ Occupation Tax imposed by the
City of Spring Valley under Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65
ILCS 5/8-11-1.3) shall be administered, collected and enforced by the Illinois
Department of Revenue; and,
 
WHEREAS, any Non-Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax imposed by the City
of Spring Valley under Section 8-11-1.4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS
5/8-11-1.4) shall be administered, collected and enforced by the Illinois
Department of Revenue; and,
 
WHEREAS, proceeds generated from the imposition of any Non-Home Rule Municipal
Retailers’ Occupation Tax or Non-Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax by
the City of Spring Valley must be used for “public infrastructure” or “property
tax relief,” as those terms are defined at Section 8-11-1.2 of the Illinois
Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.2); and,
 
WHEREAS, the City Council believes that it is appropriate, necessary, and in
the best interests of the City of Spring Valley and its residents, that the
City of Spring Valley to amend its previously imposed Non-Home Rule Municipal
Retailers’ Occupation Tax pursuant to Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois
Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3) and Non-Home Rule Municipal Service
Occupation Tax pursuant to Section 8-11-1.4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65
ILCS 5/8-11-1.4) so that the City of Spring Valley can provide property tax
relief and invest in public infrastructure, as those terms are defined at
Section 8-11-1.2 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.2), and to
clarify the portion of the new rate that represents the amount imposed under
referendum authority in order to preserve the right to impose an additional 1%.
 
NOW, THEREFORE, be it ordained, by the City Council of Spring Valley as
follows:
 
Section 1. Incorporation of Recitals. The foregoing recitals shall be and are
hereby incorporated as findings of fact as if said recitals were fully set
forth herein.
 
Section 2. Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers’ Occupation Tax Imposed. A tax is
hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible
personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property titled or
registered with an agency of this state's government, at retail in this
municipality at the rate of 1% (0.5% approved by referendum and 0.5% approved
by ordinance only) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of
such business while this Ordinance is in effect. The imposition of this tax is
in accordance with and subject to the provisions of Section 8-11-1.3 of the
Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3).
 
Section 3. Non-Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax Imposed. A tax is
hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this municipality in the business of
making sales of service, of the selling price of all tangible personal property
transferred by such serviceman as an incident to a sale of service. The rate of
this tax shall be the same rate identified in Section 2, above. The imposition
of this tax is in accordance with and subject to the provisions of Section 8-
11-1.4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.4).
 
Section 4. Illinois Department of Revenue to Administer Both Taxes. The taxes
hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident
thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Department of Revenue of the
State of Illinois. The Department of Revenue shall have full power to
administer and enforce the provisions of this Ordinance.
 
Section 5. Clerk to file Ordinance with Illinois Department of Revenue. As
required under Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-
1.3), the Clerk is hereby directed to file a certified copy of this Ordinance
with the Illinois Department of Revenue on or before April 1, 2025.
 
Section 6. Effective Date. This Ordinance shall take effect on the first day of
July next following the adoption and filing of this Ordinance with the
Department of Revenue, if filed on or before the preceding April 1st.
 
Section 7. Limitation on Use of Proceeds. The City of Spring Valley shall only
expend the proceeds generated from any tax imposed by virtue of this Ordinance
on: (a) expenditures related to “municipal roads and streets, access roads,
bridges, and sidewalks; waste disposal systems; and water and sewer line
extensions, water distribution and purification facilities, storm water
drainage and retention facilities, and sewage treatment facilities[;]” (b)
efforts to “reduce the levy for real estate taxes or avoid an increase in the
levy for real estate taxes that would otherwise have been required” by the City
of Spring Valley; or (c) any other or further permitted uses under Section 8-
11-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1) as may now or hereafter
be authorized therein.
 
Section 8. Qualified Exemption of Aviation Fuel from Both Taxes. No provision
of this Ordinance shall be interpreted to impose any tax on aviation fuel, as
defined in Section 3 of the Retailers’ Occupation Tax Act (35 ILCS 120/3),
unless the proceeds of said tax are expended for airport-related purposes, as
that term is defined in Section 6z-20.2 of the State Finance Act (30 ILCS 105/
6z-20.2), and said expenditures are made in compliance with the certification
requirements for airport-related purposes under Section 2-22 of the Retailers'
Occupation Tax Act (35 ILCS 120/2–22).
 
Section 9. Repeal of Conflicting Provisions. All ordinances, resolutions and
policies or parts thereof, in conflict with the provisions of this Ordinance
are, to the extent of the conflict, expressly repealed on the effective date of
this Ordinance.
 
Section 10. Severability. If any provision of this Ordinance or application
thereof to any person or circumstances is ruled unconstitutional or otherwise
invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of
this Ordinance that can be given effect without the invalid application or
provision, and each invalid provision or invalid application of this Ordinance
is severable.
 
Section 11. Headings/Captions. The headings/captions identifying the various
sections and subsections of this Ordinance are for reference only and do not
define, modify, expand or limit any of the terms or provisions of the
Ordinance.
 
Section 12. Publication. The Clerk is directed by the corporate authorities to
publish this Ordinance in pamphlet form. This Ordinance shall be in full force
and effect after its passage and publication in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/1-2-
4.

ORDINANCE NO.    1912   
 
AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING AND DIRECTING THE REMOVAL
OF A YIELD SIGN AND THE ERECTION OF A STOP SIGN AT THE
INTERSECTION OF SAXON PLACE AND WESTMINSTER DRIVE
IN THE CITY OF SPRING VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
Background Recitals
 
WHEREAS, The City of Spring Valley has previously erected a yield sign at the
intersection of Saxon Place and Westminster Drive; and
 
WHEREAS, The Mayor and City Council of the City of Spring Valley deem it to be
in the best interests of the public health, safety, and welfare of the
residents of the City of Spring Valley to remove the existing yield sign at the
intersection of Saxon Place and Westminster Drive and replace it with a stop
sign.
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF SPRING
VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AS FOLLOWS BELOW.
 
Section 1:   The findings contained in the Background Recitals to this
Ordinance are found to be true and correct and are hereby adopted as part of
this Ordinance.
 
Section 2:   The Mayor and City Council of the City of Spring Valley, Bureau
County, Illinois, does hereby authorize and direct its Superintendent to remove
the existing yield sign at the intersection of Saxon Place and Westminster
Drive and to erect a stop sign in its place.
 
Section 3:   This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its passage and
publication in pamphlet form as provided by law.
 
   PRESENTED, PASSED, AND ADOPTED at a regular meeting of the City Council of
the City of Spring Valley, Bureau County, Illinois, on March 17, 2025, by a
roll call vote as follows:

ORDINANCE NO.    1913   
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 8, STANDING COMMITTEES,
OF CHAPTER 7, COUNCIL, OF TITLE 1, ADMINISTRATIVE, OF THE CITY CODE
FOR THE CITY OF SPRING VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
Background Recitals
 
WHEREAS, Section 8, STANDING COMMITTEES, of Chapter 7, COUNCIL, of Title 1,
ADMINISTRATIVE, of the City Code establishes the standing committees of the
City Council; and
 
WHEREAS, The City Council would like to amend Section 8, STANDING COMMITTEES,
of Chapter 7, COUNCIL, of Title 1, ADMINISTRATIVE, to eliminate the position of
co-chairman for said standing committees.
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF SPRING
VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AS FOLLOWS BELOW.
 
Section 1:   The findings contained in the Background Recitals to this
Ordinance are found to be true and correct and are hereby adopted as part of
this Ordinance.
 
Section 2:   Section 8, STANDING COMMITTEES, of Chapter 7, COUNCIL, of Title 1,
ADMINISTRATIVE of the City Code is hereby amended as follows (deletions are
shown in strikeout font and additions are shown in underlined, bold italics
font):
 
It shall be the duty of the Mayor at the first regular meeting of the Council
in the month of May each year, or as soon thereafter as practicable, to appoint
a chairman and co-chairman of the following five (5) standing committees of the
council:
 
Finance Committee.
Legislative Committee.
Public Health and Safety Committee.
Public Streets and Property Committee.
Public Utilities Committee.
 
All council members shall be members of each standing committee. (1972 Code;
amd. Ord. 1813, 5-17-2021; Ord. [insert], 4-7-2025 )
 
Section 3:   All of the remaining provisions of Section 8, STANDING COMMITTEES,
of Chapter 7, COUNCIL, of Title 1, ADMINISTRATIVE, of the Spring Valley City
Code not otherwise amended by this ordinance shall remain in full force and
effect.
 
Section 3:   This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its passage and
publication in pamphlet form as provided by law and shall be incorporated into
the Spring Valley City Code.
 
   PRESENTED, PASSED, AND ADOPTED at a regular meeting of the City Council of
the City of Spring Valley, Bureau County, Illinois, on April 7, 2025, by a roll
call vote as follows:

ORDINANCE NO.  1914
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 4, LICENSE REQUIRED,
OF CHAPTER 11, RESIDENTIAL RENTAL PROPERTY,
OF TITLE 3, BUILDING REGULATIONS, OF THE CITY CODE
FOR THE CITY OF SPRING VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
Background Recitals
 
WHEREAS, The City of Spring Valley has authority to issue licenses and abate
nuisances pursuant to the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-60-2); and
 
WHEREAS, The Spring Valley City Council previously used that authority to
establish regulations and licensing requirements on Residential Rental
Properties within the City; and
 
WHEREAS, The Mayor and City Council of the City of Spring Valley deem it to be
in the best interests of the public health, safety, and welfare of the
residents of the City of Spring Valley to clarify when overdue license payments
are due for Residential Rental Properties within the City.
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF SPRING
VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AS FOLLOWS BELOW.
 
Section 1:   The findings contained in the Background Recitals to this
Ordinance are found to be true and correct and are hereby adopted as part of
this Ordinance.
 
Section 2:   Subsection (B) of Section 5, LICENSE APPLICATION, of Chapter 11,
RESIDENTIAL RENTAL PROPERTY, of Title 3, BUILDING REGULATIONS, of the Spring
Valley City Code shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced by the following
new Subsection (B):
 
   (B) Each application for a new license or a renewal of an existing license
shall be accompanied by a fee of Twenty-Five Dollars ($25.00) for single family
residential rental property, multiple family dwelling residential rental
property, or rooming house residential property. In addition, an additional
dwelling unit and a rooming unit fee of Ten Dollars ($10.00) will be assessed
for each dwelling unit(s) and rooming unit(s) in excess of one. All such fees
shall be required to be paid with any new license application. Additionally,
the fee(s) for any prior years where a license for residential rental property
was required by this Code but not obtained shall be due and payable at that
time. Any newly issued license shall be valid unless suspended and/or revoked,
as provided herein, from the date of issuance up to and including December 31
st of the year of issuance. All residential rental licenses shall expire on
December 31 st of each year. The charge for any license renewal after an
initial license has been issued shall be Twenty-Five Dollars ($25.00). In the
event that any license application fee due in regards to a renewal of an
existing license shall not be paid by December 31 st of any given year, then,
in that event, there shall be an additional late charge assessed in the amount
of Fifty Dollars ($50.00). All fees and charges required by this Subsection
shall be due and payable at the Office of the Spring Valley City Clerk and
Billing Department.
 
Section 3:   All of the remaining provisions of Section 5, License Application,
of Chapter 11, RESIDENTIAL RENTAL PROPERTY, of Title 3, BUILDING REGULATIONS,
of the Spring Valley City Code not otherwise amended by this ordinance shall
remain in full force and effect.
 
Section 4:   This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its passage and
publication in pamphlet form as provided by law.
 
 
   PRESENTED, PASSED, AND ADOPTED at a regular meeting of the City Council of
the City of Spring Valley, Bureau County, Illinois, on April 7, 2025, by a roll
call vote as follows:

VanSchaick         X
Herrmann           X
Affelt             X
Chiaventone        X
Campbell           X
Baltikauski        X
Pellegrini         X
Bogacz             X
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
APPROVED:                  ATTEST:
 
 
                                    
Melanie Malooley Thompson, Mayor         Rebecca Hansen, City Clerk
 
 
 
 
 
ORDINANCE NO.    1917   
 
AN ORDINANCE CREATINGTHE POSITIONS OF ACTIVITIES & PROGRAM
COORDINATOR AND EVENT & MARKETING MANAGER FOR THE COMMUNITY
CENTER OF THE CITY OF SPRING VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
Background Recitals
 
WHEREAS, The City of Spring Valley has been in the process of developing a
Community Center as a space for the community to gather, as well as a place to
host various activities, events, and programs; and
 
WHEREAS, The Community Center is nearing completion; and
 
WHEREAS, The City of Spring Valley desires to create the part-time positions of
Activities & Program Coordinator and Event & Marketing Manager to facilitate
the use and enjoyment of the Community Center; and
 
WHEREAS, The employees hired to the positions of Activities & Program
Coordinator and Event & Marketing Manager shall not work more hours than
allowed to be worked by employees before they must be enrolled in the Illinois
Municipal Retirement Fund according to its rules and regulations; and
 
WHEREAS, The City of Spring Valley has the authority to create the new
positions and to establish the duties, title and remuneration of the Activities
& Program Coordinator and Event & Marketing Manager pursuant to the authority
granted by Section 10-4-1 of the Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/10-4-1); and
 
WHEREAS, The Mayor and City Council of the City of Spring Valley deem it to be
in the best interests of the public health, safety, and welfare of the
residents of the City of Spring Valley to create the positions of Activities &
Program Coordinator and Event & Marketing Manager for its Community Center.
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF SPRING
VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AS FOLLOWS BELOW.
 
Section 1:   The findings contained in the Background Recitals to this
Ordinance are found to be true and correct and are hereby adopted as part of
this Ordinance.
 
Section 2:   The Following Chapter 34, COMMUNITY CENTER, of Title 1,
ADMINISTRATIVE, of the Spring Valley City Code shall added to the City Code:
 
CHAPTER 34 COMMUNITY CENTER
 
1-34-1: Activities & Program Coordinator
 
(A)   The City of Spring Valley hereby establishes the position of Activities &
Program Coordinator for the Community Center. The Activities & Program
Coordinator shall be responsible for developing and implementing a variety of
programs and activities that cater to the needs and interests of the community
members. This includes scheduling public and private events, maintaining the
community calendar, and collaborating with local organizations, businesses, and
volunteers to organize activities that promote community engagement and
participation. Additionally, the Coordinator shall serve as a point of contact
for community members, addressing their concerns, providing information about
activities and programming, and fostering a sense of community within the
Community Center. The Coordinator shall work closely with the Event & Marketing
Manager, sharing ideas and providing feedback to ensure the success of hosted
events and their positive impact on the community. Other duties that arise will
be a shared responsibility of the Coordinator and the Event & Marketing
Manager.
 
(B)   The Activities & Program Coordinator for the Community Center of the City
of Spring Valley shall report his or her activities to the Spring Valley City
Council and provide the Spring Valley City Council with periodic updates on his
or her activities and accomplishments. The Activities & Program Coordinator for
the Community Center of the City of Spring Valley shall report directly to the
Mayor of the City of Spring Valley and be supervised by the Mayor of the City
of Spring Valley with additional reporting to the Spring Valley City Council as
set forth in this section.
 
1-34-2: Event and Marketing Manager
 
(A)   The City of Spring Valley hereby establishes the position of Event &
Marketing Manager for the Community Center. The Event & Marketing Manager shall
be responsible for supervising and managing events at the Community Center.
This includes creating and distributing promotional materials, managing online
content for social media posts and website updates, and building and
maintaining positive relationships with community members, local businesses,
and media outlets to enhance the participation in and coverage of events. The
Manager shall work with community leaders and residents to identify their needs
and interests, collaborate with the Activities & Program Director, and ensure a
safe and welcoming environment for all visitors. Additionally, the Manager
shall collaborate with local organizations and businesses on the marketing and
promotion of events. The Manager shall assist in the supervision of events held
in the Community Center. The Manager shall work closely with the Activities &
Program Coordinator, sharing ideas and providing feedback to ensure the success
of hosted events and their positive impact on the community. Other duties that
arise will be a shared responsibility of the Manager and the Activities &
Program Coordinator.
 
(B)   The Event & Marketing Manager for the Community Center of the City of
Spring Valley shall report his or her activities to the Spring Valley City
Council and provide the Spring Valley City Council with periodic updates on his
or her activities and accomplishments. The Event & Marketing Manager for the
Community Center of the City of Spring Valley shall report directly to the
Mayor of the City of Spring Valley and be supervised by the Mayor of the City
of Spring Valley with additional reporting to the Spring Valley City Council as
set forth in this section.
 
Section 3:   This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its passage and
publication in pamphlet form as provided by law.
 
   PRESENTED, PASSED, AND ADOPTED at a regular meeting of the City Council of
the City of Spring Valley, Bureau County, Illinois, on May 19, 2025, by a roll
call vote as follows:

ORDINANCE NO. 1919
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING CHAPTER 18, ALCOHOLIC LIQUORS,
OF TITLE 5, BUSINESS REGULATIONS, OF THE CITY CODE OF
THE CITY OF SPRING VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
Background Recitals
 
 
WHEREAS, Chapter 18, Alcoholic Liquors, of Title 5, Business Regulations, of
the Spring Valley City Code establishes the regulations for the licensing and
sale of alcoholic liquors in the City of Spring Valley; and
WHEREAS, the Mayor and the City Council desire to add a supplemental class of
liquor license that would allow existing liquor license holders to serve
alcohol temporarily at a location other than the premises that the licensee is
licensed to operate; and
WHEREAS, the City Code does not currently provide for such a supplemental
license; and
WHEREAS, the City of Spring Valley is authorized to regulate the number, kind,
and classification of local liquor licenses pursuant to Section 5/4-1 of the
Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS 5/4-1).
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF SPRING
VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AS FOLLOWS BELOW.
 
   Section 1:   The findings contained in the Background Recitals to this
Ordinance are found to be true and correct and are hereby adopted as part of
this Ordinance.
 
   Section 2:   A new Section 5-18-27.10 of Chapter 18, Alcoholic Liquors, of
Title 5, Business Regulations, of the Spring Valley City Code is created and
shall read as follows:
 
5-18-27.10: CLASS TE Temporary Extension of Premises Liquor License:
A Class TE Temporary Extension of Premises liquor license authorizes the retail
sale of alcohol by the current holder of a Class A, Class A-1, Class A-2, Class
C, and Class D liquor license at nonresidential public premises other than the
premises covered by the existing license at locations and on days approved by
the Liquor Control Commissioner. All of the terms and conditions of the license
holder’s primary liquor license shall extend and apply to the Class TE license
issued. The license holder must submit proof of adequate Dram Shop Insurance
covering the premises licensed under the Class TE liquor license prior to being
issued such a license. Any violation of the terms of the Class TE license shall
be considered a violation of the license holder’s primary liquor license and
shall subject the license holder to penalties and/or sanctions on the primary
liquor license.
 
(A)   A liquor license shall permit the sale of alcohol only in the premises
described in the liquor license application and license except that the Liquor
Control Commissioner, or their designee, may issue to the holder of a primary
liquor license a second premises license, a Class TE liquor license, which
authorizes the licensee to operate temporarily at a location other than the
premises at which said licensee is licensed to operate. Any licensee desiring a
Class TE license shall submit an application containing the name of the
licensee, a description of the temporary location, the expected dates and hours
of operation, and any other information relevant to the sale of alcohol at that
location that the Liquor Control Commissioner may request. No Class TE license
will be issued for any premises which is not a proper location for the retail
sale of alcohol under the laws of the State of Illinois or the City Code of
Spring Valley.
 
(B)   An application, made on forms provided by the City Clerk, must be
submitted at least seven days prior to the date of the planned event to allow
for the license application to be processed. The application must contain the
following information:
1. The legal name of the applicant and any DBA, if applicable;
2. Contact information of the applicant, including an address, phone number,
and email address;
3. The date and time of the event;
4. A description of the event, including the location(s) not contained in the
licensee’s current licensed premises that will be considered under the
application as a temporary extension of premises;
5. An event site plan, including an identification of the area(s) where alcohol
will be stored and served;
6. Proof of adequate Dram Shop Insurance covering the premises proposed to be
licensed under the Class TE liquor license; and
7. Any other information or documents determined to be necessary by the Liquor
Control Commissioner.
 
C.   The fee for the application for a Class TE liquor license shall be as
established in Section 5-18-28, License Fees, of this Chapter.
 
   Section 3:   Section 5-18-1, Definitions, of Chapter 18, Alcoholic Liquors,
of Title 5, Business Regulations, of the Spring Valley City Code is hereby
amended with the following additional definition, to be incorporated in with
the currently established definitions in alphabetical order:
 
TEMPORARY EXTENSION OF PREMISES: An authorization to sell or serve alcohol
temporarily at a location other than the premises that the licensee is licensed
to operate.
 
   Section 4:   Section 5-18-28, License Fees, of Chapter 18, Alcoholic
Liquors, of Title 5, Business Regulations, of the Spring Valley City Code is
hereby amended to add the following fee to the existing table of license fees:
 
CLASS “TE”      $10.00/day
 
Section 5:   All of the remaining provisions of Chapter 18, ALCOHOLIC LIQUORS,
of Title 5, BUSINESS REGULATIONS, of the Spring Valley City Code not otherwise
amended by this Ordinance shall remain in full force and effect.
 
Section 6:   This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its passage,
approval, and publication in pamphlet form as provided by law.
 
 
   PRESENTED, PASSED, AND ADOPTED at a regular meeting of the City Council of
the City of Spring Valley, Bureau County, Illinois, on July 21, 2025, by a roll
call vote as follows:

ORDINANCE NO.    1920   
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING NOISE REGULATIONS AND REQUIRING
THE IDENTIFICATION OF CONTRACTOR VEHICLES
FOR THE CITY OF SPRING VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
Background Recitals
 
WHEREAS, the City of Spring Valley, in an effort to regulate excessive noise
that could disturb the repose, health, peace and safety of its citizens, has
previously regulated the hours that contractors could work on the construction,
alteration, and repair of a building or the excavation of streets and highways;
and
 
WHEREAS, The Mayor and City Council believe that it would be in the best
interests of the citizens of Spring Valley to amend the hours that contractors
can operate without violating the City’s noise ordinance; and
 
WHEREAS, The Mayor and City Council further believe it would be in the best
interests of the safety and welfare of the citizens of the City of Spring
Valley to require contractors to have their vehicles identified by company name
when operating in the City of Spring Valley;
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF SPRING
VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AS FOLLOWS BELOW.
 
Section 1:   The findings contained in the Background Recitals to this
Ordinance are found to be true and correct and are hereby adopted as part of
this Ordinance.
 
Section 2:   Subsection (D), CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR OF BUILDING, EXCAVATION OF
STREETS AND HIGHWAYS, of Section 5, EXEMPTIONS, of Chapter 14, NOISE, of Title
6, POLICE REGULATIONS of the City Code is hereby deleted and replaced by the
following new Subsection (D):
 
(D) Construction Noise: The construction, demolition, alteration, or repair of
any building, the excavation of streets and highways, and any construction or
utility work in the City rights-of-way is allowed only between the hours of
seven o’clock (7:00) AM and seven o’clock (7:00) PM. In cases of emergency,
however, construction and repair noises are exempt.
 
Section 3:   All of the remaining provisions of Section 5, EXEMPTIONS, of
Chapter 14, NOISE, of Title 6, POLICE REGULATIONS of the Spring Valley City
Code not otherwise amended by this ordinance shall remain in full force and
effect.
 
Section 4:   Section 8, ANNUAL REGISTRATION FOR CONTRACTORS, of Chapter 10,
BUILDING PERMIT FEES AND INSPECTIONS, of Title 3, BUILDING REGULATIONS, of the
City Code is hereby amended by the addition of the following subsection:
 
   (E) Vehicles owned or used by a contractor, construction equipment that is
capable of being self-propelled or any construction equipment capable of being
towed shall display on the side of the equipment the name of the company for
which it is employed. The name shall be in letters at least 2 inches tall and
one-half inch wide. This Section shall not apply to any motor vehicle upon
which is affixed the insignia required under Section 18c-4701 of the Illinois
Commercial Transportation Law. Any person or company convicted of violating
this Section shall be subject to a fine not less than $100 and to exceed $750.
 
Section 5:   All of the remaining provisions of Section 8, ANNUAL REGISTRATION
FOR CONTRACTORS, of Chapter 10, BUILDING PERMIT FEES AND INSPECTIONS, of Title
3, BUILDING REGULATIONS, of the Spring Valley City Code not otherwise amended
by this ordinance shall remain in full force and effect.
 
Section 6:   This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its passage and
publication in pamphlet form as provided by law and shall be incorporated into
the Spring Valley City Code.
 
   PRESENTED, PASSED, AND ADOPTED at a regular meeting of the City Council of
the City of Spring Valley, Bureau County, Illinois, on August 4, 2025, by a
roll call vote as follows:

ORDINANCE NO.    1921   
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING AND UPDATING CERTAIN CITY CODE PROVISIONS
FOR THE CITY OF SPRING VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
Background Recitals
 
WHEREAS , the Mayor and City Council of the City of Spring Valley have been
reviewing the City Code and would like to update certain Sections therein; and
 
WHEREAS, Section 3, DEFINITIONS, of Chapter 12, VACANT BUILDINGS AND PROPERTY,
of Title 3, BUILDING REGULATIONS, of the City Code defines the terms relating
to vacant buildings and property within the City of Spring Valley, including a
definition of “building inspector”; and
 
WHEREAS, The City Council would like to amend Section 3, DEFINITIONS, of
Chapter 12, VACANT BUILDINGS AND PROPERTY, of Title 3, BUILDING REGULATIONS, to
update the definition of “building inspector” to include any deputy building
inspector appointed by the City Council; and
 
WHEREAS, Section 2, ABANDONMENT OF VEHICLES, of Chapter 7, INOPERABLE AND
ABANDONED VEHICLES, of Title 6, POLICE REGULATIONS, of the City Code states a
general prohibition on the abandonment of vehicles on highways and public or
private property within the City of Spring Valley; and
 
WHEREAS, The City Council would like to amend Section 2, ABANDONMENT OF
VEHICLES, of Chapter 7, INOPERABLE AND ABANDONED VEHICLES, of Title 6, POLICE
REGULATIONS, to clarify that inoperable vehicles are considered an abandoned
vehicle and that, in addition to highways, the abandonment of a vehicle is also
prohibited on streets and alleys; and
 
WHEREAS, Section 1, PUBLIC PARKS DESIGNATED, of Chapter 6, PUBLIC PARKS, of
Title 8, PUBLIC WAYS, UTILITIES AND SUBDIVISIONS, of the City Code designates
the public parks withing the City of Spring Valley; and
 
WHEREAS, The City Council would like to amend Section 1, PUBLIC PARKS
DESIGNATED, of Chapter 6, PUBLIC PARKS, of Title 8, PUBLIC WAYS, UTILITIES AND
SUBDIVISIONS, to update the designation of public parks in the City; and
 
WHEREAS, Section 3, RESPONSIBLE BIDDER, of Chapter 19, PURCHASING, of Title 1,
ADMINISTRATIVE, of the City Code establishes the minimum qualifications and
requirements for a responsible bidder for construction contracts, as well as
when the City will require a responsible bidder for public works projects; and
 
WHEREAS, The City Council would like to amend Section 3, RESPONSIBLE BIDDER, of
Chapter 19, PURCHASING, of Title 1, ADMINISTRATIVE, to clarify the minimum
expenditure necessary to require a bidder to comply with the minimum
qualifications and requirements of a responsible bidder as outlined in this
Section; and
 
WHEREAS, Section 2, DESIGNATION OF NUMBERS, of Chapter 8, HOUSE NUMBERING, of
Title 8, PUBLIC WAYS, UTILITIES AND SUBDIVISIONS, of the City Code establishes
the method for the numbering of buildings and lots in the City of Spring
Valley; and
 
WHEREAS, The City Council would like to amend Section 2, DESIGNATION OF
NUMBERS, of Chapter 8, HOUSE NUMBERING, of Title 8, PUBLIC WAYS, UTILITIES AND
SUBDIVISIONS, to clarify the numbering of lots in additional subdivisions
within the City; and
 
WHEREAS, Section 13, NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS, of Chapter 9, PROPERTY MAINTENANCE
AND OCCUPANCY CODE, of Title 3, BUILDING REGULATIONS, of the City Code outlines
the requirements for notice of a violation of the Property Maintenance and
Occupancy code and the penalties for noncompliance; and
 
WHEREAS, The City Council would like to amend Section 13, NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS,
of Chapter 9, PROPERTY MAINTENANCE AND OCCUPANCY CODE, of Title 3, BUILDING
REGULATIONS, to update amount of the fine if the Property Maintenance and
Occupancy Code is violated and not remedied after proper notice has been given.
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF SPRING
VALLEY, BUREAU COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AS FOLLOWS BELOW.
 
Section 1:   The findings contained in the Background Recitals to this
Ordinance are found to be true and correct and are hereby adopted as part of
this Ordinance.
 
Section 2:   The definition of “BUILDING INSPECTOR” in Section 3, DEFINITIONS,
of Chapter 12, VACANT BUILDINGS AND PROPERTY, of Title 3, BUILDING REGULATIONS
of the City Code is hereby amended as follows (deletions are shown in strikeout
font and additions are shown in underlined, bold italics font):
 
BUILDING INSPECTOR: The City of Spring Valley building inspector , or his or
her designee , deputy building inspector, or any employee of the engineering
firm chosen by the City of Spring Valley to serve as City Engineer.
 
Section 3:   All of the remaining provisions of Section 3, DEFINITIONS, of
Chapter 12, VACANT BUILDINGS AND PROPERTY, of Title 3, BUILDING REGULATIONS, of
the Spring Valley City Code not otherwise amended by this ordinance shall
remain in full force and effect.
 
Section 4:   Section 2, ABANDONMENT OF VEHICLES, of Chapter 7, INOPERABLE AND
ABANDONED VEHICLES, of Title 6, POLICE REGULATIONS of the City Code is hereby
amended as follows (deletions are shown in strikeout font and additions are
shown in underlined, bold italics font):
 
The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle or any part thereof on any
highway , street, or alley in this city is unlawful and subject to penalties as
set forth in this chapter. The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle
or any part thereof on private or public property, other than a highway ,
street, or alley , in view of the general public, anywhere in this city is
unlawful except on property which is zoned and used for the repair and/or
storage of abandoned vehicles. Any vehicle that is inoperable,  unlicensed,
without proper registration or license plates, or with registration that has
expired, shall be deemed an abandoned vehicle. A motor vehicle or any part
thereof so abandoned on private property may be authorized for removal by or
upon the order of the chief of police, after a waiting period of seven (7) days
or more has expired, or may be removed immediately if determined to be a
hazardous dilapidated motor vehicle under 65 ILCS 5/11-40-3-1. (Ord. 1760, 8-
12-2019; Ord. 1827, 11-15-2021; Ord. [insert], 8-4-2025 )
 
Section 5:   All of the remaining provisions of Section 2, ABANDONMENT OF
VEHICLES, of Chapter 7, INOPERABLE AND ABANDONED VEHICLES, of Title 6, POLICE
REGULATIONS, of the Spring Valley City Code not otherwise amended by this
ordinance shall remain in full force and effect.
 
Section 6:   Section 1, PUBLIC PARKS DESIGNATED, of Chapter 6, PUBLIC PARKS, of
Title 8, PUBLIC WAYS, UTILITIES AND SUBDIVISIONS of the City Code is hereby
amended as follows (deletions are shown in strikeout font and additions are
shown in underlined, bold italics font):
 
There shall be authorized and established and hereafter maintained the
following public parks located within the cC ity: cC ity pP ark, Kirby Park,
Savitch Park , Baltikowski Park, Knol Park, Pederzani Park, Casford Park, Coal
Miners Park, Spring Valley Mini Park, City Hall Park, Foley Field, Barto
Landing, and Coveny Veteran’s Memorial Pool, as well as the bump outs on the
100 and 200 blocks of East and West St. Paul Street,  and any other lands which
the cC ity shall hereafter acquire or lease for park purposes. (1972 Code; Ord.
[insert], 7-2-2025 )
 
Section 7:   All of the remaining provisions of Section 1, PUBLIC PARKS
DESIGNATED, of Chapter 6, PUBLIC PARKS, of Title 8, PUBLIC WAYS, UTILITIES AND
SUBDIVISIONS, of the Spring Valley City Code not otherwise amended by this
ordinance shall remain in full force and effect.
 
Section 8:   Section 3, RESPONSIBLE BIDDER, of Chapter 19, PURCHASING, of Title
1, ADMINISTRATIVE of the City Code is hereby amended as follows (deletions are
shown in strikeout font and additions are shown in underlined, bold italics
font):
 
The City of Spring Valley will require all bidders submitting biids for public
works projects paid for in whole, or in part, with public funds from the City
of Spring Valley for public works projects of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00)  Fifty Thousand Dollars ($50,000.00) or more to comply with the
requirements of this sS ection by providing proof of compliance with the
requirements of this sS ection at the time a bidder submits a bid to the City
of Spring Valley in order to be considered a responsible bidder under section
8-10-3 the Illinois Municipal Code.
 
Section 9:   All of the remaining provisions of Section 3, RESPONSIBLE BIDDER,
of Chapter 19, PURCHASING, of Title 1, ADMINISTRATIVE, of the Spring Valley
