and effect.
 
Section 10:   Section 2, DESIGNATION OF NUMBERS, of Chapter 8, HOUSE NUMBERING,
of Title 8, PUBLIC WAYS, UTILITIES AND SUBDIVISIONS, of the City Code is hereby
amended by the addition of the following subsections:
 
   (O) Separate numbers shall be assigned to lots in Bernal’s Subdivision, same
to be identical to the lot numbers of said lots.
 
   (P) Separate numbers shall be assigned to lots in Sunset Farms Subdivision,
same to be identical to the lot numbers of said lots
 
   (Q) Separate numbers shall be assigned to lots in Wolfer’s Grove
Subdivision, same to be identical to the lot numbers of said lots
 
   (R) Separate numbers shall be assigned to lots in Willow Trail Subdivision,
same to be identical to the lot numbers of said lots
 
   (S) Separate numbers shall be assigned to lots in Oak Grove Subdivision,
same to be identical to the lot numbers of said lots
 
Section 11:   All of the remaining provisions of Section 2, DESIGNATION OF
NUMBERS, of Chapter 8, HOUSE NUMBERING, of Title 8, PUBLIC WAYS, UTILITIES AND
SUBDIVISIONS, of the Spring Valley City Code not otherwise amended by this
ordinance shall remain in full force and effect.
 
Section 12:   Subsection (E)1, VIOLATOR SUBJECT TO PENALTY, of Section 13,
NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS, of Chapter 9, PROPERTY MAINTENANCE AND OCCUPANCY CODE, of
Title 3, BUILDING REGULATIONS of the City Code is hereby amended as follows
(deletions are shown in strikeout font and additions are shown in underlined,
bold italics font):
 
1.   Violator Subject To Penalty: The responsible owner, operator or occupant
shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00)  one
hundred dollars ($100)  nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
day such violation exists after expiration of the time specified for correction
in the notice given pursuant to this section; and unless the city has granted
an extension as requested in writing by the responsible owner, operator or
occupant.
 
Section 13:   All of the remaining provisions of Section 13, NOTICE OF
VIOLATIONS, of Chapter 9, PROPERTY MAINTENANCE AND OCCUPANCY CODE, of Title 3,
BUILDING REGULATIONS, of the Spring Valley City Code not otherwise amended by

RESOLUTION NO. 919
 
A RESOLUTION HIRING AN ACTIVITIES &PROGRAM COORDINATOR AND EVENT & MARKETING
MANAGER FOR THE COMMUNITY CENTER
 
Background Recitals
 
A.   The City Council of the City of Spring Valley finds it necessary and in
the public interest to employ an Activities & Program Coordinator and Event &
Marketing Manager for the community center.
 
B.   The City Council recently established the aforementioned positions by
passage of ordinance that amended Chapter 34, COMMUNITY CENTER, of Title 1,
ADMINISTRATIVE, of the Spring Valley City Code (1-34-1), (1-34-2).
 
C.   With the community center nearing completion, the City Council believes it
is appropriate to fill the newly established position to begin preparations for
operation of the community center.
 
D.   Mary Janusick has applied for the position of Activities & Program
Coordinator and Betsy Sobin has applied for the position of Event & Marketing
Manager.
 
E.   The renumeration for these positions shall be reviewed from time to time
and modified by the Mayor as necessary but shall initially be set at $500 per
for each position, paid bi-weekly.
 
NOW THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED by the City Council of the City of Spring Valley,
Bureau County, Illinois, that the employment of Mary Janusick as Activities &
Program Coordinator and Betsy Sobin as Event & Marketing Manager is hereby
authorized and approved on the terms noted above and contained within the City
Code and the Mayor and City Clerk are hereby authorized and directed to execute
all necessary documents related to their employment.
 
Passed by the Spring Valley City Council, Bureau County, Illinois at a regular
meeting held on
June 2, 2025.

ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 188
AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR THE ADOPTION OF THE OFFICIAL CODE OF THE CITY OF
SPRING VALLEY; PROVIDING FOR THE CONTINUANCE IN EFFECT OF ALL GENERAL LAWS IN
EFFECT ON THE DATE OF SUCH ADOPTION; PROVIDING FOR THE CONTINUATION OF ALL
SPECIAL ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED IN THE OFFICIAL CODE AND PROVIDING FOR THE
REGULAR SUPPLEMENTATION OF THE OFFICIAL CITY CODE.
BE IT ORDAINED by the mayor and city council of the city of Spring Valley,
Illinois:
   Section 1. Pursuant to the provisions of section
1-2-3 of the Illinois municipal code and from and after the date of passage of
this ordinance, this city code of the city of Spring Valley, Illinois, prepared
by Sterling Codifiers, Inc., under the direction of the governing body of the
city of Spring Valley, is hereby approved and accepted and declared to be the
official city code containing all ordinances of a general nature in effect at
the time of such codification. Said code shall be accepted in all courts
without question as the official code and law of the city as enacted by the
mayor and city council of the city of Spring Valley.
   Section 2. There is hereby adopted, as a method of perpetual codification,
the loose leaf type of binding, together with continuous supplement service
provided by Sterling Codifiers, Inc., whereby each newly adopted ordinance of a
general and permanent nature amending, altering, adding to or deleting
provisions of the official code is identified by the proper catchline and is
inserted in the proper place in each of the official copies. Each such new
provision shall become effective upon the passage of the ordinance. Insertion
of the proper replacement pages shall be made in the copies of the code, three
(3) copies of which shall be maintained in the office of the clerk, certified
as to correctness and available for inspection at any and all times that said
office is regularly open.
   Section 3. All ordinances of a general nature included in this official city
code shall be considered as a continuation of said ordinance provisions and the
fact that some provisions have been deliberately eliminated by the governing
body shall not serve to cause any interruption in the continuous effectiveness
of ordinances included in said official city code. All ordinances of a special
nature, as set forth in the savings clause (title 1, chapter 2) of said code
shall continue in full force and effect unless specifically repealed and
amended by provisions of the city code. Such ordinances are not intended to be
included in the official city code.
   Section 4. This ordinance shall be in full force and effect immediately upon
its passage, approval and publication in book or pamphlet form as provided by
section 1-2-4 of the Illinois municipal code.
PASSED AND APPROVED THIS 20th day of December 1972.
            CITY OF SPRING VALLEY
            s/ Joseph Ruva  Mayor
ATTEST:
s/ Beverly West   
City Clerk
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATIVE
CHAPTER 1
CITY CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Construction Of Words
1-1-5: Interpretations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the governing body this code is hereby declared to be and
shall hereafter constitute the official code of the city of Spring Valley. Any
reference made to the number of any section contained herein shall be
understood to refer to the position of the same under its appropriate chapter
and title heading, and to the general penalty clause relating thereto, as well
as to the section itself, when reference is made to this code by title in any
legal document. (1972 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in all administrative tribunals of this
state as the ordinances of the city of general and permanent effect 1 . (1972
Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-3, 5/1-2-6.
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this code shall set forth the title, chapter and section
number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall constitute a
sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the
amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to Sterling
Codifiers and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this code. Each such replacement page shall be
properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of this code
within thirty (30) days from the date of its final passage. (1972 Code)
1-1-4: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any section of this code importing the plural number is
used, in describing or referring to any matters, parties, or persons, any
single matter, party, or person shall be deemed to be included, although
distributive words may not have been used.
When any subject matter, party or person is referred to in this code by words
importing the singular number only, or the masculine gender, several matters,
parties, or persons and females as well as males and bodies corporate shall be
deemed to be included; provided, that these rules of construction shall not be
applied to any section of this code which contains any express provision
excluding such construction or where the subject matter or content may be
repugnant thereto. (1972 Code)
1-1-5: INTERPRETATIONS:
In the determination of the provisions of each section of this code the
following rules shall be observed:
   (A)   Intent To Defraud: Whenever an intent to defraud is required in order
to constitute an offense, it shall be sufficient if an intent appears to
defraud any person.
   (B)   Liability Of Employers And Agents: When the provisions of any section
of this code prohibits the commission of an act, not only the person actually
doing the prohibited act or omitting the directed act, but also the employer
and all other persons concerned with or in aiding or abetting the said person
shall be guilty of the offense described and liable to the penalty set forth.
(1972 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVINGS CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the city passed prior to the adoption of this code
are hereby repealed, except such as are referred to herein as being still in
force or are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to
the saving clauses contained in the following section), from which are excluded
the following ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy ordinances;
appropriation ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations;
franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to persons or
corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances; ordinances
establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public places;
improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to elections;
ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or from the
city; and all special ordinances. (1972 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and other
public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public
utilities shall be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this code or by virtue
of the preceding section, excepting as this code may contain provisions for
such matters, in which case this code shall be considered as amending such
ordinance or ordinances in respect of such provisions only. (1972 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance,
whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty,
forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising
under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense
or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so
incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes
effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform to the
ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable. If
any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any provision of a new
ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the party affected, applied
to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect.
This section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or
implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions
upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
Nothing contained in this or the preceding section shall be construed as
abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general ordinances of
the city herein repealed; or as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering
any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person,
firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the city under any ordinance or
provision thereof in force at the time of the adoption of this code. (1972
Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Definitions, General
1-3-1: DEFINITIONS, GENERAL:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this code they shall have the
meaning herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another.
CITY: The city of Spring Valley.
CODE: Unless otherwise specifically stated shall mean this code.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this code to a city employee by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the city of
Spring Valley".
FEE: A sum of money charged by the city for the carrying on of a business,
profession or occupation.
KNOWINGLY: Imports only a knowledge that the facts exist which brings the act
or omission within the provisions of this code. It does not require any
knowledge of the unlawfulness of such act or omission.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
MISDEMEANOR: Any offense deemed a violation of the provisions of this code
which is a lesser offense than a felony as defined by state law.
NEGLIGENT, NEGLECT, NEGLIGENCE AND NEGLIGENTLY: Imports a want of such
attention to the nature or probable consequences of the act or omission as a
prudent man ordinarily bestows in acting in his own concern.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and welfare of the
inhabitants of the city; or any act or thing repugnant to, or creating a hazard
to, or having a detrimental effect on the property of, another person or to the
community.
OCCUPANT: Applied to a building or land shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such building or land whether alone or with others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this code.
OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this code to a city officer by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the city of
Spring Valley".
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: Applied to a building or land shall include any part owner, joint owner,
tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of such
building or land.
PERSON: Shall include the singular and the plural and shall also mean and
include any person, firm, corporation, association, partnership or any other
form of association or organization.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Shall include every description of money, goods, chattels,
effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged,
transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or
interest therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in small quantities
direct to the consumer.
STREET: Shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public ways, public
squares, public places and sidewalks.
TENANT: Applied to a building or land shall include any person who occupies the
whole or any part of such building or land whether alone or with others.
WHOLESALER AND WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall
be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things
in quantity to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WILFULLY: When applied to the intent with which an act is done or omitted,
implies simply a purpose or willingness to commit the act or make the omission
referred to. It does not require any intent to violate law, or to injure
another, or to acquire an advantage. (1972 Code)
CHAPTER 4
PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: Penalty
1-4-1-1: Settlement
1-4-2: Default; Labor (Rep. by Ord. 1889, 5-6-2024)
1-4-3: License

1-4-5: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this Code shall be fined
in a sum not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for any one
offense, excepting any specific section of this Code wherein the maximum fine
is limited to a lesser amount. (Ord. 1400, 11-10-2008)
1-4-1-1: SETTLEMENT:
   (A)   For any defendant charged for either the first or second time with the
offense listed below, the City of Spring Valley offers an opportunity for the
defendant to avoid a court appearance and settle the City ordinance violation
complaint by paying the City of Spring Valley the sum of seventy five dollars
($75.00) within fourteen (14) days from the date of the offense as charged in
the City ordinance violation ticket.

   (B)   Any defendant wishing to accept the City of Spring Valley's offer to
settle the City ordinance violation complaint pursuant to Illinois Supreme
Court Rule 574 must make the seventy five dollar ($75.00) payment to the Spring
Valley City Clerk's Office either in cash, certified check, money order, or
cashier's check made payable to the City of Spring Valley.
   (C)   If a defendant does not exercise the opportunity to settle the dispute
pursuant to Illinois Supreme Court Rule 574 and the terms of this section, the
fine provisions set forth in this Code for the offenses enumerated herein shall
remain in full force and effect. (Ord. 1540, 8-5-2013; amd. Ord. 1649, 11-7-
2016; Ord. 1855, 8-15-2022; Ord. 1884, 11-6-2023)
1-4-2: DEFAULT; LABOR:
(Rep. by Ord. 1889, 5-6-2024)
1-4-3: LICENSE:
When a person is convicted of a violation of any section of this Code any
license previously issued to him by the City may be revoked by the court or by
the Governing Body. (1972 Code)
1-4-4: APPLICATION:
The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of
this Code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate section.
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this Code where any duty
is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any act which is of a continuing
nature is forbidden or declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day such
duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise
specifically provided in this Code.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by
different clauses or sections of this Code the prosecuting officer may elect
under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the
same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other
penalty being enforced.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a
breach of any section or provision of this Code and there shall be no fine or
penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this chapter
shall apply and a separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day
during or on which a breach or violation occurs or continues. (1972 Code)
1-4-5: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the Governing Body to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee
is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (1972
Code)
CHAPTER 5
WARDS
SECTION:
1-5-1: Boundaries
1-5-1: BOUNDARIES:
The city is hereby divided into four (4) wards with boundaries as follows:
First ward, which shall include that part of the city lying south of the
centerline of Dakota Street as extended easterly on U.S. Route 6 to the east
city limits and lying east of the centerline of Hennessey Street extended
southerly to the south city limits.
Second ward, which shall include that part of the city lying south of the
centerline of Dakota Street as extended westerly to the west city limits and
lying west of the centerline of Hennessey Street as extended southerly to the
south city limits.
Third ward, which shall include that part of the city lying north of the
centerline of Dakota Street as extended westerly to the west city limits and
west of the centerline of Hennessey Street as extended northerly to the north
city limits.
Fourth ward, which shall include that part of the city lying north of the
centerline of Dakota Street as extended easterly to the east city limits on
Route 6 and lying east of the centerline of Hennessey Street extended northerly
to the north city limits. (1972 Code)
CHAPTER 6
MAYOR
SECTION:
1-6-1: Election
1-6-2: Duties
1-6-3: Appointment Of Officers
1-6-4: Designation Of Officers' Duties
1-6-5: Mayor Pro Tem
1-6-6: Acting Mayor
1-6-7: Formal Occasions
1-6-8: Bond
1-6-1: ELECTION:
The mayor shall be elected for a four (4) year term, and shall serve until his
successor is elected and qualified as is provided by statute. (1972 Code)
1-6-2: DUTIES:
The mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the city, shall preside over
the meetings of the council, and shall perform such duties as may be required
of him by statute or ordinance. He shall have supervision over all of the
executive officers and employees of the city, and shall have the power and
authority to inspect all books and records pertaining to city affairs and kept
by any officer or employee of the city at any reasonable time. (1972 Code)
1-6-3: APPOINTMENT OF OFFICERS:
The mayor shall appoint, by and with the advice and consent of the city
council, all officers of the city whose election or appointment is not
otherwise provided for. Any vacancies occurring in an appointive office shall
be filled in the same manner. (1972 Code)
1-6-4: DESIGNATION OF OFFICERS' DUTIES:
Whenever there is a dispute as to the respective duties or powers of any
appointed officer of the city this dispute shall be settled by the mayor after
consultation with the city attorney; and the mayor shall have the power to
delegate to any appointed officer any duty which is to be performed when no
specific officer has been directed to perform that duty. (1972 Code)
1-6-5: MAYOR PRO TEM:
During a temporary absence or disability of the mayor, the city council shall
elect one of its number to act as mayor pro tem, who during such absence or
disability shall possess the powers of mayor, as is provided by statute. (1972
Code)
1-6-6: ACTING MAYOR:
In the event of a vacancy in the office of mayor, the council may appoint one
of its members as acting mayor to serve until the vacancy is filled at a
regular or special election as provided by law. (1972 Code)
1-6-7: FORMAL OCCASIONS:
The mayor shall act for and on behalf of the city on formal occasions and
receptions; but in his absence or inability to attend any such function, the
council may select any other city officer to so act. (1972 Code)
1-6-8: BOND:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the mayor shall execute a bond
in such amount and with such sureties as may be required by the council,
conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of his office, provided
the amount of such bond shall not be less than three thousand dollars
($3,000.00). (1972 Code)
CHAPTER 7
COUNCIL
SECTION:
1-7-1: Council Members
1-7-2: Qualifications
1-7-3: Regular Meetings
1-7-4: Special Meetings
1-7-5: Quorum
1-7-6: Members Required To Vote
1-7-7: Passage Of Ordinance Over Veto
1-7-8: Standing Committees
1-7-9: Duties Of Standing Committees
1-7-10: Attachment Of Documents To Reports
1-7-11: Deferment Of Committee Reports
1-7-12: Adoption Of "Robert's Rules Of Order Revised"
1-7-13: Ordinances, Resolutions, Petitions And Communications
1-7-14: Public Comment At Council And Committee Meetings
1-7-1: COUNCIL MEMBERS:
The council shall consist of the mayor and two (2) aldermen from each ward; it
shall be judge of the election and qualification of its own members, and in
case any vacancy shall occur in the office of alderman, by death, resignation,
removal or any other cause, such vacancy shall be filled as provided by
statute. (1972 Code)
1-7-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
No person shall be eligible to the office of alderman unless he shall be a
qualified elector and reside within the ward for which he was elected, nor
shall he be eligible if he is in arrears in the payment of tax or any other
liability due to the city; nor shall he be directly or indirectly interested in
any contract whatever to which the city is a party; nor shall he be eligible if
he shall have been convicted of malfeasance, bribery or corrupt practices or
crime; nor shall he be eligible to any office the salary of which is payable
out of the city treasury, if at the time of his appointment he shall be a
member of the council; nor shall any member of the council at the same time
hold any other office under the city government; nor shall he be, either
directly or indirectly, individually or as a member of a firm, engaged in any
business transaction with the city, through its mayor or any of its authorized
boards, agents or attorney, whereby any money is to be paid, directly or
indirectly, out of the city treasury to such member of firms; nor shall any
member of the council sign any bond in any case wherein the city is interested.
(1972 Code)
1-7-3: REGULAR MEETINGS:
The regular stated meetings of the council shall be held in the council rooms
in the city hall at the hour of seven o’clock (7:00) P.M. on the first and
third Mondays of each month commencing with the meeting on Monday, June 7,
2021, except when any such day shall happen to be a legal holiday, in which
case the meetings shall be held on the day next following at the same hour.
(Ord. 1336, 5-21-2007; amd. Ord. 1812, 5-17-2021)
1-7-4: SPECIAL MEETINGS:
Special meetings of the council may be called by the mayor or by any three (3)
aldermen, whenever in their discretion they deem it necessary, in which event
such meeting shall be called in the following manner: The mayor, or the three
(3) aldermen, as the case may be, shall file in the clerk's office a statement
in writing, setting forth the object and purpose of the special meeting and
directing the clerk to forthwith give notice of the same. Upon the filing of
such statement the clerk shall cause to be served personally upon each member
of the council or left at his usual place of business or abode, at least twenty
four (24) hours before the time of such meeting, a notice of the special
meeting, setting forth the object and purposes thereof, and the time of holding
the same, which notices shall be served by some member of the police force.
Said notice may be served by the clerk by mail if said notice is deposited in
the U.S. mail at least forty eight (48) hours before time of said meeting. No
business other than that mentioned in the call shall be transacted at a special
meeting. The clerk shall give such other and further notice of such meeting as
required by law. (1972 Code)
1-7-5: QUORUM:
A majority of the aldermen shall constitute a quorum to do business, but a
smaller number may adjourn from time to time, and may compel the attendance of
absentees. (1972 Code)
1-7-6: MEMBERS REQUIRED TO VOTE:
Every member of the council shall vote on all questions in which he is not
directly or personally interested, which may be brought before the council for
its action in such a manner as to require a vote to be taken thereon.
The ayes and nays shall be taken upon the passage of all ordinances, and on all
propositions to create any liability against the city, or for the expenditure
or appropriation of its money, and in all other cases at the request of any
member, which shall be entered on the journal of the proceedings; and the
concurrence of a majority of all the members elected in the council shall be
necessary to the passage of any such ordinance or proposition, except where
greater than a majority vote is required by statute. (1972 Code)
1-7-7: PASSAGE OF ORDINANCE OVER VETO:
In case the mayor shall veto any ordinance or any part of an ordinance and
return the same to the council, together with his objections thereto, the vote
by which the same was passed shall be reconsidered by the council; and, if
after such consideration, two-thirds (2/3) of all the members elected to the
council shall agree by ayes and nays to pass the same, it shall go into effect,
notwithstanding the disapproval of the mayor. The vote to pass the same over
the mayor's veto shall be taken by ayes and nays, and entered on the journal.
No vote of the council shall be reconsidered or rescinded at any special
meeting thereof, unless at such special meeting there shall be present as many
aldermen as were present when such vote was taken. (1972 Code)
1-7-8: STANDING COMMITTEES:
It shall be the duty of the mayor at the first regular meeting of the council
in the month of May each year, or as soon thereafter as practicable, to appoint
a chairman and co-chairman of the following five (5) standing committees of the
council:
Finance committee.
Legislative committee.
Public health and safety committee.
Public streets and property committee.
Public utilities committee.
All council members shall be members of each standing committee. (1972 Code;
amd. Ord. 1813, 5-17-2021)
1-7-9: DUTIES OF STANDING COMMITTEES:
It shall be the duty of the standing committees of the council to keep a close
watch over the affairs of their respective departments of the city government.
They shall have the general management, control and supervision of all works
and things ordered to be made or done by the council in their respective
departments, and they shall make reports to the council of whatever facts may
be deemed of importance.
Each committee whether standing or special shall properly inspect and report in
writing upon all matters referred to it by the council and do and perform such
other and further duties as the council may from time to time prescribe.
(Ord. 1888, 5-6-2024)
1-7-10: ATTACHMENT OF DOCUMENTS TO REPORTS:
The City Clerk, in reporting upon any subject referred to it, shall attach to
their report all papers or documents in its possessions relative to matters so
referred.
(amd. Ord. 1888, 5-6-2024)
1-7-11: DEFERMENT OF COMMITTEE REPORTS:
Any report of a committee of the council shall be deferred, for final action
thereon, to the next regular meeting of the council after the report is made,
upon the request of two (2) aldermen present. (1972 Code)
1-7-12: ADOPTION OF "ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER REVISED":
The rules of parliamentary practice comprised in the latest published edition
of "Robert's Rules Of Order Revised" shall govern the council in all cases to
which they are applicable and in which they are not inconsistent with the
special rules of the city council and are not inconsistent with statutes of the
state of Illinois. (1972 Code)
1-7-13: ORDINANCES, RESOLUTIONS, PETITIONS AND COMMUNICATIONS:
Copies of ordinances, resolutions, petitions and communications shall be sent
to each member of the council forty-eight (48) hours prior to any regular or
special meeting wherein such resolution or ordinance is to be brought up for
consideration unless the council moves by a two-thirds (2/3) vote to suspend
the rules at any regular or special meeting.
(Ord. 1888, 5-6-2024)
1-7-14: PUBLIC COMMENT AT COUNCIL AND COMMITTEE MEETINGS:
   (A)   On all Spring Valley city council agendas the public should be given
two (2) opportunities to address the council. The first opportunity to address
the council will be after the roll call of the members. This opportunity to
address the city council will be limited to matters on the agenda for
consideration by the city council at the meeting. Individuals commenting on
agenda items shall be limited to two (2) minutes in length, unless the mayor
grants the individual wishing to address the council additional time.
   (B)   Prior to the adjournment of the Spring Valley city council meeting,
the agenda shall also allow for public comments on any matters not covered by
the agenda for the meeting. Individuals making public comments at the end of
the meeting shall be limited to two (2) minutes in length, unless the mayor
grants the individual making the public comment additional time.
   (C)   The rules established for meetings of the Spring Valley city council
are also made applicable to all Spring Valley committee meetings. (Ord. 1586,
10-13-2014)
CHAPTER 8
CITY CLERK
SECTION:
1-8-1: Election; Term
1-8-2: Bond And Oath
1-8-3: Office Hours
1-8-4: Signatures
1-8-5: Money Collected
1-8-6: Accounts
1-8-7: Records
1-8-8: Seal
1-8-9: Documents
1-8-10: Indices
1-8-11: Ex Officio Collector
1-8-12: Additional Duties
1-8-13: Vacancies
1-8-14: Deputy Clerk
1-8-1: ELECTION; TERM:
The city clerk shall be elected and serve for a four (4) year term and until
his successor is elected and qualified, as provided by statute. (1972 Code)
1-8-2: BOND AND OATH:
Before entering upon his duties of office, the city clerk shall execute a bond
in such amount as is provided by statute, conditioned upon the faithful
performance of his duties, and shall take oath as prescribed for other city
officers. (1972 Code)
1-8-3: OFFICE HOURS:
The clerk shall keep the office of the city clerk located in the city hall open
from nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. until five o'clock (5:00) P.M. Monday through
Friday. (Ord. 542, 6-7-1982; amd. Ord. 1779, 5-19-2020)
1-8-4: SIGNATURES:
The city clerk shall seal and attest all contracts of the city and all
licenses, permits and such other documents as shall require this formality.
(1972 Code)
1-8-5: MONEY COLLECTED:
The clerk shall turn over all money received by him on behalf of the city to
the city treasurer promptly upon receipt of the same; and with such money he
shall give a statement as to the source thereof. (1972 Code)
1-8-6: ACCOUNTS:
The clerk shall keep accounts showing all money received by him and the source
and disposition thereof, and such other accounts as may be required by statute
or ordinance. (1972 Code)
1-8-7: RECORDS:
In addition to the record of ordinances and other records which the clerk is
required by statute to keep, he shall keep a register of all licenses and
permits issued and the payments thereon; a record showing all of the officers
and regular employees of the city; and such other records as may be required by
the city council. (1972 Code)
1-8-8: SEAL:
The clerk shall be the custodian of the city seal, and shall affix its
impression on documents whenever this is required. (1972 Code)
1-8-9: DOCUMENTS:
The clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the city which
are not assigned to the custody of some other officer. (1972 Code)
1-8-10: INDICES:
The clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records
kept by him, so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had. (1972
Code)
1-8-11: EX OFFICIO COLLECTOR:
The clerk shall act as and perform all the duties of collector unless and until
a separate collector is appointed. (1972 Code)
1-8-12: ADDITIONAL DUTIES:
In addition to the duties herein provided, the clerk shall perform such other
duties and functions as may be required by statute or ordinance. (1972 Code)
1-8-13: VACANCIES:
In case the office of city clerk shall become vacant for any reason, the mayor
and council shall appoint a successor as provided by statute. (1972 Code)
1-8-14: DEPUTY CLERK:
There is hereby created the office of deputy clerk. The city clerk is
authorized to appoint a deputy clerk who shall have the power and duty to
execute all documents required by any law or ordinance to be executed by the
clerk, and affix the seal of the city thereto whenever required.
When signing any documents the deputy clerk shall sign the name of the city
clerk followed by the word "by" and the deputy clerk's own name and the words
"deputy clerk".
The powers and duties herein described shall be exercised by such deputy clerk
only in the absence of the city clerk from his office in the city hall, and
only when either written direction has been given by the city clerk to exercise
such power, or the city council has determined by resolution that the city
clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform such function.
Such deputy clerk shall have the authority and power herein described, and such
further power and authority as may be provided by statute. (1972 Code)
CHAPTER 9
CITY TREASURER
SECTION:
1-9-1: Election
1-9-2: Oath And Bond
1-9-3: Duties
1-9-4: Deposit Of Funds
1-9-5: Records
1-9-6: Accounts
1-9-7: Reports
1-9-8: Register Of Warrants
1-9-1: ELECTION:
The city treasurer shall be elected as provided by statute and shall serve
until his successor is elected and qualified. (1972 Code)
1-9-2: OATH AND BOND:
The treasurer, before entering upon the duties of his office, shall take the
oath prescribed for city officers and shall give bond in such sum as may be
required by the council, but the bond shall not be less than the amount of the
estimated revenues and special assessments of the city for the current year,
with sureties to be approved by the council. The bond shall be conditioned upon
the faithful performance by the treasurer of his duties of office, and to
indemnify the city for any loss due to any neglect of duty or wrongful act on
the part of the treasurer. (1972 Code)
1-9-3: DUTIES:
The treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by statute
or ordinance. He shall receive all money paid to the city, either directly from
the person paying it or from the hands of such other officer as may receive it,
and he shall pay out only on vouchers or orders properly signed by the city
clerk and the mayor. (1972 Code)
1-9-4: DEPOSIT OF FUNDS:
He shall deposit the city funds in such depositories as may be selected from
time to time as is provided by statute, and he shall keep the city money
separate and distinct from his own money with it or make private or personal
use of city funds. (1972 Code)
1-9-5: RECORDS:
The treasurer shall keep such records showing all money received by him, the
source from which it was received, and the purpose for which it was paid out;
and he shall keep a record showing at all times the financial status of the
city. (1972 Code)
1-9-6: ACCOUNTS:
The treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by the
council, and shall keep them in the manner required by law. (1972 Code)
1-9-7: REPORTS:
The treasurer shall make monthly reports to the council showing the state of
the finances of the city, and the amounts received and spent during the month,
which reports shall be filed. He shall make an annual report at the close of
the fiscal year with the total amount of all receipts and expenditures of the
city and his transactions during the preceding year. (1972 Code)
1-9-8: REGISTER OF WARRANTS:
The treasurer shall keep a register of all warrants, bonds or orders filed with
him or paid by him, and all vouchers, as is required by statute. (1972 Code)
CHAPTER 10
CITY ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-10-1: Appointment
1-10-2: Oath And Bond
1-10-3: Duties
1-10-4: Other Legal Matters
1-10-5: Assistant City Attorney
1-10-1: APPOINTMENT:
The city attorney shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent
of the city council. (1972 Code)
1-10-2: OATH AND BOND:
The city attorney shall take the oath prescribed by law and execute a bond to
the city in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) with sureties,
conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his office. (1972
Code)
1-10-3: DUTIES:
The city attorney shall attend all regular meetings of the city council,
represent the city in hearings in circuit court relating to ordinance
violations, and draft the annual appropriation ordinance and tax levy
ordinance. (1972 Code)
1-10-4: OTHER LEGAL MATTERS:
The attorney shall be the legal advisor for the city and represent the city in
all other legal matters. The city council may, at the request of the city
attorney, retain or authorize additional counsel to assist the city attorney in
legal matters. (1972 Code)
1-10-5: ASSISTANT CITY ATTORNEY:
The mayor may upon the request and recommendation of the city attorney, and
with the advice and consent of the city council, appoint one or more assistants
who shall, upon taking the oath prescribed by law, be authorized to perform the
duties of the city attorney without additional compensation therefor. (Ord., 9-
21-1981)
CHAPTER 11
INDEMNIFICATION
SECTION:
1-11-1: Findings
1-11-2: City Action
1-11-3: Actions Not Covered
1-11-1: FINDINGS:
The City Council finds that it is the public policy of the State of Illinois
that members of governmental bodies shall not be liable in damages for the
exercise of discretion in determining policies. This public policy is set forth
in 745 Illinois Compiled Statutes 10/2-201 which provides as follows:
Except as otherwise provided by Statute, a public employee serving in a
position involving the determination of policy or the exercise of discretion is
not liable for any injury resulting from his act or omission in determining
policy when acting in the exercise of such discretion even though abused.
(Ord. 1658, 12-19-2016)
1-11-2: CITY ACTION:
In light of section
1-11-1 of this chapter, if any claim or action not covered by insurance is
instituted against any elected or appointed City official, employee or
authorized volunteer in connection with any act or omission in determining
policy, the City shall, to the fullest extent allowed by the law:
   (A)   Appear and defend against the claim or actions;
   (B)   Indemnify the elected or appointed City official, employee or
authorized volunteer for his or her court costs and attorney's fees incurred in
the defense of such claim or action;
   (C)   Pay or indemnify the elected or appointed City official, employee or
authorized volunteer for a judgment based on such claim or action; and
   (D)   Pay or indemnify the elected or appointed City official, employee or
authorized volunteer for a compromise or settlement of such claim or action,
provided that the settlement is approved by a majority of the members of the
City Council. The term "elected or appointed City official" shall mean any
former or current Mayor, Alderman or member of any City board, committee and
commission. (Ord. 1658, 12-19-2016)
1-11-3: ACTIONS NOT COVERED:
The foregoing indemnity shall not extend to any of the following:
   (A)   Any liability, attorney's fees or costs with respect to any matter in
which the elected or appointed City official, employee or authorized volunteer
is finally adjudged to be guilty of a criminal act; to the extent that any
criminal proceeding shall be pending at the time of indemnification or any
criminal proceeding shall thereafter be instituted, any indemnification paid or
promised shall be conditioned upon the termination of the criminal proceeding
without a finding of guilt;
   (B)   Any liability or judgment against an elected or appointed City
official, employee or authorized volunteer which is payable to the City itself
or where the City was injured and the elected or appointed City official,
employee or authorized volunteer either obtained personal benefit or financial
gain as a result of his or her wrongful conduct;
   (C)   Any liability, attorney's fees or costs incurred as a result of a City
initiated or approved investigation into the misconduct of the elected or
appointed City official, employee or authorized volunteer;
   (D)   Any liability, attorney's fees or costs incurred as a result of the
elected or appointed City official's, employee's or authorized volunteer's
failure to reasonably cooperate or participate in the defense of any claim,
action, suit or proceeding with any person, party or entity; or
   (E)   Any liability excluded by a written waiver from the elected or
appointed City official, employee or authorized volunteer. (Ord. 1658, 12-19-
2016)
CHAPTER 12
SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS
SECTION:
1-12-1: Creation Of Office
1-12-2: Streets
1-12-3: Waterworks
1-12-4: Sewers
1-12-5: Employees
1-12-6: Property
1-12-7: Union Membership
1-12-8: Assistant
1-12-1: CREATION OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created the office of superintendent of public works, an
executive office of the city. The said superintendent shall be appointed by the
mayor and with the advice and consent of the city council. (1972 Code)
1-12-2: STREETS:
The superintendent of public works shall have charge of the construction and
care of all public streets, alleys and driveways in the city, and with the
keeping of the same clean. He shall see to it that all gutters and drains
therein function properly and that the same are kept free from defects. (1972
Code)
1-12-3: WATERWORKS:
The superintendent of public works shall have charge of the operation and
maintenance of the municipal water distribution system. (1972 Code)
1-12-4: SEWERS:
In the absence of provisions to the contrary, the superintendent of public
works shall have charge of the construction and maintenance of all public
sanitary and stormwater sewers in the city. (1972 Code)
1-12-5: EMPLOYEES:
All officers or employees assigned to the department of public works shall
perform their duties subject to the orders and under the supervision of
superintendent of public works. (1972 Code)
1-12-6: PROPERTY:
The superintendent of public works shall be the custodian of all property of
the city which is not assigned to the care or custody of any other officer.
(1972 Code)
1-12-7: UNION MEMBERSHIP:
If the individual appointed to the office of superintendent of public works is,
immediately prior to his appointment, an employee of the city, covered under a
collective bargaining agreement with the city and if the individual does not
wish to relinquish his union membership, the office of superintendent of public
works may be filled by said individual and the salary established for the
superintendent of public works shall be recomputed to an hourly wage which
shall, as near as possible, reflect the salary established for the
superintendent of public works, taking into account the fact that said
superintendent will receive overtime wages under the terms of the city's
collective bargaining agreement. Nothing contained in this section shall be
construed as in any way limiting the right of the mayor to remove the
superintendent of public works without cause and to reappoint a new
superintendent of public works with the advice and consent of the city council.
If the superintendent of public works resigns his position or is removed from
office by the mayor, his union seniority shall have continued to accrue
unabated during the time he has served as superintendent of public works. In
the event that a superintendent of public works, who elects to maintain his
union membership, is removed or resigns from office, the individual may remain
a city employee, if said individual has sufficient seniority to entitle him to
such a position on the city work force. (Ord., 5-6-1985)
1-12-8: ASSISTANT:
The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, may employ an
assistant to the superintendent of public works. Said assistant shall have the
same union rights as are provided for the superintendent, if the individual
shall choose to maintain his union membership. (Ord., 5-6-1985)
CHAPTER 13
REGISTRAR OF VITAL STATISTICS
SECTION:
1-13-1: Registrar Of Vital Statistics
1-13-2: Report Of Stillbirths And Deaths
1-13-3: Record Of Stillbirths And Deaths
1-13-1: REGISTRAR OF VITAL STATISTICS:
The city clerk shall be registrar of vital statistics for the city. (1972 Code)
1-13-2: REPORT OF STILLBIRTHS AND DEATHS:
A report of all stillbirths and deaths shall be made to the local registrar of
vital statistics, which report shall contain all information required by state
law. (1972 Code)
1-13-3: RECORD OF STILLBIRTHS AND DEATHS:
The local registrar shall keep a record showing all stillbirths and deaths
occurring within the city, which record shall include all information required
to be kept by state law. (1972 Code)
CHAPTER 14
REVENUE AND FINANCE
SECTION:
1-14-1: Fiscal Year
1-14-2: Borrowing Money; Limitation
1-14-3: Annual Appropriations
1-14-4: Limitation Of Expenditures
1-14-5: No Contract Without Appropriation
1-14-6: Annual Tax Levy
1-14-7: Tax Rates
1-14-8: Manner Of Collecting Taxes
1-14-9: Special Tax Levy
1-14-10: Uniformity Of Taxation
1-14-11: Contracts And Purchases
1-14-12: Bidding Requirements
1-14-13: Petitions, Fee Established
1-14-14: Photocopying Of Public Records
1-14-15: Municipal Utility Tax
1-14-1: FISCAL YEAR:
The current fiscal year and municipal year of the city is hereby extended to
April 30, 1982. The fiscal year and municipal year of the city shall,
thereafter, commence on May 1 of each year. (Ord. 513, 7-6-1981)
1-14-2: BORROWING MONEY; LIMITATION:
The council may, whenever the interests of the city require it, borrow money on
the credit of the city for corporate purposes, and issue bonds therefor, in
such amounts and forms, and on such conditions as it shall prescribe, but shall
not become indebted in any manner or for any purpose to an amount, including
existing indebtedness, in the aggregate to exceed five percent (5%) on the
value of the taxable property therein, to be ascertained by the last assessment
for state and county taxes previous to the incurring of such indebtedness; and
before or at the time of incurring any indebtedness, shall provide for the
collection of a direct annual tax sufficient to pay the interest on such debt
as it falls due, and also to pay and discharge the principal thereof within
twenty (20) years after contracting the same; provided, however, that the five
percent (5%) debt limitation shall not be applicable at any time hereafter
should the constitution of the state and applicable statutes of the state
remove said limitation. (1972 Code)
1-14-3: ANNUAL APPROPRIATIONS:
The council shall, as soon as practicable, after the commencement of each
fiscal year, and within the first quarter of each fiscal year, pass an
ordinance to be termed the annual appropriation bill; it shall appropriate such
sums of money as may be deemed to be necessary to defray all necessary expenses
and liabilities of the city for the current year; and in such ordinance shall
specify the objects and purposes for which such appropriations are made, and
the amount appropriated for each object or purpose. No further appropriations
shall be made at any other time within such fiscal year, unless the proposition
to make each appropriation has been first sanctioned by a majority of the legal
voters of the city, either by a petition signed by them, or at a general or
special election called therefor, or otherwise authorized by statute. (1972
Code)
1-14-4: LIMITATION OF EXPENDITURES:
Neither the council, nor any department or officer of the city, shall add to
the corporate expenditures in any one year anything over and above the amount
provided for in the annual appropriation bill of that year except as herein
otherwise specially provided; and no expenditure for an improvement to be paid
for out of the general fund of the city shall exceed, in any one year, the
amount provided for such improvement in the annual appropriation bill;
provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall prevent the council from
ordering, by a two- thirds (2/3) vote, any improvement, the necessity of which
is caused by any casualty or accident happening after such annual appropriation
is made. The council may, by a like vote, order the mayor and the finance
committee to borrow a sufficient amount to provide for the expense necessary to
be incurred in making any improvements, the necessity for which has arisen, as
is herein mentioned, for a space of time not exceeding the close of the next
fiscal year; which sum, and the interest, shall be added to the amount
authorized to be raised in the next general tax levy, and embraced therein.
Should any judgment be obtained against the city, the mayor and finance
committee, under the sanction of the council, may borrow a sufficient amount to
pay the same, for a space of time not exceeding the close of the next fiscal
year, which sum and interest shall, in like manner, be added to the amount
authorized to be raised in the general tax levy of the next year and embraced
therein. (1972 Code)
1-14-5: NO CONTRACT WITHOUT APPROPRIATION:
No contract shall be hereafter made by the council, or any committee or member
thereof, and no expense shall be incurred by any of the officers or departments
of the city, whether the object of the expenditure shall have been ordered by
the council or not, unless an appropriation shall have been previously made
concerning such expense, except as herein otherwise expressly provided. (1972
Code)
1-14-6: ANNUAL TAX LEVY:
The council shall annually, on or before the first Tuesday in September in each
year, ascertain the total amount of appropriations for all corporate purposes
legally made, and to be collected from the tax levy of that fiscal year; and by
an ordinance specifying in detail the purposes for which such appropriations
are made and the sum or amount appropriated for each purpose, respectively,
levy the amount so ascertained upon all the property subject to taxation within
the city, as the same is assessed and equalized for state and county purposes
for the current year. A certified copy of such ordinance shall be filed with
the county clerk, whose duty it shall be to ascertain the rate percent, which,
upon the total valuation of all the property subject to taxation within the
city, as the same is assessed and equalized for state and county purposes, will
produce a net amount not less than the amount so directed to be levied; and it
shall be the duty of the county clerk to extend such tax in a separate column
upon the books of the collector of the state and county taxes, within the city;
provided, the aggregate amount of taxes levied for any one year, exclusive of
the amount levied for the payment of bonded indebtedness or the interest
thereon, shall not exceed the rate of two percent (2%) upon the aggregate
valuation of all the property within the city subject to taxation, as the same
was equalized for state and county taxes of the preceding year. (1972 Code)
1-14-7: TAX RATES:
The city will file tax levy ordinances each year for those levies to which it
chooses to levy and to which is entitled by law in an amount not to exceed the
maximum rate allowable by law.
(Ord. 1888, 5-6-2024)
1-14-8: MANNER OF COLLECTING TAXES:
The tax so assessed shall be collected and enforced in the same manner and by
the same officers as state and county taxes, and shall be paid over by the
officers collecting the same to the treasurer. (1972 Code)
1-14-9: SPECIAL TAX LEVY:
Whenever the city is required to levy a tax for the payment of any particular
debt, appropriation or liability, the tax for such purpose shall be included in
the total amount assessed by the council, and certified to the county clerk as
aforesaid; but the council shall determine, in the ordinance making such
assessment, what proportion of such total amount shall be applicable to the
payment of the particular debt, appropriation or liability; and the treasurer
shall set apart such proportion of the tax collected and paid to him for the
payment of such particular debt, appropriation or liability, and shall not
disburse the same for any other purpose until such debt, appropriation or
liability shall have been discharged. (1972 Code)
1-14-10: UNIFORMITY OF TAXATION:
All taxes levied or assessed by the city, except special assessment for local
improvements, shall be uniform upon all taxable property and persons within the
limits of the city, and no property shall be exempt therefrom, other than such
property as may be exempt from taxation under the constitution and the general
laws of the state. (1972 Code)
1-14-11: CONTRACTS AND PURCHASES:
No contract or purchase of any item or supply involving the expenditure of five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more, shall be made by, for, or in the name of
the City of Spring Valley, except upon the prior approval of the Spring Valley
City Council in a regular or special meeting considering said contract or
purchase; provided, however, that the provisions hereof shall not be held or
construed to limit in any way any requirement of law as to the making of
contracts in excess of certain amounts based upon specifications and public
advertisement for bids pursuant to section
8-9-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code 1 ; further provided that the Spring
Valley City Council will expect supervisory employees of any department seeking
authorization for purchases of more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) to
report to the Spring Valley City Council the method used by the supervisory
employee to obtain bids or quotes from vendors for any item or supply unless an
emergency situation occurs or where in the opinion of the Spring Valley City
Council obtaining bids or quotes for the items of supply would be
impracticable, and in the case of emergency or impractibility, the purchase may
be approved by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the Spring Valley City Council. (Ord.
1718, 3-26-2018)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/8-9-1.
1-14-12: BIDDING REQUIREMENTS:
The City’s bidding requirements shall be controlled by 65 ILCS 5/8-9-1 as now
in effect or hereinafter amended.
(Ord. 1888, 5-6-2024)
1-14-13: PETITIONS, FEE ESTABLISHED:
   (A)   A fee of four hundred dollars ($400.00) is hereby established for any
petitions or requests which are referred to the Spring Valley Planning
Commission or the Spring Valley Board of Zoning Appeals by the Spring Valley
City Council and which require a hearing of the Spring Valley Planning
Commission or the Spring Valley Board of Zoning Appeals. The fee set forth
herein shall be paid by the petitioner when the petitioner submits their
petition to the Spring Valley City Clerk.
   (B)   The provisions of this section shall govern petitions for changes in
zoning, petitions for variances from the requirements of the Land Development
Code, petitions for approval of new subdivision plats or variances from the
subdivision regulations of the City, and any other matters requiring a hearing
before the Spring Valley Planning Commission or the Spring Valley Board of
Zoning Appeals. (Ord. 704, 9-19-1989; amd. Ord. 1197, - -2006; Ord. 1379, 6-9-
2008)
1-14-14: PHOTOCOPYING OF PUBLIC RECORDS:
There is hereby established the following fees for providing records pursuant
to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act 1 :
   (A)   A copying fee of fifteen cents ($0.15) per page for each copy prepared
in conjunction with a Freedom of Information Act request; and
   (B)   A fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per hour for clerical time involved
in compiling the records requested pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act
request.
Clerical time shall include the clerical time of any Spring Valley City
employee or any employee of any firm doing business with the City of Spring
Valley, if said firm has in its possession records which must be disclosed
pursuant to a Freedom of Information Act request. (Ord. 968, 4-3-2000)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 140/6.
1-14-15: MUNICIPAL UTILITY TAX:
   (A)   Definitions: For the purpose of this section:
    GROSS RECEIPTS: The consideration received for distributing, supplying,
furnishing or selling gas, or electricity for use or consumption and not for
resale, and for all services rendered in connection therewith valued in money,
whether received in money or otherwise, including cash, credit, services and
property of every kind and material and for all services rendered therewith,
and shall be determined without any deduction on account of the cost of the
service, product or commodity supplied, the cost of materials used, labor or
service cost, or any expenses whatsoever.
   PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership,
association, joint stock company, joint adventure, corporation, municipal
corporation or political subdivision of this State, or a receiver, trustee,
conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court.
   PERSON DELIVERING GAS AND/OR ELECTRICITY: Illinois Power Company or any
successor utility company.
   TAXPAYER: Illinois Power Company or any successor utility company. (Ord.
1116, 10-20-2003; amd. Ord. 1625, 12-21-2015)
   (B)   Tax Imposed: A tax is imposed on all persons engaged in the following
occupations or privileges:
      1.   Persons engaged in distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling
gas for use or consumption within the city of Spring Valley and not for resale,
excluding all sales of gas billed to the city of Spring Valley, all sales of
gas billed to Hall Township high school district 502, all sales of gas billed
to Spring Valley community consolidated school district 99, and all sales of
gas billed to St. Bede Abbey and St. Bede Academy, at the rate of five percent
(5%) of the gross receipts therefrom.
      2.   The privilege of using or consuming electricity acquired in a
purchase at retail and used or consumed within the corporate limits of the
municipality, excluding all sales of electricity billed to the city of Spring
Valley, all sales of electricity billed to Hall Township high school district
502, all sales of electricity billed to Spring Valley community consolidated
school district 99 and all sales of electricity billed to St. Bede Abbey and
St. Bede Academy, at the following rates, calculated on a monthly basis for
each purchaser:
         (a)   For the first 2,000 kilowatt hours used or consumed in a month:
0.5541 cents per kilowatt hour;
         (b)   For the next 48,000 kilowatt hours used or consumed in a month:
0.3633 cents per kilowatt hour;
         (c)   For the next 50,000 kilowatt hours used or consumed in a month:
0.3270 cents per kilowatt hour;
         (d)   For the next 400,000 kilowatt hours used or consumed in a month:
0.3179 cents per kilowatt hour;
         (e)   For the next 500,000 kilowatt hours used or consumed in a month:
0.3088 cents per kilowatt hour;
         (f)   For the next 2,000,000 kilowatt hours used or consumed in a
month: 0.2907 cents per kilowatt hour;
         (g)   For the next 2,000,000 kilowatt hours used or consumed in a
month: 0.2861 cents per kilowatt hour;
         (h)   For the next 5,000,000 kilowatt hours used or consumed in a
month: 0.2816 cents per kilowatt hour;
         (i)   For the next 10,000,000 kilowatt hours used or consumed in a
month: 0.2770 cents per kilowatt hour; and
         (j)   For all electricity used or consumed in excess of 20,000,000
kilowatt hours in a month: 0.2725 cents per kilowatt hour.
The tax rates set forth in the preceding table will be used at least through
December 31, 2008, are proportional to the rates enumerated in 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-2 (as modified by Public Act 90-561), and do not
exceed the revenue that could have been collected during 1997 using the rates
enumerated in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-2 (as modified by Public Act
90-561).
Pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-2, the rates set forth in this
subsection (B) shall be effective upon approval by the Illinois commerce
commission. (Ord. 1625, 12-21-2015)
   (C)   Exceptions: None of the taxes authorized by this section may be
imposed with respect to any transaction in interstate commerce or otherwise to
the extent to which the business or privilege may not, under the constitution
and statutes of the United States, be made the subject of taxation by this
state or any political subdivision thereof; nor shall any persons engaged in
the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing, or selling or transmitting
gas, water, or electricity, or engaged in the business of transmitting
messages, or using or consuming gas or electricity acquired in a purchase at
retail, be subject to taxation under the provisions of this section for those
transactions that are or may become subject to taxation under the provisions of
the "municipal retailers' occupation tax act" authorized by 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-1; nor shall any tax authorized by this section be
imposed upon any person engaged in a business or on any privilege unless the
tax is imposed in like manner and at the same rate upon all persons engaged in
businesses of the same class in the municipality, whether privately or
municipally owned or operated, or exercising the same privilege within the
municipality.
   (D)   Additional Taxes: Such tax shall be in addition to other taxes levied
upon the taxpayer or its business.
   (E)   Collection: The tax authorized by this section shall be collected from
the purchaser by the person maintaining a place of business in this state who
delivers the electricity and/or gas to the purchaser. This tax shall constitute
a debt of the purchaser to the person who delivers the electricity and/or gas
to the purchaser and if unpaid, is recoverable in the same manner as the
original charge for delivering the electricity and/or gas. Any such tax
collected by a person delivering electricity and/or gas shall constitute a debt
owed to the municipality by such person delivering the electricity and/or gas.
Persons delivering electricity and/or gas shall collect the tax from the
purchaser by adding such tax to the gross charge for delivering the electricity
and/or gas. Persons delivering electricity and/or gas shall also be authorized
to add to such gross charge an amount equal to three percent (3%) of the tax to
reimburse the person delivering electricity and/or gas for the expense incurred
in keeping records, billing customers, preparing and filing returns, remitting
the tax and supplying data to the municipality upon request. If the person
delivering electricity and/or gas fails to collect the tax from the purchaser,
then the purchaser shall be required to pay the tax directly to the
municipality in the manner prescribed by the municipality. Persons delivering
electricity and/or gas who file returns pursuant to this subsection shall, at
the time of filing such return, pay the municipality the amount of the tax
collected pursuant to this section.
   (F)   Reports To Municipality: On or before the last day of each month, each
taxpayer shall make a return to the city for the preceding month stating:
      1.   His name.
      2.   His principal place of business.
      3.   His gross receipts and/or kilowatt hour usage during the month upon
the basis of which the tax is imposed.
      4.   Amount of tax.
      5.   Such other reasonable and related information as the corporate
authorities may require.
The taxpayer making the return herein provided for shall, at the time of making
such return, pay to the city of Spring Valley, the amount of tax herein
imposed; provided that in connection with any return, the taxpayer may, if he
so elects, report and pay an amount based upon his total billings of business
subject to the tax during the period for which the return is made (exclusive of
any amounts previously billed) with prompt adjustments of later payments based
upon any differences between such billings, and the taxable gross receipts.
   (G)   Credit For Overpayment: If it shall appear that an amount of tax has
been paid which was not due under the provisions of this section, whether as
the result of a mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be
credited against any tax due, or to become due, under this section from the
taxpayer who made the erroneous payment; provided that no amounts erroneously
paid more than three (3) years prior to the filing of a claim therefor shall be
so credited.
No action to recover any amount of tax due under the provisions of this section
shall be commenced more than three (3) years after the due date of such amount.
   (H)   Penalty: Any taxpayer who fails to make a return, or who makes a
fraudulent return, or who wilfully violates any other provisions of this
section shall be subject to a fine in an amount not less than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense, and in addition, shall be liable in a civil action for the amount of
tax due. Each and every day on which an offense is committed or continues,
shall be deemed a separate offense. Nothing in this section shall be construed
as limiting any additional or further remedies that the city may have for
enforcement of this section. (Ord. 1116, 10-20-2003)

1-15-1: OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES SALARIES:
The salaries of the appointed and elected officials and employees shall be
subject to constitutional prohibition of changing salaries of elected officials
during the incumbents' terms thereof as follows:
   (A)   The compensation of the Mayor shall be the sum of fifteen thousand
dollars ($15,000.00) annually, payable monthly, and the Mayor shall also be
paid the sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) annually, payable monthly, for
their duties as Liquor Commissioner, both salaries to take effect upon the
beginning of the Mayoral term after the general Municipal elections in April
2025. Additionally, the Mayor may elect in lieu of salary to be covered under
the health insurance policy of the City of Spring Valley as a full time
employee of the City of Spring Valley. If the Mayor elects health insurance
coverage, the Mayoral salary and the salary for Liquor Commissioner shall be
reduced to reflect the payments made by the City of Spring Valley to cover the
Mayor on the Spring Valley health insurance policy.
   (B)   The compensation of the City Clerk and the ex officio Collector shall
be payable in equal biweekly installments as follows:
 
Effective   Annual Salary
May 1, 2025 $70,000.00
May 1, 2026 $73,000.00
May 1, 2027 $76,000.00
May 1, 2028 $79,000.00
 
   (C)   If the City Clerk elects to decline health insurance coverage for
either the City Clerk individually, the City Clerk’s spouse or the City Clerk’s
family provided by the City of Spring Valley to all full time employees of the
City of Spring Valley, the City Clerk’s salary shall be increased by fifty
percent (50%) of the cost which the City of Spring Valley would otherwise pay
in health insurance premiums if the Clerk elected health insurance coverage for
the Clerk individually, the Clerk’s spouse or the Clerk’s family under the
terms of the health insurance policy of the City of Spring Valley.
   (D)   The compensation of each Alderman elected at the Municipal election of
April 2021, at any election or any appointment subsequent thereto, shall be
five hundred dollars ($500.00) per month. No additional compensation will be
provided for attendance as committee meetings. Each Alderman may be allowed
three (3) absences from a regularly scheduled City Council meeting and three
(3) absences from a committee meeting in any calendar year. If an Alderman has
more than three (3) absences from regularly scheduled City Council meetings,
the Alderman's salary shall be reduced by one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
each regular City Council meeting the Alderman fails to attend within a
calendar year. If an Alderman has more than three (3) absences from a scheduled
committee meeting, the Alderman's salary shall be reduced by fifty dollars
($50.00) for each committee meeting the Alderman fails to attend within a
calendar year.
   (E)   The compensation of Liquor Commissioner is included in the
compensation of the Mayor provided in subsection (A) of this section.
   (F)   The compensation of the City Attorney shall be seven thousand two
hundred dollars ($7,200.00) per annum, payable monthly, as a retainer for
attendance at regular City Council meetings. Compensation for additional
services shall be paid at a reasonable hourly rate to be set by the Mayor, with
the advice and consent of the City Council, in conjunction with the City
Attorney. The compensation paid to the City Attorney under the provisions of
this subsection shall not be considered a salary and the relationship between
the City and the City Attorney shall be a relationship of attorney-client and
principal-agent, not employer-employee. The City Attorney shall be responsible
for exercising independent legal judgment, advising the City Council of its
legal rights and responsibilities and performing any other legal services
directed by the Mayor or the City Council in an independent, professional
manner.

Effective retroactive to July 31, 2021, the compensation for Spring Valley
Volunteer Fireman shall be as set forth below:
Members of the Spring Valley Volunteer Fire Department shall receive
compensation for their services as members of the Spring Valley Volunteer Fire
Department based upon a point system allocation adopted by and agreed upon by
the members of the Spring Valley Volunteer Fire Department. On July 31 of each
year, the members of the Spring Valley Volunteer Fire Department shall
calculate each members' total points and the total cumulative points of all
members of the Spring Valley Volunteer Fire Department from the period of
August 1 of the preceding year through July 31 of the year of calculation. The
point totals accumulated by each volunteer fireman shall be divided into the
Compensation Pool as appropriated by the City of Spring Valley to reimburse
Spring Valley volunteer firemen for their time and service to the City. Each
point shall be assigned its weighted relative value. Each member of the Spring
Valley Volunteer Fire Department shall receive benefits from the Compensation
Pool in an amount equal to the number of points earned by each volunteer
fireman multiplied by the point value total for each point as determined by the
members of the Spring Valley Volunteer Fire Department. After calculating the
points earned by each member of the Spring Valley Volunteer Fire Department,
the Spring Valley Fire Chief shall submit to the Spring Valley City Clerk each
respective Spring Valley volunteer fireman's share of the Compensation Pool on
or before August 10 of each year and the City of Spring Valley shall pay each
volunteer fireman the amounts owed to the volunteer fireman pursuant to the
provisions of this subsection on or before August 31 of each year.
The Compensation Pool for the Spring Valley Volunteer Fire Department shall be
as follows:
 
$30,750.00 for the first year (2021)
$31,519.00 for the second year (2022)
$32,307.00 for the third year (2023)
$33,115.00 for the fourth year (2024)
