1-15-2: BENEFITS; POLICE DEPARTMENT:
Benefits for members of the Police Department shall be as follows:
   (A)   Health Insurance: Health insurance shall be furnished with the premium
to be paid by the City, providing coverage for a semiprivate hospital room per
day.
   (B)   Vacation: Vacations for police officers shall be as provided in
section
1-15-10 of this chapter.
   (C)   Sick Leave: Sick leave for full time police officers shall be as
provided in section
1-15-9 of this chapter.
   (D)   Court Appearances: (Rep. by Ord. 982, 7-5-2000, eff. retroactive to 7-
2-2000)
   (E)   Holiday Pay: Police officers required to be on duty during the
following holidays shall be entitled to compensation of double time, based at
the rate of each officer's hourly rate, over and above their regular pay:
 
New Year's Eve  Labor Day
New Year's Day  Veterans Day
President's Day Thanksgiving Day
Easter          Day after Thanksgiving
Memorial Day    Christmas Eve
Fourth of July  Christmas
 
In addition, employees shall receive one (1) floating holiday in lieu of their
birthday.
For the purpose of salaries, the traditional holidays will be celebrated, the
City Clerk shall designate and furnish the police department a record of the
traditional holidays each year.
Any police officer not scheduled to work on a listed holiday shall receive
eight (8) hours holiday pay at the officer's regular hourly rate of pay.
   (F)   Clothing Allowance: Effective retroactive to July 1, 2009, all full
time police officers of the City are entitled to replenish their uniforms and
related equipment and are entitled to reimbursement from the City in an amount
not to exceed three hundred seventy five dollars ($375.00) per calendar year,
per police officer; provided, however, that all officers seeking to replenish
their uniforms and related equipment must obtain prior approval for their
purchases from the Chief of Police. When the Chief of Police approves a
purchase by an officer to replenish his or her uniforms and related equipment,
the bill for the purchase of the uniforms and related equipment can be directed
to the City for payment or, if the officer makes an individual purchase, the
officer must submit a receipt to the Chief of Police before being eligible for
reimbursement by the City.
All part time police officers of the City are entitled to replenish their
uniforms and related equipment and are entitled to reimbursement from the City
in an amount not to exceed one hundred seventy five dollars ($175.00) per
calendar year, per police officer; provided, however, that all officers seeking
to replenish their uniforms and related equipment must obtain prior approval
for their purchases from the Chief of Police. When the Chief of Police approves
a purchase by an officer to replenish his or her uniforms and related
equipment, the bill for the purchase of the uniforms and related equipment can
be directed to the City for payment or, if the officer makes an individual
purchase, the officer must submit a receipt to the Chief of Police before being
eligible for reimbursement by the City. Any part time police officer who does
not remain in the employment of the City for at least one year must return to
the City, upon termination of his or her employment, an amount equal to any
uniform and related equipment allowance the officer received from the City.
All full time dispatchers of the City are entitled to replenish their uniforms
and are entitled to reimbursement from the City in an amount not to exceed two
hundred twenty five dollars ($225.00) per calendar year, per dispatcher;
provided, however, that all dispatchers seeking to replenish their uniforms
must obtain prior approval for their purchases from the Chief of Police. When
the Chief of Police approves a purchase by a dispatcher to replenish his or her
uniform, the bill for the purchase of the uniform can be directed to the City
for payment or, if the dispatcher makes an individual purchase, the dispatcher
must submit a receipt to the Chief of Police before being eligible for
reimbursement by the City.
   (G)   Police Dispatchers Rate of Pay: Effective retroactive to July 1, 2021,
police dispatchers shall be paid as follows:
 
           First Year     Second Year    Third Year     Fourth Year
Full-Time  $13.10/ $20.89 $13.43/ $21.41 $13.76/ $21.94 $14.11/ $22.50
Dispatcher
Part-Time  $13.00/ $18.56 $13.33/ $19.02 $13.67/ $19.50 $14.00/ $19.99
Dispatcher
 
The above rate of pay shall be determined by the Chief of Police with the
approval of the Mayor.
Vacations for Full-Time Dispatchers shall be as provided in Section
1-15-10 of this Chapter.
Sick leave for Full-Time Dispatchers shall be as provided in Section
1-15-9 of this Chapter.
Insurance shall be furnished to all full-time dispatchers with the full premium
to be paid by the City, subject to the terms and provisions as provided in this
Chapter.
If a dispatcher is called to work on their day off, or if a dispatcher is
called in to work other than his regular shift, or if a dispatcher works over
his regular shift, or if a dispatcher works over their eight (8) hour shift,
they shall receive time and one-half (1/2) based on his hourly rate of pay.
Dispatchers required to be on duty during the following holidays shall be
entitled to compensation of double time, based at the rate of each dispatcher's
hourly rate, over and above their regular pay:
 
New Year's Eve  Labor Day
New Year's Day  Veterans Day
President's Day Thanksgiving Day
Good Friday     Day after Thanksgiving
Memorial Day    Christmas Eve
Fourth of July  Christmas
 
In addition, employees shall receive one (1) floating holiday in lieu of their
birthday.
Any dispatcher not scheduled for work on a holiday shall receive eight (8)
hours holiday pay at the dispatcher's regular hourly rate of pay.
   (H)   Overtime: If an officer is called to work on his day off, or if an
officer is called out to work other than his regular shift, or if an officer
works over his eight (8) hour shift, he shall receive time and one-half (½)
based on the rate of work performed. All overtime submitted must be approved by
the Chief of Police.
   (I)   Vacation Selection: Vacation will be pursuant to departmental
regulations and in conformity with present departmental practices.
   (J)   New Employees: Employees with less than a year of seniority commence
earning their vacation upon completion of one month of seniority. However, such
employee may not use the vacation until he has satisfactorily completed his
first year of actual service.
   (K)   Pro Rata Vacation: Employees with at least one year of seniority
shall, upon retirement or separation from the department, be entitled to
vacation pay for leave earned but not used as of the date of separation.
   (L)   Bereavement Leaves Of Absence: Bereavement leaves of absence shall be
as provided in the bereavement section of the Spring Valley, Illinois Personnel
Manual in force at the time the employee requests a bereavement leave of
absence.
   (M)   Military Leave: Employees who are enrolled members of a reserve unit
of the Armed Forces of the United States, including the National Guard, shall
be granted a leave of absence not to exceed two (2) weeks for the purpose of
attending camps or schools.
   (N)   Life Insurance: The City shall furnish life insurance with a death
benefit of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
   (O)   Jury Service Leave: Employees who are called for jury service in any
court of the State shall be granted a leave of absence to serve as a juror. The
employee shall be entitled to the following: If fees paid for such jury
service, exclusive of transportation expenses and meals, are less than the
straight time salary paid by the City to the employee for a similar period of
time, the City shall reimburse the employee for the loss because of such
service.
   (P)   Police Officer Educational Increase: (Rep. by Ord. 1343, 6-18-2007)
   (Q)   Bulletproof Vests: (Rep. by Ord. 1113, 8-4-2003, eff. retroactive to
6-29-2003)
   (R)   Partial Leave Of Absence: Officers taking a partial leave of absence
approved by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall be compensated on
a pro rata basis as to wages and insurance. Police pension benefits payable by
the City shall be in accord with State law. Such officer on a partial leave of
absence shall not receive vacation pay nor accrue sick leave while on said
partial leave of absence.
   (S)   Any reference to first year in the ordinance codified herein shall be
deemed to be the period from July 1, 2021, through June 30, 2022. Any reference
to the second year in this ordinance shall be deemed to be the period from July
1, 2022, through June 30, 2023. Any reference to the third year in this
ordinance shall be deemed to be the period from July 1, 2023, through June 30,
2024. Any reference to the fourth year in this ordinance shall be deemed to be
the period from July 1, 2024, through June 30, 2025. (Ord., 2-21-1977, eff.
retroactive to 1-1-1977; Ord. 1468, 2-4-1980; Ord. 539, 4-5-1982; Ord. 579, 3-
19-1984; Ord., 3-17-1986; Ord. 982, 7-5-2000, eff. retroactive to 7-2-2000;
Ord. 1039, 8-6-2001, eff. retroactive to 7-1-2001; Ord. 1113, 8-4-2003, eff.
retroactive to 6-29-2003; Ord. 1343, 6-18-2007; Ord. 1425, 7-20-2009; Ord.
1690, 8-14-2017; Ord. 1829, 12-6-2021)

1-15-8: DOGCATCHERS:
(Rep. by Ord. 1690, 8-14-2017)
1-15-9: GENERAL SICK LEAVE BENEFITS:
The sick leave benefits for all full time employees of the City shall be:
   (A)   An employee may accrue seven and one-half (71/2) days of sick leave
for the first six (6) months' employment, and in turn accrue fifteen (15) days'
sick leave for one year of employment. Thereafter an employee shall accrue
fifteen (15) days' sick leave for each additional year of employment, with a
maximum of one hundred fifteen (115) days' sick leave and those employees that
are members of IMRF will be able to bank up to two hundred forty (240) days for
pension credit service. An IMRF employee having any accumulated sick leave
greater than one hundred fifteen (115) days for any year in the last ten (10)
years which were previously lost and not compensated for, will be allowed to
recover and bank these days for pension credit services. When an employee's
sick leave is used up, accrued sick leave must start over at the beginning of
the sick leave procedure.
   (B)   In the event an employee fails to report for work as required because
of illness or accident, the immediate supervisor of said employee shall be
authorized to make such inquiries as may be necessary to verify that the
employee is unable to perform the regular duties of employment. The employee
shall, if requested by a superior, procure and file with his said superior a
written statement from a qualified medical practitioner certifying that said
employee is unable to perform his regular duties because of illness or accident
after the first day of said illness or accident. (Ord. 1151, 10-18-2004)
1-15-10: VACATIONS, GENERAL:
   (A)   Vacations for full time employees of the City, not otherwise provided
for, shall be:
      1 to 5 years..........................................2 weeks
      6 to 10 years........................................3 weeks
      11 to 20 years......................................4 weeks
      21 to 25 years......................................1 additional vacation
day each year
      26 years and over................................5 weeks
   (B)    A "week's vacation" shall be defined as forty (40) work hours.
   (C)   All full time Spring Valley City employees are required to use all
vacation time allotted to the employee within three hundred sixty-five (365)
days of the date when the employee becomes entitled to receive vacation. By way
of example, an employee completing one year's service with the City of Spring
Valley is entitled to receive two (2) weeks of paid vacation. If an employee
completes one year of service with the City of spring Valley on May 1, the
employee must use their two (2) weeks' vacation prior to April 30 of the next
year. If an employee has vacation time left at the end three hundred sixty-five
(365) days after the date the employee becomes entitled to vacation time, the
employee will lose their unused vacation time. No employee will be paid for any
lost vacation time. No unused vacation may be carried over from year to year
and added to vacation time accruing in a subsequent year.
   (D)   In the event of a personal hardship or in the event that the
employee's work with the City of Spring Valley prevents the employee from using
all of his or her vacation time within the twelve (12) months from the date
when the employee first accrues vacation time, all employees shall have the
right to file a written request to carry over vacation time beyond the dates
provided for in this section. The request must be in writing and must state the
employee's reasons for the request. The request must be submitted to the
employee's supervisor and to the Mayor of the City of Spring Valley. If the
employee making the request is a supervisor, the written request should be
submitted to the Mayor of the City of Spring Valley. The Mayor of the City of
Spring Valley will have the sole discretion to grant or deny the employee's
vacation request and the Mayor of the City of Spring Valley will advise the
Spring Valley City Council as to whether the Mayor is granting or denying the
employee the right to carry over accrued vacation time.
   (E)   In order to allow those Spring Valley City employees who may have
accumulated more than one year's vacation time prior to the adoption of this
ordinance, any Spring Valley employee who has accumulated more than one year's
vacation time as of October 1, 2020 shall be allowed to use their accumulated
vacation time in excess of their regular vacation by no later than December 31,
2021. Any Spring Valley employee who has accumulated vacation time as of
December 31, 2021 in excess of their annual yearly vacation, will lose their
accumulated vacation time as of December 31, 2021. The provisions of this
paragraph shall apply only to employees who have accumulated vacation time in
excess of their annual yearly vacation time as of October 1, 2020.
   (F)   All full time employees who resign or are terminated will receive
payment for any unused vacation earned according to the Illinois Wage Payment
and Collection Act.
   (G)   In the event of any conflict between the City of Spring Valley
Personnel Manual and the amendments to Section
1-15-10 of the Spring Valley City Code as provided for in this ordinance and
the Labor Agreement entered into between the City of Spring Valley and Laborers
International Union Local # 393, the provisions of the Labor Agreement entered
into between the City of Spring Valley and Laborer's International Union Local
#393 shall control over any contrary provisions contained in this chapter.
(Ord. 1789, 9-21-2020)
1-15-11: ILLINOIS MUNICIPAL RETIREMENT FUND PARTICIPATION:
The City hereby elects to participate in the Illinois Municipal Retirement
Fund, effective January 1, 1990.
The standard for Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund participation shall be a
position normally requiring the performance of a duty for the City for six
hundred (600) hours per year for employees hired before April 19, 2021; for
employees hired after April 19, 2021, the standard for Illinois Municipal
Retirement Fund participation shall be a position normally requiring the
performance of a duty for the City for one thousand (1,000) hours per year.
The City Clerk shall and is hereby directed to promptly file a certified copy
of the resolution codified herein with the Board of Trustees of the Illinois
Municipal Retirement Fund. (Ord., 6-5-1989; amd. Ord. 1829, 11-15-2021)
1-15-12: LONGEVITY PAYMENTS:
   (A)   Nonelected employees of the City of Spring Valley shall receive, in
addition to the salaries set forth in this Chapter, and additional annual
payment of five hundred Dollars ($500.00) per year after completing five (5)
full years of service with the City and an additional annual payment totaling
one thousand Dollars ($1,000.00) per year after completing ten (10) years of
service with the City and an additional annual payment of one thousand two
hundred and fifty Dollars ($1,250.00) after fifteen (15) years of service with
the City and an additional one thousand five hundred Dollars ($1,500.00) after
twenty (20) years of service with the City. The payments called for in this
section shall only be made to nonelected employees who have worked a minimum of
one thousand six hundred sixty-four (1,664) hours in the twelve (12) months
preceding the payment of this longevity bonus. The longevity bonus shall be
paid to the employees in a separate paycheck for each year that an employee is
entitled to said bonus by November 30 of each year; however, longevity pay
accrued and earned but not yet paid will be paid at the time of layoff,
retirement, disability, and discharge other than for just cause.
   (B)   Nonelected employees of the City of Spring Valley shall receive, in
addition to the salaries set forth in this chapter, and the longevity payment
set forth in the immediately preceding subsection, a five thousand dollar
($5,000.00) lump sum post-retirement payment if all of the following conditions
are met:
      1.   The employee has worked for the City of Spring Valley for twenty
(20) or more years;
      2.   The employee notifies the City of Spring Valley of his or her
intention to retire at least one year prior to the date on which the employee
intends to retire;
      3.   The employee works full time for the City of Spring Valley working
at least two thousand eighty (2,080) hours in the year preceding the date of
their retirement; and
      4.   The employee is eligible to begin receiving retirement benefits
under a pension plan sponsored and adopted by the City of Spring Valley upon
retirement from the City of Spring Valley.
In the case of an unexpected illness or disability, the City of Spring Valley
may, upon recommendation by the Mayor and approval by the Spring Valley City
Council, waive the one year notification provision contained in this section
and provide the retirement bonus set forth herein to any employee experiencing
an unexpected illness or disability. The City of Spring Valley intends that the
benefit conferred upon employees of the City of Spring Valley by this section
shall not apply to any part time employee of the City of Spring Valley or an
employee of the City of Spring Valley who does not work two thousand eighty
(2,080) hours for the City of Spring Valley in the year preceding their
retirement and shall not apply to any employee who is not old enough to begin
receiving retirement benefits under a retirement plan sponsored and adopted by
the City of Spring Valley upon termination of the employee's employment with
the City of Spring Valley. (Ord. 1368, 2-4-2008; amd. Ord. 1829, 11-15-2021)
1-15-13: EMPLOYEE EDUCATIONAL INCREASE:
Effective retroactive to July 1, 2009, each employee who has successfully
completed thirty (30) college hours shall receive an increase in wages of one
percent (1%). Each employee who has successfully obtained an associate degree
acquiring successful completion of at least sixty five (65) college hours shall
receive an increase in wages of two percent (2%). Each employee who has
successfully completed a bachelor's degree shall receive an increase of wages
of three percent (3%). The educational increase shall be in addition to the
salaries for all employees as set forth in this chapter, as amended from time
to time. (Ord. 1425, 7-20-2009)
1-15-14: EMPLOYEE PERSONAL DAYS:
All employees of the City of Spring Valley shall be entitled to receive two (2)
personal days off with pay during each calendar year. An employee desiring to
take a personal day must receive permission from his or her direct supervisor
to take a personal day and any employee requesting a personal day must
coordinate their request for a personal day so as not to result in an
unanticipated disruption in normal City services. The personal days provided
for in this section cannot be carried over from one calendar year to another
calendar year without prior approval of the head of the department and only for
good cause shown. In no event can an employee carry personal days for more than
one year and any employee who does not use his or her personal days within the
time period set forth herein shall lose this benefit. (Ord. 1179, 9-6-2005,
eff. 1-1-2006)
1-15-15: HEALTH INSURANCE FOR PART TIME EMPLOYEES:
   (A)   With the approval of the Mayor and the Spring Valley City Council,
part time employees of the City of Spring Valley who work thirty (30) or more
hours per week may obtain health insurance coverage through the group health
insurance plan offered by the City of Spring Valley to its full time employees.
(Ord. 1589, 11-24-2014)
   (B)   Any part time employee who desires to take advantage of this insurance
option must pay one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month to the City of Spring
Valley for this insurance coverage.
   (C)   Any part time employee desiring to obtain insurance coverage from the
City of Spring Valley must be able to establish, through his or her immediate
supervisor, that the employee is expected to work more than one thousand seven
hundred (1,700) hours for the City of Spring Valley in a calendar year.
   (D)   Any part time employee desiring to be covered under the provisions of
the health insurance policy of the City of Spring Valley shall be subject to
all copayments, deductibles, and other provisions provided for in the health
insurance policy which the City of Spring Valley has for its employees. (Ord.
1333, 5-7-2007)
1-15-16: EMPLOYEE REIMBURSEMENT FOR INSURANCE BENEFITS:
   (A)   The City of Spring Valley currently provides health insurance, dental
insurance, vision insurance and life/accidental death and dismemberment
insurance (hereinafter referred to as "insurance benefits") to all full time
employees of the City of Spring Valley and those part time employees receiving
insurance benefits pursuant to section
1-15-15 of this chapter. Each employee of the City of Spring Valley will
receive either individual insurance benefits, employee/children (dependents)
insurance benefits, employee/spouse insurance benefits, or employee/family
insurance benefits.
   (B)   Any Spring Valley employee or elected official receiving insurance
benefits from the City of Spring Valley who elects not to claim insurance
benefits under the employee/children (dependents) insurance coverage, the
employee/spouse insurance coverage, or the employee/family insurance coverage
under the City of Spring Valley's insurance benefits shall be entitled to an
increase in the employee's salary equal to fifty percent (50%) of the
difference between the amount which the City of Spring Valley would otherwise
pay in health insurance premiums, if the employee or elected official selected
insurance benefits under the employee/children (dependents) insurance coverage,
the employee/spouse insurance coverage, or the employee/family insurance
coverage under the City of Spring Valley's insurance benefits. (Ord. 1690, 8-
14-2017)
1-15-17: CONFLICTS:
The rules contained within the City of Spring Valley Personnel Manual shall
govern the provisions of holiday pay, vacations, and sick leave benefits. Any
conflict in this chapter with regard to holiday pay, vacations, and sick leaves
benefits shall be controlled by the City of Spring Valley Personnel Manual.
(Ord. 1854, 8-15-2022)

CHAPTER 17
OFFICIAL TIME
SECTION:
1-17-1: Official Time Designated
1-17-2: Transaction Of Business; Official Time
1-17-3: Setting Of City Clocks
1-17-1: OFFICIAL TIME DESIGNATED:
Central Standard Time shall be the official time within the city for the
transaction of all city business, except that from two o’clock (2:00) A.M. on
the second Sunday in March in each year, official time for the city shall be
advanced one hour. At two o’clock (2:00) A.M. on the first Sunday in November
in year such official time, by a set-back of one hour, shall be returned to
Central Standard Time.
(Ord. 1888, 5-6-2024)
1-17-2: TRANSACTION OF BUSINESS; OFFICIAL TIME:
All legal or official proceedings of the council and all official business of
the city shall be regulated as to time in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter. Whenever by ordinance, resolution or action of any municipal
officer or body an act must be performed at or within a prescribed time, it
shall be performed according to the official time as herein prescribed. When
the words "daylight saving" or "daylight saving time" or "summer time" are used
in any official document or contract, it shall be understood to have reference
to the time herein fixed for the period from the last Sunday in April to the
last Sunday in October. (1972 Code)
1-17-3: SETTING OF CITY CLOCKS:
All clocks or other timepieces in or upon public buildings or other premises
maintained at the expense of the city shall be set and run according to the
official time as provided for in this chapter. It is hereby made the duty of
the officer or other person having control and charge of such buildings and
premises to see that the clocks and other timepieces are set and run in
accordance with the official time. (1972 Code)
CHAPTER 18
CORPORATE SEAL
SECTION:
1-18-1: Corporate Seal; Description
1-18-2: Custody Of Seal
1-18-3: Facsimile
1-18-1: CORPORATE SEAL; DESCRIPTION:
A seal in a circular form, with the words "City Of Spring Valley" shall be the
seal of the city, to be used in all cases that have been or shall hereafter be
provided by the laws of the United States, the laws of several respective
states of the United States, and the provisions of this code, and in all cases
in which by the laws and customs of nations, it is necessary to use a seal by a
corporation. (1972 Code)
1-18-2: CUSTODY OF SEAL:
The seal shall remain in the custody and control of the clerk, to be by him
used as required by the provisions of this code; provided however, that in all
cases where by the provisions of this code or any other law of the city, it
shall be necessary for the mayor to use the seal, the same shall be delivered
by the clerk to the mayor temporarily, to be used by him, and after its use it
shall be again returned to the custody of the clerk. (1972 Code)

CHAPTER 19
PURCHASING
SECTION:
1-19-1: Specifications
1-19-2: Bids
1-19-3: Responsible Bidder
1-19-1: SPECIFICATIONS:
All contracts concerning public improvements, maintenance or purchases of
equipment and supplies shall be made in accord with section
1-14-11 of this title. (Ord. 423; amd. Ord. 1738, 1-28-2019)
1-19-2: BIDS:
   (A)   Advertisements: Advertisements for bids shall be placed at least one
time in a newspaper of general circulation printed and published in the City,
and said last advertisement shall not be less than ten (10) days prior to the
date of receiving or opening such bids.
   (B)   Right To Reject: The Council shall determine the most advantageous bid
for the City, but shall always in every such advertisement reserve the right to
reject any and all bids.
   (C)   Specifications On File: During the pendency of advertisements of a
proposed contract, specifications therefor shall be on file in the Office of
the Mayor or the office of the department head for which the contract is to be
let, subject to the inspection of all parties desiring to bid.
   (D)   Contracts Of Two Thousand Five Hundred Dollars Or Less: Nothing in
this chapter shall preclude the Council from directing advertisement on
contracts and specifications for bids in lesser amounts than two thousand five
hundred dollars ($2,500.00), if in their opinion it would be advantageous to
the City to do so. (Ord. 423; amd. Ord. 1738, 1-28-2019)
1-19-3: RESPONSIBLE BIDDER:
A responsible bidder for construction contracts means a bidder as defined in
section 8-10-3 of the Illinois Municipal Code 1 . The City of Spring Valley
will also consider the following minimum qualifications in determining whether
a bidder is a responsible bidder:
   (A)   Certificate/proof to transact business within the State of Illinois.
   (B)   Evidence of compliance with:
      1.   Federal employer tax identification number or social security number
(for individuals).
      2.   "Equal Opportunity Employer" provisions.
   (C)   Certificates of insurance indicating the following coverages: general
liability, workers' compensation, automobile, hazardous occupation, product
liability and professional liability.
   (D)   Participation in apprenticeship and training programs applicable to
the work to be performed on the project which are approved and registered with
the United States Department of Labor's Office of Apprenticeship and Training.
The required evidence includes a copy of all applicable apprenticeship
standards and agreements for any apprentice(s) who will perform work on the
public works project.
   (E)   Compliance with all the provisions of the Illinois Prevailing Wage
Act, including wages, medical and hospitalization insurance and retirement for
those trades as covered in the Act.
   (F)   Disclosure of the names and address of each subcontractor from whom
the contractor has accepted a bid and/or intends to hire on any part of this
project.
   (G)   A copy of the written program for the prevention of substance abuse.
      1.   The bidder shall certify that only workers that are enrolled and
tested in company-based controlled substance and alcohol testing program will
be allowed to participate on the project.
   (H)   Statements as to past performances, which shall give an accurate and
complete record of all work projects completed in the last three (3) years by
the contractor.
   (I)   The contractor and officers of the contractor disclose any tax lien or
delinquency in the last five (5) years.
   (J)   Bidder shall certify that all employees expected to perform work on
the project have completed a 10-hour or greater OSHA safety program within the
last five (5) years. Only workers that have satisfactorily completed a 10-hour
or greater OSHA safety program will be allowed to participate on the project.
The bidder must have copies of employee OSHA cards on file, and the City may
request the bidder provide copies of an employee's OSHA card and if unable to
provide, it may result in a determination that the bidder is not a responsible
bidder.
The City of Spring Valley will require all bidders submitting bids for public
works projects paid for in whole, or in part, with public funds from the City
of Spring Valley for public works projects of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00)
or more to comply with the requirements of this section by providing proof of
compliance with the requirements of this section at the time a bidder submits a
bid to the City of Spring Valley in order to be considered a responsible bidder
under section 8-10-3 of the Illinois Municipal Code. (Ord. 1650, 11-7-2016;
amd. Ord. 1738, 1-28-2019)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/8-10-3.
CHAPTER 20
ANTINEPOTISM
SECTION:
1-20-1: Elected Officials, Relatives Disqualified
1-20-2: Full Time Employees, Relatives Disqualified
1-20-3: Relatives Affected By Regulations
1-20-4: Termination Of Relative Affected
1-20-5: Disqualification From Employment Provisions
1-20-1: ELECTED OFFICIALS, RELATIVES DISQUALIFIED:
In order to prevent the appearance of nepotism, the relatives of any elected
official of the city are disqualified from becoming full time employees of the
city during the term of the elected officer's tenure. The relatives who are
disqualified from being employed by the city under the terms of this chapter
shall be the spouse, child, grandchild or parent of any elected official. All
relationships shall include those relationships arising from adoption. (Ord.
734, 3-4-1991)
1-20-2: FULL TIME EMPLOYEES, RELATIVES DISQUALIFIED:
In order to prevent the appearance of nepotism, the relatives of any full time
employees of the city are disqualified from becoming full time employees of the
city in the same department as their relative as long as their relative is a
full time employee of the city. The relatives who are disqualified from being
employed by the city under the terms of this chapter shall be the spouse,
child, grandchild or parent of any full time city employee. All relationships
shall include those arising from adoption. (Ord. 836, 5-15-1995)
1-20-3: RELATIVES AFFECTED BY REGULATIONS:
This chapter shall apply only to the relatives of either city officials or full
time city employees who are seeking full time, permanent employment with the
city. For the purposes of this chapter, a "full time employee" shall be defined
as any employee of the city who works for the city more than twenty four (24)
hours per week for thirty (30) or more weeks within any twelve (12) month
period. This chapter shall not apply to any part time summer employees of the
city. A "part time summer employee" of the city is defined as a part time
employee working for the city between the months of May and September of each
year who, although working more than twenty four (24) hours per week, does not
work for more than eighteen (18) weeks for the city within any twelve (12)
month period. (Ord. 734, 3-4-1991)
1-20-4: TERMINATION OF RELATIVE AFFECTED:
Whenever an elected official or employee becomes related, either by marriage or
adoption, to another elected official or employee in one of the relationships
previously listed in this chapter, the affected official and/or employee shall
be allowed to remain in his or her position for a period of sixty (60) days
from the date on which the affected person became related. If one of the
affected persons has not resigned within the sixty (60) day period established
herein, where one of the affected persons is an elected official, and the
remaining affected person is an employee of the city, the mayor shall terminate
the employment of the employee; and where both of the affected persons are
employees of the city, the mayor shall terminate the employee with the shortest
length of employment with the city. (Ord. 734, 3-4-1991)
1-20-5: DISQUALIFICATION FROM EMPLOYMENT PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed to disqualify from
employment any individual who is currently a full time employee of the city.
For the purposes of determining full time employees of the city on the date
when this chapter becomes effective, a "full time employee" shall be defined as
any employee who worked more than one thousand seven hundred fifty (1,750)
hours for the city during the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding
the passage of this chapter. (Ord. 734, 3-4-1991)
CHAPTER 21
INVESTMENT POLICY
SECTION:
1-21-1: Policy
1-21-2: Scope
1-21-3: Prudence
1-21-4: Objective
1-21-5: Delegation Of Authority
1-21-6: Ethics
1-21-7: Authorized Financial Dealers And Institutions
1-21-8: Authorized And Suitable Investments
1-21-9: Collateralization
1-21-10: Safekeeping And Custody
1-21-11: Diversification
1-21-12: Maximum Maturities
1-21-13: Internal Control
1-21-14: Performance Standards
1-21-15: Reporting
1-21-16: Statement Of Market Value
1-21-17: Adoption
1-21-1: POLICY:
It is the policy of the city of Spring Valley to invest public funds in a
manner which will provide the highest investment return with the maximum
security while meeting the daily cash flow demands of the city and conforming
to all state and local statutes governing the investment of public funds. (Ord.
927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-2: SCOPE:
This policy includes all funds governed by the Spring Valley city council.
(Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-3: PRUDENCE:
Investments shall be made with judgment and care, under circumstances then
prevailing, which persons of prudence, discretion and intelligence exercise in
the management of their own affairs, not for speculation, but for investment,
considering the probable safety of their capital, as well as the probable
income to be derived. The standard of prudence to be used by investment
officials shall be the "prudent person" standard and shall be applied in the
context of managing an overall portfolio. (Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-4: OBJECTIVE:
The primary objective, in order of priority, shall be:
Legality - conformance with federal, state and other legal requirements.
Safety - preservation of capital and protection of investment principal.
Liquidity - maintenance of sufficient liquidity to meet operating requirements.
Yield - attainment of market rates of return.
The portfolio should be reviewed periodically as to its effectiveness in
meeting the city's needs for safety, liquidity, rate of return, diversification
and its general performance. (Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-5: DELEGATION OF AUTHORITY:
Management and administrative responsibility for the investment program is
hereby delegated to the city treasurer. The city treasurer shall report to the
chairman of the Spring Valley city council finance committee. The treasurer and
the Spring Valley city council finance committee shall meet on an ad hoc basis
as determined by the chairman of the Spring Valley finance committee to review
the operation of the investment program and to modify this investment policy in
any manner deemed appropriate by the city council of the city of Spring Valley.
(Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-6: ETHICS:
Officers and employees involved in the investment process shall refrain from
personal business activity that could conflict with the proper execution and
management of the investment program, or that could impair their ability to
make impartial decisions. (Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-7: AUTHORIZED FINANCIAL DEALERS AND INSTITUTIONS:
The treasurer will maintain a list of financial institutions authorized to
provide investment services. In addition, a list will also be maintained of
approved security brokers/dealers selected by creditworthiness. (Ord. 927, 4-5-
1999)
1-21-8: AUTHORIZED AND SUITABLE INVESTMENTS:
Investments may be made in any type of security allowed for in Illinois
statutes regarding the investment of public funds.
Investments shall be made that reflect the cash flow needs of the fund type
being invested. (Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-9: COLLATERALIZATION:
Funds on deposit (checking accounts, certificates of deposit, etc.) in excess
of FDIC limits must be secured by some form of collateral, witnessed by a
written agreement and held at an independent third party institution in the
name of the municipality. (Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-10: SAFEKEEPING AND CUSTODY:
All security transactions, including collateral for repurchase agreements,
entered into by the city of Spring Valley, shall be conducted on a delivery
versus payment (DVP) basis. Securities will be held by an independent third
party custodian and by the treasurer and evidenced by safekeeping receipts and
a written custodial agreement. (Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-11: DIVERSIFICATION:
The city shall diversify its investments to the best of its ability based on
the type of funds invested and the cash flow needs of those funds.
Diversification can be by type of investment, number of institutions invested
in, and length of maturity. (Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-12: MAXIMUM MATURITIES:
To the extent possible, the city of Spring Valley shall attempt to match its
investments and anticipated cash flow requirements. Unless matched to a
specific cash flow, the city of Spring Valley will not directly invest in
securities maturing more than two (2) years from the date of purchase. Reserve
funds may be invested in securities exceeding two (2) years if the maturity of
such investments are made to coincide as nearly as practicable with the
expected use of the funds. (Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-13: INTERNAL CONTROL:
The treasurer is responsible for establishing and maintaining an internal
control structure designed to ensure that the assets of the city are protected
from loss, theft or misuse. The internal control structure shall be designed to
provide reasonable assurance that these objectives are met. The internal
controls shall address the following points:
   (A)   Control of collusion.
   (B)   Separation of transaction authority from accounting.
   (C)   Custodial safekeeping.
   (D)   Written confirmation of telephone transactions for investments and
wire transfers. (Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-14: PERFORMANCE STANDARDS:
This investment portfolio will be managed in accordance with the parameters
specified within the policy. The portfolio should obtain a comparable rate of
return during a market/economic environment of stable interest rates. Portfolio
performance should be compared to bench marks with similar maturity, liquidity
and credit quality as the portfolio. Nothing in these performance standards
shall be deemed to require the treasurer to invest municipal funds in financial
institutions not having business locations within the corporate limits of the
city of Spring Valley. Funds may be invested in financial institutions not
having facilities within the city of Spring Valley upon the recommendation of
the city treasurer and the concurrence of the Spring Valley city council. The
city of Spring Valley is supported by local financial institutions and deems it
to be in the best interests of the city of Spring Valley to support those local
financial institutions having a physical presence in the city of Spring Valley.
(Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-15: REPORTING:
The treasurer shall prepare an investment report at least monthly. The report
shall be provided to the Spring Valley city council. The report should be in a
format suitable for review by the general public. An annual report should also
be provided to the city council. (Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-16: STATEMENT OF MARKET VALUE:
A statement of the market value of the portfolio shall be issued to the city
council quarterly. (Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
1-21-17: ADOPTION:
This investment policy shall be adopted by the Spring Valley city council. The
policy shall be reviewed on an annual basis by the treasurer and the chairman
of the Spring Valley finance committee and any modifications made thereto must
be approved by the Spring Valley city council. (Ord. 927, 4-5-1999)
CHAPTER 22
ETHICS
SECTION:
1-22-1: State Officials And Employees Ethics Act
1-22-1: STATE OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES ETHICS ACT:
   (A)   The regulations of section 5-15 1  and article 10 2  of the state
officials and employees ethics act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et
seq. (hereinafter referred to as the "act" in this section), are hereby adopted
by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of the city to
the extent required by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5.
   (B)   The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or
accepted under the act, by any officer or any employee of the city, is hereby
prohibited.
   (C)   The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an
officer or employee of the city under the act, is hereby prohibited.
   (D)   The participation in political activities prohibited under the act, by
any officer or employee of the city, is hereby prohibited.
   (E)   For purposes of this section, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall
be defined as set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(c).
   (F)   The penalties for violations of this section shall be the same as
those penalties set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/50-5 for similar
violations of the act.
   (G)   This section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing
ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of city officers and
employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less
restrictive than this section, however, the provisions of this section shall
prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/
70-5(a).
   (H)   Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective
date of this section shall be incorporated into this section by reference and
shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of
gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes
its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be
incorporated into this section by reference without formal action by the
corporate authorities of the city.
   (I)   If the Illinois supreme court declares the act unconstitutional in its
entirety, then this section shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois
supreme court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals
or rehearings. This section shall be deemed repealed without further action by
the corporate authorities of the city if the act is found unconstitutional by
the Illinois supreme court.
   (J)   If the Illinois supreme court declares part of the act
unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the act,
or does not address the remainder of the act, then the remainder of the act as
adopted by this section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that
part of this section relating to the part of the act found unconstitutional
shall be deemed repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of
the city. (Ord. 1133, 5-17-2004)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 430/5-15.
2 2. 5 ILCS 430/10-10 – 10-40.
CHAPTER 23

   (A)   There is hereby established the position of Economic Development
Director and Project Manager for the City of Spring Valley. The duties of

shall be to work with local businesses on matters of economic development, work

Spring Valley shall report his or her activities to the Spring Valley City
Council and provide the Spring Valley City Council with regular updates on his
or her activities and accomplishments. The Economic Development Director and
Project Manager of the City of Spring Valley shall report directly to the Mayor
of the City of Spring Valley and be supervised by the Mayor of the City of
Spring Valley with additional reporting to the Spring Valley City Council as
set forth in this section. (Ord. 1177, 9-6-2005; amd. Ord. 1870, 5-15-2023)
