CHAPTER 3
EMERGENCY SERVICE AND DISASTER AGENCY LIAISON
SECTION:
2-3-1: Establishment
2-3-2: Liaison Officer
2-3-3: Function
2-3-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby created the Spring Valley ESDA liaison officer to facilitate
the cooperation and protection of the city with the Bureau County emergency
service and disaster agency in the work of disaster mitigation, preparedness,
response and recovery in accordance with the Illinois emergency service and
disaster agency act of 1988 (PA 85-1027). (Ord. 705, 11-6-1989)
2-3-2: LIAISON OFFICER:
The liaison officer of the Spring Valley ESDA shall be appointed by the mayor
and shall serve until removed by the same. The Spring Valley ESDA shall consist
only of the liaison officer unless additional personnel is approved by the
Spring Valley city council. The liaison officer shall have direct
responsibility for facilitating the cooperation and protection of the city with
the Bureau County emergency service and disaster agency.
In the event of the absence, reservation, death or inability to serve as
liaison officer, the mayor or any person designated by him, shall be enacted as
liaison officer until a new appointment is made as provided in this chapter.
(Ord. 705, 11-6-1989)
2-3-3: FUNCTION:
The city has decided not to establish a separate and independent emergency
service and disaster agency. Rather, the city council of the city has deemed it
appropriate to act in liaison with the emergency service and disaster agency
provided to the residents of the city by Bureau County, Illinois. The Spring
Valley liaison officer shall operate as a liaison with the Bureau County ESDA
and the Spring Valley liaison officer shall perform no functions other than
those liaison officer duties specifically enumerated in section 10,
subparagraph E of the Illinois emergency service and disaster agency act of
1988 (PA 85-1027). (Ord. 705, 11-6-1989)
CHAPTER 4
PARK BOARD
SECTION:
2-4-1: Creation Of Board
2-4-2: Membership
2-4-3: Removals
2-4-4: Finances
2-4-5: Jurisdiction
2-4-6: Control
2-4-7: Pool Manager And Assistant Pool Manager
2-4-8: Safety
2-4-9: Park Supervisor Duty
2-4-10: Park Custodian Duty
2-4-11: Violation Of Park Rules
2-4-1: CREATION OF BOARD:
There is hereby created a park board for the city. The park board serves to
implement the policies of the mayor and the city council, and the park board
will inform the mayor and the city council of the park board's plans for the
city parks under the direction of the park board, and for any procedures which
the park board desires to adopt in order to properly manage the city parks.
(Ord. 1800, 11-30-2020)
2-4-2: MEMBERSHIP:
The park board shall consist of eleven (11) members who shall serve for a term
of five (5) years, except that the members thus appointed for such term that
the terms of one member shall expire annually thereafter to the extent
practicable. If a vacancy occurs in the office of any board member, the mayor
shall appoint a successor to serve for the unexpired term. The members of the
park board shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the advice and consent
of the council. (Ord. 1800, 11-30-2020; Ord. 1820, 9-7-2021)
2-4-3: REMOVALS:
The mayor may, with the consent of the council, remove any member of the park
board for misconduct or neglect of duty. (Ord. 1800, 11-30-2020)
2-4-4: FINANCES:
The park board shall have charge of the expenditure of the playground and
recreation fund developed from the special tax for that purpose or from any
other source; and warrants in this fund shall be honored only on order of the
board; and shall have such other and further powers and authority as in the
statutes in such case made and provided; including the power to receive gifts
and bequests, and the issuance of bonds and all other powers specifically
provided by law. The president of the park board shall have authority to
authorize expenditures up to five hundred ($500.00) dollars. Any expenditures
made by the park board exceeding five hundred ($500.00) dollars must be
approved by the majority vote of the park board. Before making any expenditures
in excess of ten thousand ($10,000.00) dollars, the expenditure must be
approved by the majority of the members of the park board and also approved by
a majority of the city council.(Ord. 1800, 11-30-2020)
2-4-5: JURISDICTION:
The park board shall have control and jurisdiction over all playgrounds,
recreation centers, swimming pools and other public places which have
previously, or may in the future, be dedicated to the purpose of public
recreation and given over to their control. The park board has the
responsibility for the safety, cleanliness and security of Knol Park, Kirby
Park, Foley Field, the soccer field adjacent to Kirby Park, the Coveny Veterans
Memorial Pool, Baltikauski Park, Pederzani Park, Casford Park, Cole Miner's
Park, the Spring Valley Mini Park, Savitch Park, the City Hall Park and flare
outs on the 100 and 200 blocks of East and West St. Paul Street. (Ord. 1800,
11-30-2020)
2-4-6: CONTROL:
   (A)   The playgrounds and recreation areas under the jurisdiction of the
park board shall be closed to the public each day, from ten o'clock (10:00)
P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M., except that during the months of June, July,
August and September, the closing time for Kirby Park shall be extended to
eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. in the event a regularly scheduled and park board
authorized activity is in progress, and except that the closing time for the
Second Place basketball courts shall be eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. at all times
during the year.
   (B)   No automobiles, motor vehicles or bicycles shall be permitted within
the playgrounds and recreation areas under control of the park board at any
time except within parking areas expressly marked as such; no automobiles,
motor vehicles or bicycles shall be permitted within said playgrounds and
recreation areas between ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
   (C)   No alcoholic liquor or other beverages shall be sold within said
playgrounds and recreation areas under the jurisdiction of the park board at
any time except as provided in subsection (H) of this section.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person to in any way litter or cause to
be littered, the grounds, driveways or parking areas of said playgrounds and
recreation areas under the jurisdiction of the park board by scattering or
leaving papers, garbage, bottles, cans or any other refuse matter in said
playgrounds and recreation areas.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful for any person to act in an intoxicated,
boisterous, disorderly, lewd or otherwise objectionable manner within said
playgrounds and recreation areas under the jurisdiction of the park board.
   (F)   It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy, deface or otherwise
injure any property within said playgrounds and recreation areas under the
jurisdiction of the park board.
   (G)   It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any gun, rifle or
firearm of any type within said playgrounds and recreation areas under the
jurisdiction of the park board.
   (H)   No undertaking for profit of any kind may be held or conducted within
the playgrounds and recreation areas under the jurisdiction of the park board;
provided however, that the park board may permit fraternal, benevolent,
charitable or religious organizations organized not for profit to sell
refreshments and beer but excluding all other alcoholic beverages for special
events approved by both the park board and the city council. Any fraternal,
benevolent, charitable or religious organizations, organized not for profit
desiring to sell beer, but excluding all other alcoholic beverages, must first
obtain a temporary license issued by the Liquor Control Commissioner of the
City of Spring Valley as provided for by Section
5-18-11 of this code, and subject to the applicant tendering evidence of liquor
liability insurance, naming the applicant and the city as insureds with maximum
limits as provided for by Illinois law and that applicant further furnish
public liability insurance naming the city as an insured with maximum and
minimum limits to be determined by the city council.
   That the park board may further permit individuals, fraternal, benevolent,
charitable or religious organizations organized not for profit to serve beer,
but excluding all other alcoholic liquor, in conjunction with any picnic
authorized by the park board on park property, meeting the aforementioned
insurance requirements.
   That any alcoholic beverages either sold at retail or otherwise served on
playground and recreation areas under the jurisdiction of the park board shall
be in a fenced off area where no person under the age of twenty one (21) years
shall be served alcoholic liquor or be permitted to loiter. The security fence
herein required shall be of such design and construction so as to prevent the
removal of alcoholic beverages from the fenced in area and shall be approved as
to type and construction by the board or its representative.
   The sponsoring organization shall be responsible for and required to provide
security personnel which may include, but shall not be limited to, off duty law
enforcement officers or specially trained security personnel, to prevent the
violation of the restrictions imposed herein and in the event of a violation of
the restrictions set forth, the chief of police may order the sponsoring
organization to cease and terminate the sale or serving of alcoholic beverages
as herein provided.
   The sponsoring organization shall, no later than ten (10) days prior to the
scheduled event, deposit with the city clerk the sum of one thousand
($1,000.00) dollars in cash, which said deposit shall be made for the purpose
of ensuring the cleanup costs or damage to park property occasioned in the
course of conduct of the activity by said sponsoring organization. The deposit
shall be returned to the sponsoring organization within five (5) days of the
activity and only in the event the board or its representative determines that
the area used by the sponsoring organization has been restored to the same
condition as it was prior to the holding of said activity and that no unusual
damage was suffered by the park and recreation property.
   That in the event any sporting venture is permitted other than under the
recreation program sponsored by the park board of the city, the sponsor thereof
must further furnish evidence of public liability insurance naming the city as
a named insured in limits required by the city, and in addition thereto,
execute an indemnity and save harmless agreement prepared by the city attorney
in addition to the aforesaid insurance requirements.
   (I)   It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or consume alcohol in
or around the Coveny Veteran's Memorial Swimming Pool and the swimming pool
parking lot. For the purposes of this section prohibiting the possession or
consumption of alcohol, the Spring Valley city pool shall be deemed to
encompass that area bounded by Strong Avenue on the east, the entrance road to
Kirby Park off of Strong Avenue on the north, the easternmost boundary of the
new parking lot established immediately to the west of the swimming pool to the
west and the boundary of Kirby Park to the south.
   (J)   No alcoholic beverages are permitted on the playing areas or within
the confines of the fenced in areas of the baseball field (including dugouts),
the tennis courts or the volleyball courts unless prior approval for the
consumption of alcoholic beverages is given by the park board.
   (K)   Consumption of alcoholic beverages is not permitted within thirty feet
(30') of the fence surrounding the baseball field at Kirby Park during high
school baseball games.
   (L)   Non-Spring Valley residents wishing to reserve a park shelter in the
Spring Valley park system shall be required to pay a nonrefundable registration
fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) to help defray the cost of maintaining the
Spring Valley park system.
   (M)   Glass containers of any kind are not permitted in the Spring Valley
city parks due to the significant safety hazard presented by broken bottles.
All dogs, except seeing eye dogs and police canine dogs, are not permitted in
the Spring Valley city parks due to the significant safety hazard they may
present.
   (N)   The park board, with the approval and consent of the city council,
shall be authorized to appoint and employ a park supervisor and a park
custodian who shall be responsible for enforcing the park board rules and
regulations and the provisions set forth in this code. The park supervisor
shall be a full-time city employee assigned to the park board from the Spring
Valley Street Department. The park supervisor shall be assigned to the park
board and the park board shall delineate the duties and responsibilities of the
park supervisor for the period from March 1st through October 31st of each
year. During the period of each year when the park supervisor is not working at
the direction of the park board, the park supervisor shall return to his
regular employment as a member of the Spring Valley Street Department.
   (O)   Any individual or group violating either the park board rules and
regulations (copies of which are available at the Spring Valley city clerk's
office) or any provisions of this code or state law shall be subject to the
fine provisions as set forth in this section and shall also be subject to
immediate removal and ejection from the Spring Valley park system.
   (P)   All baseball leagues wishing to use Spring Valley city park facilities
shall be required to pay a fifty dollar ($50.00) league registration fee for
use of the Spring Valley baseball diamond facilities. This fee shall not apply
to Hall High School, but shall apply to any other baseball teams using Spring
Valley park facilities.
   (Q)   The fees established for the swimmers wishing to use the Coveny
Veteran's Memorial Swimming Pool shall be as follows:
 
Daily fee: adults, senior citizens and high school $ 1.25
Daily fee: youth                                   1.00
Adult season pass                                  35.00
Family season pass                                 70.00
Senior citizen pass (62 years of age and older)    20.00
Youth season pass (under 14 years of age)          30.00
 
   (R)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than
two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense.
   (S)   It shall be unlawful for anyone to use Foley Field on the days that
the Hall High School baseball teams have home games and require the use of
Foley Field. (Ord. 1800, 11-30-2020; amd. Ord. 1866, 4-3-2023)
2-4-7: POOL MANAGER AND ASSISTANT POOL MANAGER:
With the consent of the Spring Valley City Council, the park board shall employ
a pool manager and an assistant pool manager to operate the Coveny Veteran's
Memorial Swimming Pool. With the approval of the park board and the Spring
Valley City Council, the pool manager may hire pool employees and may designate
and established job responsibilities for these pool employees. The assistant
pool manager shall perform all of the functions of the pool manager when the
pool manager is not available. The salaries to be paid to the pool manager, the
assistant pool manager and any employees hired to operate the Coveny Veteran's
Memorial Swimming Pool will be established by the Spring Valley City Council
based upon recommendations and input from the park board. (Ord. 1800, 11-30-
2020)
2-4-8: SAFETY:
The pool manager is hereby authorized to implement whatever safety procedures
he deems necessary in order to ensure for the proper, responsible and safe use
of the city swimming pool. Specifically, said pool manager is authorized to
prohibit glass containers in the immediate area around the pool as well as to
take any other actions deemed necessary for public safety. (Ord. 1800, 11-30-
2020)
2-4-9: PARK SUPERVISOR DUTY:
The City of Spring Valley will assign a member of the Spring Valley Street
Department to serve as park supervisor from March 1st through October 31st of
each year. Between April 1st and October 31st of each year, the park supervisor
shall report to the park board president and the park board president shall be
responsible for supervising all work duties assigned to the park supervisor by
the park board. The park supervisor shall be required to submit a plan for
maintenance and park improvements for all playground and recreation areas under
the control of the park board not less than annually. The park supervisor shall
also attend all park board meetings and give a report of his/her work
activities to the park board. The park board shall prepare a written list of
duties and responsibilities to be performed by the park supervisor. Those
duties shall include, at a minimum, to cut grass at all city parks, clean the
restrooms at all city parks in order to keep the restrooms in a clean and safe
condition, assist other city employees in opening and closing the Coveny
Veterans Swimming Pool in May and August of each year, prepare baseball,
softball and soccer fields for their intended uses, clean and maintain picnic
pavilions, make repairs to all recreational facilities and equipment as
required, supervise any part-time summer help assigned to the park supervisor
to assist the park supervisor with the park supervisor's duties, and to
accomplish any other additional tasks assigned to the park supervisor by the
park board. If requested by the president of the park board, the park
supervisor shall be available for work during weekends and after five o’clock
(5:00) P.M. on weekdays. From November 1st to February 28th each year, the park
supervisor shall work as a member of the Spring Valley Street Department and
shall be under the direct supervision of the city superintendent of public
works. In the event of any unanticipated emergency occurring between March 1st
and October 28th of each year which requires the park supervisor to temporarily
return to work as a member of the Spring Valley Street Department, the city
superintendent of public works shall notify the park board president that the
park supervisor has been temporarily reassigned to the Spring Valley Park
Department. After the emergency ends, the city superintendent of public works
shall notify the park board president that the park supervisor has been
returned to his or her duties as park supervisor under the supervision of the
park board president. (Ord. 1800, 11-30-2020)
2-4-10: PARK CUSTODIAN DUTY:
The park custodian position is created to assist the park supervisor with the
duties assigned to the park supervisor by the park board. The park custodian
position is created in order to ensure that there will be an employee available
to perform the duties assigned to the park supervisor on weekends and on
holidays when the park supervisor may not be at work. Additionally, the park
custodian may be assigned by the park board to assist the park supervisor
during those times during the year when the duties assigned to the park
supervisor cannot be reasonably completed by only one employee. The park
custodian position shall be a part-time position. The park custodian shall not
be allowed to work more than five hundred ninety-nine (599) hours in any fiscal
year (May 1st to April 30th) and the park custodian position will not receive
any benefits other than the salary paid to the park custodian. Before hiring a
park custodian, the park board must provide the city council with the name of
the proposed park custodian, the wage to be paid to the park custodian and the
days and hours during which the park custodian will be expected to work and
receive approval from the city council to hire a park custodian. (Ord. 1800,
11-30-2020)
2-4-11: VIOLATION OF PARK RULES:
Any individual or group violating either the park boar rules and regulations
(copies of which are available at the Spring Valley City Clerk's office) or any
provisions of the Spring Valley City Code or state law shall be subject to a
fine of not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) and shall also be subject to immediate removal and ejection
from the Spring Valley park system. (Ord. 1800, 11-30-2020)
CHAPTER 5
POLICE PENSION BOARD
SECTION:
2-5-1: Creation
2-5-2: Members
2-5-3: Maintenance Of Fund
2-5-1: CREATION:
There shall be a police pension fund established in the city as provided by
law. (1972 Code)
2-5-2: MEMBERS:
The board of trustees of the said fund shall consist of five (5) members, two
(2) appointed by the mayor, one of such members serving for the period of one
year beginning on the second Tuesday of the first May after the passage of this
chapter, and one of such members serving for a period of two (2) years
beginning on the same date, with the successors to any of the foregoing
trustees serving for a period of two (2) years, or until such time as their
successors are appointed and qualified, and two (2) elected by the members of
the police department, and one elected by the beneficiaries of the pension
fund. The elections shall be held on the third Monday in April, and the term of
each member elected shall be for two (2) years, beginning on the second Tuesday
of the first May after the passage of this chapter. The pension board shall
meet at least quarterly as provided by law, and shall hold such additional
meetings as may be called by the president of the pension board. (1972 Code)
2-5-3: MAINTENANCE OF FUND:
There shall be deposited in the pension fund, the sums required by law, which
shall include eight and one-half percent (81/2%) per month, deducted from the
salary of each member of the police force, together with the proceeds of an
annual tax which shall be levied as provided by law.
For the purposes of this section, the word "salary" means the annual salary
including longevity attached to the rank held by the policemen as established
by the municipality's appropriation ordinance, but does not include "overtime
pay", "holiday pay", "bonus pay", "merit pay", or any other cash benefit over
and above the salary established by the appropriation ordinance. (Ord., 11-2-
1981)
CHAPTER 6
BOARD OF HEALTH
SECTION:
2-6-1: Creation And Members
2-6-2: Duties
2-6-3: Quarantine And Vaccination
2-6-1: CREATION AND MEMBERS:
There is hereby created the board of health for the city. The board of health
shall consist of the mayor, chief of police and health officer, said health
officer being a duly licensed physician appointed by the mayor with the advice
and consent of the council. (1972 Code)
2-6-2: DUTIES:
The board of health shall have the powers and perform the duties assigned to it
by statute or ordinance. It shall be the duty of the board of health to enforce
all provisions of this code which relate to public health or relate to
nuisances.
The board of health shall make all necessary rules and regulations for the
protection of the health of the city and to guard against the spread of
contagious diseases and to prevent by necessary rules the induction of
diseases, contagious or otherwise, within the corporate limits of the city.
(1972 Code)
2-6-3: QUARANTINE AND VACCINATION:
The board of health is hereby authorized to make such reasonable rules as may
be necessary regarding quarantine and vaccination, for the prevention and
spread of contagious diseases, and to quarantine premises where such diseases
occur for such time as may be necessary to protect public health.
The said board shall have the power to prevent persons from entering or leaving
premises on which a case of contagious or epidemic disease occurs or is found,
and to placard the same with signs indicating the nature of such disease and
the existence of quarantine. (1972 Code)
CHAPTER 7
LIBRARY BOARD
SECTION:
2-7-1: Establishment And Approval
2-7-2: Number Of Directors
2-7-3: Terms Of Directors
2-7-4: Vacancies
2-7-5: Officers
2-7-6: Freedom Of Use
2-7-7: Report Of Directors
2-7-8: Donations
2-7-9: Damage To Property
2-7-10: Penalties
2-7-11: Name
2-7-1: ESTABLISHMENT AND APPROVAL:
The grant heretofore made to the city by Andrew Carnegie for the purpose of
building and establishing a free public library for the use and benefit of the
inhabitants of the city, and the ordinance approving the same be and the same
is hereby accepted and readopted by the city. (1972 Code)
2-7-2: NUMBER OF DIRECTORS:
The mayor has by previous ordinance and with the approval of the council,
appointed a board of nine (9) directors for the said public library and reading
room, chosen from the citizens at large with reference to their fitness for
such office. (1972 Code)
2-7-3: TERMS OF DIRECTORS:
Said directors shall hold office, one-third (1/3) for one year, one-third (1/3)
for two (2) years and one-third (1/3) for three (3) years from July 1 following
their appointment, and have been so appointed that annually thereafter the
mayor shall before July 1 of each year appoint as before three (3) directors,
to take the place of the retiring directors, who shall hold office for three
(3) years and until their successors are appointed. The mayor may, by and with
the consent of the council, remove any director for misconduct or neglect of
duty. (1972 Code)
2-7-4: VACANCIES:
Vacancies in the board of directors occasioned by removals, resignations or
otherwise shall be reported to the council by the mayor and be filled in like
manner as original appointments, and no director shall receive compensation as
such. (1972 Code)
2-7-5: OFFICERS:
Said directors shall elect one of their number president and elect a secretary
and such other officers as they may deem necessary, and annually thereafter, on
the first Tuesday in July, they shall elect a president and secretary. Said
board of directors shall keep a record of its proceedings and shall make and
adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for the guidance of said board and for
the government of said library and reading room as may be expedient, not
inconsistent with this chapter. Said board of directors shall have exclusive
control of the library building and of the supervision, care and custody of the
grounds, rooms or buildings constructed or procured for that purpose, shall be
authorized to receive donations and gifts, and the income arising therefrom and
all other like funds shall be deposited in the treasury of the city to the
credit of the library fund, and shall be kept separate and apart from other
monies of the city; and the council shall on the duly authenticated request of
the board of directors of the library, appropriate out of the library funds
above mentioned such sums as may be required for the construction, supply and
maintenance of said library. The appropriations above provided for in this
section shall be paid by the city treasurer on the order of the board of
directors of the library signed by their president and secretary; and the
council shall make annual appropriations of such amount as may be deemed
necessary for the support of said library and reading room and levy a tax for
the same or transfer the amount so appropriated out of other funds not
otherwise appropriated; and all such monies so raised by taxation or
transferred out of other funds as aforesaid shall be deposited in the treasury
of the city, to the credit of the library fund, and shall be kept separate and
apart from other monies of the city and shall be drawn upon warrants signed by
the mayor and city clerk upon vouchers signed by the president and secretary of
the said board of directors.
Said board of directors shall have power to invest at interest the library
funds received from donations as aforesaid and to collect and pay over to the
city treasurer the amounts so invested and the income arising from the same;
shall have the power to appoint a suitable librarian and necessary assistants
and fix their compensation, and shall have power to remove such appointees and
shall in general carry out the spirit and intent of this chapter in
establishing and maintaining a public library and reading room. (1972 Code)
2-7-6: FREEDOM OF USE:
The public library and reading room established by this chapter shall be
forever free to the inhabitants of the city, always subject to such reasonable
rules and regulations as the library board may adopt in order to render the use
of said library and reading room of the greatest benefit to the greatest
number. The said board may exclude from the use of said library and reading
room any and all persons who shall wilfully violate said rules. Said board may
extend the privileges and use of such library and reading room to persons
residing outside of the city and in this state, upon such terms and conditions
as said board may from time to time, by its regulations prescribe. (1972 Code)
2-7-7: REPORT OF DIRECTORS:
The said board of directors shall make, on or before the second Monday in June,
an annual report to the council, stating the condition of their trust on June 1
in that year, the various sums of money received from the library fund and from
other sources, and how much monies have been expended and for what purpose; the
number of books and periodicals on hand and the number added by purchase, gift
or otherwise during the year, the number lost or missing; the number of
visitors attending; the number of books loaned out and the general character
and kind of such books, and other statistics, information and suggestions as
they may deem of general interest, and all portions of said report as relate to
the receipt and expenditure of money, as well as the number of books on hand,
books lost or missing, and books purchased shall be verified by the affidavit
of the president or secretary of said board of directors. (1972 Code)
2-7-8: DONATIONS:
Any person desiring to make donations of money, personal property or real
estate for the benefit of such library shall have the right to vest the title
to the money or real estate so donated in the board of directors of the public
library and reading room, to be held and controlled by such board, when
accepted according to the terms of the deed, gift, devise or bequest of such
property; and as to such property, the said board shall be held and considered
to be special trustees. (1972 Code)
2-7-9: DAMAGE TO PROPERTY:
Every person who shall negligently injure any book or other property of said
library and reading room under the control of the board of directors thereof,
or who shall neglect or refuse to return any book, periodical or paper
belonging thereto or under the control thereof, after demand therefor has been
made by the said board or its agent, shall, on conviction thereof, be fined not
less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
each offense. (1972 Code)
2-7-10: PENALTIES:
Every person who shall wilfully violate any rule or regulation adopted by said
board of directors pursuant to sections
2-7-6 and
2-7-7 of this chapter, and conspicuously posted in the room or rooms where the
books of said library and reading room are kept, or who shall be guilty of any
noisy, boisterous or disorderly conduct in or about said room or rooms, shall,
on conviction thereof, be fined not exceeding twenty five dollars ($25.00) for
each offense. Any fines recovered for violations of this chapter shall be paid
into and become a part of the library fund. (1972 Code)
2-7-11: NAME:
The public library and reading room heretofore established shall be known and
called "Spring Valley Public Library". (1972 Code)
CHAPTER 8
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
SECTION:
2-8-1: Creation
2-8-2: Membership
2-8-3: Appointment Of Board
2-8-4: Appointment Of Police Officers
2-8-5: Rules
2-8-6: Qualification Of Applicants To Police Department
2-8-7: Notice Of Examination
2-8-8: Register Of Eligibles
2-8-9: Promotions
2-8-10: Temporary Appointments
2-8-11: Discharge
2-8-12: Report To Council
2-8-13: Records
2-8-14: Forfeiture As Member Of Board
2-8-15: Compensation
2-8-1: CREATION:
There is hereby created a board to be known as the board of fire and police
commissioners. (Ord. 899, 5-17-1997)
2-8-2: MEMBERSHIP:
The mayor of the city, with the consent of the council, shall appoint a board
of fire and police commissioners. This board shall consist of three (3)
members, whose terms of office shall be three (3) years and until their
respective successors are appointed and have qualified, except as provided in
section
2-8-3 of this chapter. No such appointment, however, shall be made by any mayor
within thirty (30) days before the expiration of his term of office. (Ord. 899,
5-17-1997)
2-8-3: APPOINTMENT OF BOARD:
The first appointments to be made by the mayor, with the approval of the
council, shall be as follows: one of the members shall be appointed to serve
until the end of the then current municipal year, another to serve until the
end of the municipal year second next ensuing. But every member shall serve
until his successor is appointed and has qualified. (Ord. 899, 5-17-1997)
2-8-4: APPOINTMENT OF POLICE OFFICERS:
The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all officers and
members of the police department of the municipality with the exception of the
chief of police, who shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the
council. All appointments to such department other than that of the lowest
rank, however, shall be made from the rank next below that to which the
appointment is made, except that the chief of police shall be appointed by the
mayor with the approval of the city council. (Ord. 899, 5-17-1997)
2-8-5: RULES:
The board shall make rules: a) to carry out the purpose of this chapter, and b)
for appointments and removals in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter. The board, from time to time, may make changes in these rules.
All these rules and changes shall be printed immediately for distribution. The
board shall give notice: a) of the place where the printed rules may be
obtained, and b) of the date, not less than ten (10) days subsequent to the
time of publication, when the rules or changes therein shall go into operation.
This notice shall be published in the official paper of the municipality, if
there is one, and if not, then in a newspaper generally circulated in the
municipality. (Ord. 899, 5-17-1997)
2-8-6: QUALIFICATION OF APPLICANTS TO POLICE DEPARTMENT:
All applicants for a position in the police department of the municipality
shall be subjected to examination, which shall be public, competitive, free to
all electors of the municipality, subject to reasonable limitations as to
residence, age, health, habits and moral character and subject to any other
provisions as set forth in the board of fire and police commissioners act 1
and subject to those rules and regulations duly adopted and promulgated by the
board of fire and police commissioners pursuant to the authority granted to the
board by this chapter. (Ord. 899, 5-17-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 – 5/10-2.1-30.
2-8-7: NOTICE OF EXAMINATION:
Notice of the time and place of every examination shall be given by the board
by a publication not less than two (2) weeks preceding the examination, in the
official newspaper of the municipality, if there is one, and if not, then in
any newspaper of general circulation published in the municipality. This notice
shall also be posted in a conspicuous place in the city hall for two (2) weeks
prior to the examination. (Ord. 899, 5-17-1997)
2-8-8: REGISTER OF ELIGIBLES:
The board of fire and police commissioners shall prepare and keep a register of
persons whose general average standing, upon examination, is not less than the
minimum fixed by the rules of the board, and who are otherwise eligible. These
persons shall take rank upon the register as candidates in the order of their
relative excellence as determined by examination, subject to the provisions of
the board of fire and police commissioners act and the rules and regulations
promulgated by the board pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 899, 5-17-1997)
2-8-9: PROMOTIONS:
The board, by its rules, shall provide for promotion in the police department
on the basis of ascertained merit and seniority in service and examination, and
shall provide in all cases, where it is practicable, vacancies shall be filled
by promotion. All examinations for promotion shall be competitive among such
members of the next lower rank as desire to submit themselves to examination.
All promotions shall be made from the three (3) having the highest rating. The
rules governing examination for promotion shall be as provided for by the board
in its published rules and regulations. (Ord. 899, 5-17-1997)
2-8-10: TEMPORARY APPOINTMENTS:
In order to prevent a stoppage of public business, to meet extraordinary
emergencies, or to prevent material impairment of the police department, the
board may make temporary appointments, to remain in full force until the
regular appointments may be made under the provisions of this chapter, but
never to exceed sixty (60) days. The provision for temporary appointments
granted to the board shall in no way be deemed to limit or negate the authority
of the mayor, upon the recommendation of the chief of police, to appoint and
hire part time police officers pursuant to the provisions contained in the
Illinois municipal code 1 . (Ord. 899, 5-17-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-21.
2-8-11: DISCHARGE:
No officer or member of the police department of the city of Spring Valley who
has held that position for more than one year prior to the adoption of this
chapter, or who has been appointed under the rules and examination provided for
by this chapter, shall be removed or discharged except for cause, upon written
charges, and after an opportunity to be heard in his own defense. All
provisions relating to the procedure for discharging or reprimanding an officer
or member of the police department shall be as set forth in the board of fire
and police commissioners act 1  and the rules and regulations of the board of
fire and police commissioners duly adopted and promulgated pursuant to the
authority granted by this chapter. (Ord. 899, 5-17-1999)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1-5 – 5/10-2.1-30.
2-8-12: REPORT TO COUNCIL:
At any time requested by the corporate authorities of the city, the board of
fire and police commissioners shall submit to the mayor a report of its
activities and the rules in force and the practical effect thereof. In this
report, the board may make suggestions which the board believes would result in
greater efficiency in the police department. The mayor shall transmit the
report to the council. (Ord. 899, 5-17-1997)
2-8-13: RECORDS:
The board may designate one of its own members to act as secretary or may
appoint the city attorney as acting secretary to the board. The secretary: a)
shall keep the minutes of the board's proceedings, b) shall be custodian of all
papers, pertaining to the business of the board, c) shall keep a record of all
examinations held, and d) shall perform all other duties the board prescribes.
(Ord. 899, 5-17-1997)
2-8-14: FORFEITURE AS MEMBER OF BOARD:
No person holding a lucrative office under the United States, this state or
this municipality shall be a member of the board of fire and police
commissioners. The acceptance of any such lucrative office by a member of the
board shall be treated as a resignation of his office as a member of the board.
Not more than two (2) members of the board shall belong to the same political
party. (Ord. 899, 5-17-1997)
2-8-15: COMPENSATION:
The secretary shall be paid a reasonable compensation for his services, to be
fixed by the council. The council shall also fix the compensation to be paid to
the members of the board, but until the council makes provisions therefor, the
members of the board shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 899, 5-17-1997)
CHAPTER 9
MUNICIPAL BAND
SECTION:
2-9-1: Creation
2-9-2: Appropriation For Levy
2-9-3: Council To Have Full Power
2-9-4: Concerts
2-9-5: Band Officers And Finances
2-9-6: Records And Reports
2-9-1: CREATION:
There is hereby established and created a municipal band, which said group
shall continue to provide musical entertainment in accordance with the
provisions and intent of the statutes of the state of Illinois. (1972 Code)
2-9-2: APPROPRIATION FOR LEVY:
The council shall annually appropriate and levy such sums as may be necessary
and proper for the maintenance of such municipal band. (1972 Code)
2-9-3: COUNCIL TO HAVE FULL POWER:
The council shall have full power, jurisdiction and authority with reference to
the employment of such band, including compensation to be paid such band, the
designation of the place or places within said city at which such band shall
furnish music as aforesaid, the number of concerts to be given, or occasions
upon which such band shall be employed, and the matter of arrangement of any
and all details necessary in connection with the employment of such band, and
the payment of compensation therefor. (1972 Code)
2-9-4: CONCERTS:
The council shall be the sole judge as to the number of concerts to be given
annually, the date of commencement and close of the season for the holding of
outdoor concerts; all of which shall be as nearly as possible in conformity
with the practice adhered within the city in the past for the holding of such
band concerts. (1972 Code)
2-9-5: BAND OFFICERS AND FINANCES:
The members of the municipal band shall, from time to time, elect officers from
within said membership for the purpose of managing the municipal band, and the
officers thus elected shall have charge of the expenditures from the band fund,
and warrants on this fund shall be honored only upon proper presentation to the
council. (1972 Code)
2-9-6: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
The officers of the municipal band shall keep a record of its proceedings, and
shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations as may be necessary for
the guidance of said band. The officers shall annually and within thirty (30)
days from the close of the fiscal year, make a report to the council of the
condition of said band and the activities during the preceding fiscal year.
(1972 Code)
CHAPTER 10
BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
2-10-1: Appointments
2-10-2: General Duties
2-10-3: Meeting Dates
2-10-1: APPOINTMENTS:
There is hereby established the board of local improvements for the city, which
shall consist of the mayor and members of the council. (1972 Code)
2-10-2: GENERAL DUTIES:
The board of local improvements shall have the powers and perform the duties
assigned to it by statute or ordinance. (1972 Code)
2-10-3: MEETING DATES:
The board of local improvements shall meet on the second Monday of January,
April, July and October at seven thirty o'clock (7:30) P.M. If the regular
meeting date falls on a holiday or if there is no quorum present, the board of
local improvements shall meet on the next secular day. Provided that a special
meeting may be called by the mayor in the manner provided for calling special
meetings of the city council. (1972 Code)
CHAPTER 11
INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-11-1: Definitions
2-11-2: Creation Of Industrial Development Commission Of The City
2-11-3: Commission Membership, General
2-11-4: Powers Of The Industrial Development Commission Of The City
2-11-5: Investment Of Funds
2-11-6: Exemption From Construction And Bidding Requirements For Public
Buildings
2-11-7: Powers Conferred As Additional And Supplemental; Limitations Imposed;
Effect
2-11-8: Pecuniary Interest Of Members Or Employees Of The Commission;
Prohibition; Disclosure
2-11-9: Severability Clause
2-11-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms wherever used or referred to in this chapter shall have the
following meanings unless in any case a different meaning appears from the
context:
CITY: The city of Spring Valley.
COMMISSION: The industrial development commission of the city of Spring Valley.
DEVELOPMENT PROJECT OR PROJECT: Any building or facility or any area,
industrial park or portion thereof, or combination or part thereof occupied or
utilized by an industrial, manufacturing, or business enterprise located within
or partially within the municipality, or plan to so occupy or utilize now
existing or hereafter acquired or constructed by the commission pursuant to the
terms of this act, including any or all buildings, improvements, additions,
extensions, replacements, appurtenances, lands, machinery, equipment,
furnishing, landscaping, utilities, railroad spurs and sidings, wharfs,
approaches and roadways necessary or desirable in connection therewith or
incidental thereto.
GOVERNMENT: The United States Of America or instrumentality thereof.
PROJECT COSTS: The sum total of all reasonable or necessary costs incidental to
the acquisition, construction, reconstruction, repair, improvement and
extension of a project including, without limitation, the cost of studies and
surveys, plans, specifications, architectural and engineering services, legal,
marketing or other special services, financing, acquisition, demolition,
construction, equipment and site development of new and rehabilitated
buildings, rehabilitation, reconstruction, repair or remodeling of existing
buildings and all other necessary or incidental expenses whether directly or
indirectly related to the project.
PROJECT SITE DESIGNATION: Project area and site plan.
SITE PLAN: Proposed planned development or planned conservation project. (Ord.
709, 2-5-1990)
2-11-2: CREATION OF INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION OF THE CITY:
There is hereby created a body politic and corporate to be known as the
industrial development commission of the city. The commission is constituted a
public instrumentality of the city and the exercise by the commission of the
powers conferred by this chapter shall be deemed and held to be the performance
of an essential public function. (Ord. 709, 2-5-1990)
2-11-3: COMMISSION MEMBERSHIP, GENERAL:
   (A)   The mayor, with the approval of the city council, shall appoint the
members of the industrial development commission, whose terms of office shall
commence from the date of appointment.
   (B)   The commission shall consist of five (5) members.
   (C)   On creation of the commission, initial appointments to the commission
shall be as follows: two (2) members for two (2) year terms; two (2) members
for three (3) year terms; one member for a four (4) year term. Thereafter,
whenever a vacancy occurs by reason of the expiration of the term of any
member, the mayor, with the approval of the city council, shall appoint a
member to the commission for a term of three (3) years.
   (D)   Members of the commission shall hold office until their successors are
appointed and may serve more than one successive term.
   (E)   Whenever a vacancy on the commission shall occur as a result of
resignation, death, or any other reason other than expiration of the term of a
member, the mayor, with the approval of the city council, shall appoint a
member to complete the term of vacancy.
   (F)   Members of the commission shall receive no compensation for their
services.
   (G)   Removal from the commission by the mayor shall be for cause and only
with the concurrence of the city council.
   (H)   The commission shall determine bylaws consistent with the purposes of
this chapter subject to approval of the city council. (Ord. 709, 2-5-1990)
2-11-4: POWERS OF THE INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION OF THE CITY:
The commission may exercise the following powers under this chapter provided,
however, that in no event shall the commission encumber city funds or incur
city debt or liability without prior city council approval; or take any final
action under the provisions of the following subsections without approval of
the city council.
   (A)   To construct, acquire by gift, lease or purchase, reconstruct,
improve, better or extend, or to finance the construction acquisition,
reconstruction, improvement, betterment, or extension of any industrial project
within or without the municipality or partially within or partially without the
municipality, but in no event further than ten (10) miles from the territorial
boundaries of such municipality, and to acquire by gift, lease or purchase
lands or rights in land in connection therewith.
   (B)   To rent, lease, sell or otherwise dispose of such industrial project.
   (C)   To enter into agreements or contracts with any individual,
association, foundation, developer, private corporation, governmental agencies,
or any form of joint ownership or venture or any type of real estate agreement
containing covenants, restrictions and conditions regarding the use of such
property for industrial and commercial and related purposes, in accordance with
the planned project and such other covenants, restrictions and conditions as
the commission may deem necessary to effectuate the purposes of this chapter.
   (D)   To make any of the covenants, restrictions and conditions of the
foregoing contracts, covenants running with the land, and to provide
appropriate remedies for any breach of any such covenants or conditions,
including the right in the commission to terminate such contracts and any
interest in the property created pursuant thereto.
   (E)   To apply for and accept advances, grants, contributions and any other
form of financial assistance from the federal government, the state, county,
city or other public body or from any sources, public or private, for the
purposes of this law, and to enter into and carry out contracts in connection
therewith.
   (F)   The commission, notwithstanding the provisions of any other ordinance,
may include in any contract for financial assistance with the federal
government for a project such conditions imposed pursuant to federal law as the
commission may deem reasonable and appropriate and which are not inconsistent
with the purpose of this chapter.
   (G)   To propose and to assist in the preparation of, designation of, or
plans for economic development projects and to assist in the undertaking and
carrying out of projects for economic development.
   (H)   To do all acts and things necessary or convenient for the promotion of
its businesses and the general welfare of the commission; to carry out the
powers granted to it by this chapter or any other ordinance.
   (I)   In all of the above, the departments and instrumentalities of the city
are directed to cooperate with the commission consistent with their
responsibilities under law, the general public interest, and the purposes of
this chapter. (Ord. 709, 2-5-1990)
2-11-5: INVESTMENT OF FUNDS:
The commission, without further city council approval, may invest any funds
held by it pursuant to this chapter in accordance with the provisions set forth
in the investment of public funds act, 30 Illinois Compiled Statutes 235/1 et
seq. (Ord. 709, 2-5-1990)
2-11-6: EXEMPTION FROM CONSTRUCTION AND BIDDING REQUIREMENTS FOR PUBLIC
BUILDINGS:
The acquisition and construction of a project shall not be subject to any
requirements relating to public buildings, structures, grounds, works or
improvements imposed by the Illinois Revised Statutes or any other similar
requirements which may be lawfully waived by this section and any requirements
of competitive bidding or restriction imposed on the procedure for award of
contracts for such purpose or for the lease, sale or other disposition of
property of the commission is not applicable to any action taken under
authority of this chapter. (Ord. 709, 2-5-1990)
2-11-7: POWERS CONFERRED AS ADDITIONAL AND SUPPLEMENTAL; LIMITATIONS IMPOSED;
EFFECT:
The powers conferred by this chapter are in addition and supplemental to, and
the limitations imposed by this chapter shall not affect the powers conferred
by law or any other ordinance. Projects may be acquired, purchased,
constructed, reconstructed, improved, bettered, equipped and extended,
notwithstanding that any law or any other ordinance may provide for the
acquisition, purchase, construction, reconstruction, improvement, equipping,
betterment and extension of a like project; and without regard to the
requirements, restrictions, limitations or other provisions contained in any
law or any other ordinance. (Ord. 709, 2-5-1990)
2-11-8: PECUNIARY INTEREST OF MEMBERS OR EMPLOYEES OF THE COMMISSION;
PROHIBITION; DISCLOSURE:
   (A)   Any member of the commission who owns or controls any interest direct
or indirect in any property included in any industrial development commission
project shall disclose the same in writing to the commission and such
disclosure shall be entered upon the minutes book of the commission.
   (B)   No member of the commission shall vote or act on any project in which
said member holds an interest.
   (C)   No employee of the commission shall acquire any interest, direct or
indirect, in any industrial development commission project or in any property
included or planned to be included in any industrial development commission
project.
   (D)   If the city council of the city determines that any commission member
has acquired an interest that is adverse to the best interests of the city, the
city council may require said member to divest himself of said property or
interest, or take what other steps are necessary to assure compliance with this
section.
   (E)   In the event of a conflict between the provisions of this chapter or
in the event that a matter not covered by this chapter shall arise, the
provisions regarding conflicts of interest as set forth in 50 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 105/3 et seq., shall control. (Ord. 709, 2-5-1990)
2-11-9: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
The provisions of this chapter are severable and if any of its provisions or
any sentence, clause or paragraph shall be held unconstitutional by any court,
of competent jurisdiction, the decisions of such court shall not affect or
impair any of the remaining provisions. (Ord. 709, 2-5-1990)

2-12-2: Rules And Regulations
2-12-3: Rate Of Tax Or License

(Ord. 1651, 11-21-2016)
