TITLE 3
BUILDING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
BUILDING INSPECTOR
SECTION:
3-1-1: Appointments
3-1-2: Building Inspector Duties
3-1-3: Fire Marshal Duties
3-1-4: Building Inspector Qualifications
3-1-5: Fire Marshal Qualifications
3-1-6: Ex Officio Electrical Official
3-1-7: Ex Officio Housing Official
3-1-8: Ex Officio Building Official
3-1-9: Stop Order
3-1-10: Entry Powers
3-1-11: Penalty
3-1-12: Copies Of Permits To Assessors
3-1-13: Deputy Building Inspector
3-1-14: Commercial Building Inspection Program
3-1-15: Refuse Dumpsters For Construction Projects
3-1-1: APPOINTMENTS:
   (A)   Building Inspector: There is hereby created the position of building
inspector who shall be appointed by the Mayor by and with the advice and
consent of the Council.
   (B)   Fire Marshal: There is hereby created the position of Fire Marshal who
shall be appointed by the Mayor by and with the advice and consent of the
Council. (Ord. 1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-2: BUILDING INSPECTOR DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the building inspector to see to the enforcement of all
ordinance provisions relating to building or zoning, to inspect all buildings
or structures being constructed, repaired or altered as frequently as may be
necessary to insure compliance with all Spring Valley City ordinances and
Building Codes adopted by the City of Spring Valley, and to discharge any other
duties assigned to the building inspector by the Mayor of the City of Spring
Valley with the consent of the Spring Valley City Council. The building
inspector shall perform the following duties which are intended to be examples
of, but not an exclusive list of the building inspector's duties: (Ord. 1738,
1-28-2019)
   (A)   Enforces City's zoning ordinance and all adopted Building Codes,
including Plumbing, Electrical, and Engineering Codes.
   (B)   Review all building and zoning requests in the City of Spring Valley.
   (C)   Respond to inquiries and confirm compliance for a proposed or existing
use of site.
   (D)   Responsible for issuing all building and demolition permits.
   (E)   Responsible for the enforcement of other City ordinances, such as
inspection of vacant buildings, inspection of residential rental property,
inspection of signs and inspection of demolition projects.
   (F)   Acts as a liaison to the City Engineer, Spring Valley Plan Commission,
Spring Valley Board of Zoning Appeals, and Spring Valley City Attorney.
   (G)   Prepares monthly and annual reports to City Council pertaining to
building activities that include number of permits issued, to whom they were
issued, the amount of fees collected and the estimated value of the project.
Prepares monthly reports to the City Council pertaining to building inspections
conducted by the building inspector which include the date of the inspection,
the owner of the property, the location of the property and any defects noted
during the inspection. Provides a monthly report to the City Council listing
all deficiency notifications issued by the building inspector, including the
name of the property owner to whom the deficiency notice was sent, the address
for the property and a description of the deficiency.
   (H)   Maintains a daily activity log for all fees associated with specific
types of building permits.
   (I)   Coordinates inspection services as needed.
   (J)   Reviews plan and document submittals required for building permits.
   (K)   Responsible for the review of the International Building Code,
International Mechanical Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas
Code, National Electric Code, International Energy Conservation Code, Illinois
State Plumbing Code, and Illinois Accessibility Code for the necessary
upgrades. Provides recommendation to the City Engineer, the Spring Valley Plan
Commission and the Spring Valley Board of Zoning Appeals, prior to Spring
Valley City Council approval.
   (L)   Performs various office duties including filing, record keeping,
report writing and data entry as it relates to the building inspector's duties.
   (M)   Handle all of the duties of the Zoning Administrator as defined in
subsection
14-10-2(B) of this Code.
   (N)   Is responsible for conducting all inspections required pursuant to the
Spring Valley, Illinois residential rental property nuisance prevention
ordinance. (Ord. 1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-3: FIRE MARSHAL DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the Fire Marshal to perform responsible management,
technical and administrative work in developing, implementing and managing a
comprehensive fire prevention and loss management program. The position shall
be a part time position with compensation of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per
month. The Fire Marshal position is not under the jurisdiction of the Fire
Department. The Fire Marshal shall perform the following duties which are
intended to be examples of, but not an exhaustive list of, the Fire Marshal's
duties:
   (A)   Code interpretation, assistance to building inspector and City
Engineer as requested.
   (B)   Code review and recommendation:
      1.   Review and evaluate code updates and fire safety conditions, and
State Fire Marshal directives as they are disseminated, considering Federal,
State and local codes applicable to fire safety, and make recommendations to
policies, procedures and ordinances. Recommend changes to City codes that will
be affected, furnish information regarding code updates to City officials,
Building Inspector, City Attorney, Fire Chief and Fire Department Training
Officer.
      2.   Assist the Fire Department and other City departments with ISO
documentation when requested.
      3.   Maintain library of applicable code, and fire prevention and loss
management documentation as it pertains to the Fire Marshal position.
Participate in webinars updating various codes affecting building construction,
fire safety and fire suppression.
   (C)   Plan review for compliance with Fire Codes:
      1.   Perform comprehensive review of plan documents, and assist other
City departments when meeting with architects, engineers, contractors, other
building and development related persons to review and discuss construction
activities and City loss management programs for all development and remodeling
projects.
      2.   Conduct field inspections of construction projects related to fire
and life safety issues in conjunction with the building inspector and the City
Engineer.
      3.   Review and sign off on sprinkler system plans, and witness final
sprinkler system tests. Provide information, test results, location of system
components to the Fire Department.
      4.   When requested by the Fire Chief, review incident reports for
guidance in code review when a code violation or violations are involved in a
fire event.
   (D)   Other duties:
      1.   Assist with flow testing of water mains when requested for fire
flows required and building sprinkler applications in conjunction with the City
Engineer and the City Public Works Superintendent. Determine fire flow required
for new systems with sprinkler contractor and installer.
      2.   Attend safety seminars and hazard review meetings to obtain current
information as required. Subscribe to publications related to fire prevention
and safety of the public and fire responders.
      3.   Maintain log of activities and present to City Council on regular
basis.
      4.   Assist in training of other personnel in fire prevention and related
technical areas as related to Fire Marshal position.
      5.   Assist State Fire Marshal or Fire Chief, when requested, with items
including, but not limited to: determining cause of origin, cause and loss
value of fire incidents, collection of evidence and participate in prosecution
activities.
      6.   Provide code compliance information to contractors, job managers and
builders.
      7.   Assist Fire Department with building information and perform
preplans.
      8.   Provide special training when requested to first responders. (Ord.
1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-4: BUILDING INSPECTOR QUALIFICATIONS:
The building inspector shall have the following qualifications:
   (A)   Have knowledge of the basic principles and techniques of structural
building inspection, permit process and Building Codes.
   (B)   Have the ability to analyze and interpret building plans and
specifications for compliance with other applicable laws.
   (C)   Have the ability to apply codes and ordinances in making zoning and
building decision.
   (D)   Have the ability to work well with engineers, architects, contractors
and the general public.
   (E)   Possess an Associate's Degree in engineering science, construction
management, or a related trade school, or equivalent construction experience.
   (F)   Have experience with plumbing, electrical, framing, and foundation
inspections. (Ord. 1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-5: FIRE MARSHAL QUALIFICATIONS:
The Fire Marshal shall have knowledge of the principles, methods, and practices
of fire loss prevention management, applicable Federal, State and local codes,
Spring Valley ordinances and regulations. The Fire Marshal shall also have
knowledge of the mechanical, chemical, and related characteristics for a wide
variety of flammable and explosive materials and objects. The Fire Marshal
shall also have the following job related qualifications.
   (A)   Plan, organize, and participate in comprehensive fire prevention and
loss management programs.
   (B)   Develop, revise and assure compliance with fire loss management
policies and procedures.
   (C)   Maintain accurate and thorough records, files and reference materials.
   (D)   Read and interpret construction plans and specifications.
   (E)   Establish and maintain effective and cooperative working relationships
with various City departments, citizens and professional contacts.
   (F)   Supervise and train new personnel for the Fire Marshal position.
   (G)   The Fire Marshal shall possess any combination of equivalent education
and experience that could likely provide the required knowledge, skills and
abilities including, but not limited to:
      1.   Education: An Associate's Degree or equivalent in fire science or
closely related field is strongly recommended, but not required. In lieu of an
Associate's Degree or equivalent in fire science, the Fire Marshal shall have
sufficient professional experience in fire science through employment or
volunteer activities.
      2.   Experience: Five (5) years' experience involving suppression and
prevention activities and the inspection of structures for conformance to fire
safety standards and systems, including supervisory experience, and building
trade experience and affiliations.
      3.   Licenses, Certifications, Registrations:
         (a)   Licenses: Possession of a valid Illinois driver's license.
         (b)   Certificates: Certification as a State Fire Prevention Officer.
(Ord. 1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-6: EX OFFICIO ELECTRICAL OFFICIAL:
The building inspector shall act as electrical official and shall have all
powers and duties necessary for enforcement of the Electrical Code. (1972 Code;
amd. Ord. 1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-7: EX OFFICIO HOUSING OFFICIAL:
The building inspector shall act as housing official and shall have all powers
and duties necessary for enforcement of the Housing Code. (1972 Code; amd. Ord.
1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-8: EX OFFICIO BUILDING OFFICIAL:
The building inspector shall act as building official and have all powers and
duties necessary for enforcement of the Building Code. (1972 Code; amd. Ord.
1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-9: STOP ORDER:
The building inspector shall have the power to order all work stopped on
construction, alteration or repair of buildings in the City when such work is
being done in violation of any provision of any ordinance relating thereto or
in violation of the land development provisions of this Code. Work shall not be
resumed after the issuance of such an order except on the written permission of
the building inspector; provided, however, that if the stop order is an oral
one, it shall be followed by a written stop order within an hour. Such stop
order may be served by any policeman. (1972 Code; amd. Ord. 1379, 6-9-2008;
Ord. 1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-10: ENTRY POWERS:
The building inspector shall have the power to make or cause to be made an
entry into any building or premises where work of altering, repairing or
constructing of any building or structure is going on for the purpose of making
inspections at any reasonable hour. (1972 Code; amd. Ord. 1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-11: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall continue work in violation of a stop
order of the building inspector shall be fined not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each day on
which any work in violation of such stop order is done. (1972 Code; amd. Ord.
1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-12: COPIES OF PERMITS TO ASSESSORS:
In addition to all other duties the building inspector shall forward to the
Township Assessor and County Assessor a copy of each building permit issued
within fifteen (15) days of such issuance. Each such copy shall show the legal
description of the lot or area concerned, and the real estate index number, if
any. (1972 Code; amd. Ord. 1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-13: DEPUTY BUILDING INSPECTOR:
The Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Council, may appoint a deputy
building inspector to assist the building inspector if necessary for the proper
enforcement of the provisions of this Code. The deputy building inspector shall
have the same authority as the building inspector as set forth in this chapter.
(1972 Code; amd. Ord. 1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-14: COMMERCIAL BUILDING INSPECTION PROGRAM:
   (A)   The building inspector shall be required to conduct periodic
inspections of all commercial buildings and all buildings located within a
commercial district as defined under the Spring Valley Land Development Code in
order to verify that all buildings comply with the Spring Valley Building Code,
the Electrical Code, the Plumbing Code and the Housing Code. The inspections
called for under the provisions of this section shall be performed on a
periodic basis as determined by the building inspector. However, the
inspections called for under the provisions of this section shall be performed
not less frequently than once every two (2) years. At the conclusion of the
inspection, the building inspector shall notify the property owner, in writing,
of any violations of the Building Code, Electrical Code, Plumbing Code or
Housing Code disclosed by said inspection. The property owner or any other
individual or entity legally responsible for correcting any Building Code,
Electrical Code, Plumbing Code, or Housing Code violations shall have thirty
(30) days from the date of the building inspector's notice of code violations
to correct any code violations noted by the building inspector. (Ord. 1564, 3-
31-2014; amd. Ord. 1705, 11-20-2017)
   (B)   The building inspector shall provide the property owner with a written
notice notifying the property owner of the date and time when the building
inspector will conduct the inspection called for under the provisions of this
section. The building inspector shall provide this notice of the date and time
of the inspection to the property owner at least ten (10) days prior to the
date set for the inspection. If the property owner refuses to allow the
building inspector entry to the property in order for the building inspector to
complete the inspection called for under the provisions of this section, the
building inspector shall report the property owner's action to the City
Attorney and the City Attorney shall be directed to file a lawsuit in the
Circuit Court of Bureau County in order to obtain a court order authorizing the
building inspector to enter into the building and conduct the inspection called
for under this section.
   (C)   Any building owner or other individual or entity legally responsible
for correcting any code violations noted by the building inspector in his
written report who refuses to correct the code violations within the timetables
set forth in this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and said refusal
to correct the code violations shall be deemed to be a public nuisance. The
City Council may direct the City Attorney to file a lawsuit in the Circuit
Court of Bureau County seeking to compel the building owner or individual or
legal entity responsible for correcting the code violations to take whatever
action is necessary to correct the code violations and abate said nuisance.
(Ord. 821, 7-5-1994; amd. Ord. 1705, 11-20-2017)
3-1-15: REFUSE DUMPSTERS FOR CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS:
The building inspector shall have the authority to require contractors to
purchase a dumpster to dispose of construction debris on any construction
project within the corporate limits of the City of Spring Valley. The building
inspector shall have the discretion to either demand that a contractor purchase
a dumpster or waive the requirement that a contractor purchase a dumpster,
depending upon the following factors: a) the size of the construction project;
b) the anticipated debris to be generated in conjunction with the construction
project; c) the anticipated cost of the construction project; and d) assurances
from the contractor that construction debris will be disposed of by the
contractor in a manner in accordance with the rules promulgated by the State of
Illinois through the Environmental Protection Agency, and the ordinances
adopted by the City of Spring Valley. Any decision by the building inspector to
waive the requirement that a contractor purchase a dumpster must be in writing.
(Ord. 1705, 11-20-2017)
CHAPTER 2
BUILDING CODE; MECHANICAL CODE; EXISTING BUILDING CODE
SECTION:
3-2-1: Adoption
3-2-2: Establishment Of Office Of Building Official
3-2-3: Duties Of Building Official
3-2-4: Right Of Entry
3-2-5: Definitions
3-2-6: Fire Limits Established
3-2-7: Savings Clause
3-2-8: Validity
3-2-9: Penalties
3-2-10: Swimming Pool Fences
3-2-1: ADOPTION:
   (A)   There is hereby adopted by the city of Spring Valley for the purpose
of establishing rules and regulations for the construction, alteration,
removal, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy, location and maintenance of
buildings and structures, including permits and penalties, that certain
building code known as the international building code, latest edition,
including any amendments, deletions or additions thereto incorporated into said
international building code after the passage of the ordinance codified herein
or any revisions or subsequent modifications thereof made after the passage of
the ordinance codified herein. If the international building code or any other
code adopted by the city of Spring Valley allows for more than one option for
construction or design, the most restrictive option shall apply, unless
permission to deviate from the most restrictive option is granted to the
applicant by the Spring Valley city council, after review and recommendation by
the Spring Valley city engineer, the Spring Valley building inspector or the
Spring Valley fire chief, as appropriate.
   (B)   There is hereby adopted by the city of Spring Valley for the purpose
of establishing rules and regulations for mechanical equipment used in building
construction, alteration, removal, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy,
location and maintenance, including permits and penalties, that certain
mechanical code known as the international mechanical code, latest edition,
including any amendments, deletions or additions thereto incorporated into said
international mechanical code after the passage of the ordinance codified
herein or any revisions or subsequent modifications thereof made after the
passage of the ordinance codified herein. If the international mechanical code
allows for more than one option for construction or design, the most
restrictive option shall apply, unless permission to deviate from the most
restrictive option is granted to the applicant by the Spring Valley city
council, after review and recommendation by the Spring Valley city engineer,
the Spring Valley building inspector or the Spring Valley fire chief, as
appropriate. (Ord. 1408, 2-2-2009)
   (C)   There is hereby adopted by the city of Spring Valley for the purpose
of establishing rules and regulations for the construction, alteration,
removal, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy, location, and maintenance of
buildings and structures, including permits and penalties, that certain
building code known as the 2012 international existing building code, latest
edition, including any amendments, deletions, or additions thereto incorporated
into said international existing building code after the passage of the
ordinance codified herein or any revisions or subsequent modifications thereof
made after the passage of the ordinance codified herein. If the 2012
international existing building code adopted by the city of Spring Valley
allows for more than one option for existing construction or existing design,
the most restrictive option shall apply, unless permission to deviate from the
most restrictive option is granted to the applicant by the Spring Valley city
council, after review and recommendation by the Spring Valley city engineer,
the Spring Valley building inspector or the Spring Valley fire chief as
appropriate. (Ord. 1562, 3-17-2014)
3-2-2: ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE OF BUILDING OFFICIAL:
   (A)   The office of building official is hereby created and the executive
official in charge shall be known as the building official.
   (B)   The building official shall be appointed by the mayor of the city
subject to approval of the council. His appointment shall continue during good
behavior and satisfactory service. He shall not be removed from office except
for cause after full opportunity has been given him to be heard on specific
charges.
   (C)   During temporary absence or disability of the building official the
appointing authority shall designate an acting building official. (1972 Code)
3-2-3: DUTIES OF BUILDING OFFICIAL:
It shall be the duty of the building official to enforce all laws relating to
the construction, alteration, removal and demolition of buildings and
structures. (1972 Code)
3-2-4: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
The building official, in the discharge of his official duties, and upon proper
identification, shall have authority to enter any building, structure or
premises at any reasonable hour. (1972 Code)
3-2-5: DEFINITIONS:
   (A)   Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the building code, it
shall be held to mean the city of Spring Valley, Illinois.
   (B)   Wherever the term "corporation counsel" is used in the building code,
it shall be held to mean the attorney for the city.
   (C)   Wherever the term "building official" is used in the building code, it
shall be held to mean the building inspector of the city of Spring Valley.
(1972 Code)
3-2-6: FIRE LIMITS ESTABLISHED:
The fire limits of the city are as heretofore defined in an ordinance of the
city adopted April 12, 1895, as amended, defining the fire limits of the city.
In addition thereto, all parts of the city zoned B1, downtown commercial
district; B2, community retail and service district; B3, professional services
district; and B4, general commercial district, are hereby designated to be the
fire limits of the city of Spring Valley. (Ord. 1408, 2-2-2009)
3-2-7: SAVINGS CLAUSE:
Nothing in this chapter or in the codes hereby adopted shall be construed to
affect any suit or proceeding now pending in any court, or any rights acquired,
or liability incurred, nor any cause or causes of action accrued or existing,
under any act or ordinance, repealed hereby. Nor shall any right or remedy of
any character be lost, impaired or affected by this chapter. (1972 Code)
3-2-8: VALIDITY:
The invalidity of any section or provision of this chapter or of the codes
hereby adopted shall not invalidate other sections or provisions thereof. (1972
Code)
3-2-9: PENALTIES:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the codes hereby adopted
or fail to comply therewith, or who violate or fail to comply with any order
made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of
specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate
or permit issued thereunder and from which no appeal has been taken, or who
shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the court of
competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each
and every such violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a
misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and
not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). The imposition of one penalty for
any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all
such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects
within a reasonable time; and when not otherwise specified, each ten (10) days
that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense.
The application of the foregoing penalty shall not be held to prevent the
enforced removal of prohibited conditions. (1972 Code)
3-2-10: SWIMMING POOL FENCES:
   (A)   It shall be the duty of all property owners to erect a fence around
their inground or aboveground swimming pools. The fence required by this
section shall be of sufficient size and construction material so as to prevent
a person from accidentally coming into contact with the swimming pool. At a
minimum, the fence shall be at least forty two inches (42") in height and
constructed of a material sufficient to prevent a person from accidentally
coming into contact with the swimming pool.
   (B)   Any resident of the city of Spring Valley owning an aboveground
swimming pool may obtain a waiver from the fence requirement contained herein,
if the owner of the aboveground swimming pool can demonstrate to the Spring
Valley building inspector that the size of the aboveground swimming pool and
location of the aboveground swimming pool makes it unnecessary to erect a fence
for the protection of the public. (Ord. 1273, 8-21-2006)
CHAPTER 3
ELECTRICAL CODE
SECTION:
3-3-1: Adoption Of Electrical Code
3-3-2: Establishment Of Office Of Electrical Official
3-3-3: Duties Of Electrical Official
3-3-4: Right Of Entry
3-3-5: Definition
3-3-6: Savings Clause
3-3-7: Validity
3-3-8: Penalties
3-3-9: Ground Rod Requirements For Residential Electric Service
3-3-1: ADOPTION OF ELECTRICAL CODE:
There is hereby adopted by the city of Spring Valley for the purpose of
safeguarding of persons and of buildings and their contents from hazards
arising from the use of electricity for light, heat, power, radio, signaling
and for other purposes, including permits and penalties, that certain
electrical code recommended by the National Fire Protection Association, being
particularly the NFPA, national electrical code, latest edition, including any
amendments, deletions or additions thereto incorporated into said NFPA,
national electrical code, after the passage of the ordinance codified herein or
any revisions or subsequent modifications thereof made after the passage of the
ordinance codified herein. If the NFPA, national electrical code, allows for
more than one option for construction or design, the most restrictive option
shall apply, unless permission to deviate from the most restrictive option is
granted to the applicant by the Spring Valley city council, after review and
recommendation by the Spring Valley city engineer, the Spring Valley building
inspector or the Spring Valley fire chief, as appropriate.
Notwithstanding any provisions to the contrary contained in the NFPA, national
electrical code, it shall be unlawful to use PVC (plastic conduit) for service
entrance installations running from the outside power meter to the main
electrical disconnect located within the building for the supply of electrical
power to any structure within the corporate limits of the city. The use of PVC
(plastic conduit) for conduit installed throughout the structure from the main
electrical disconnect to the various power outlets shall be as provided for in
the NFPA, national electrical code, latest edition. (Ord. 1408, 2-2-2009)
It shall be unlawful to use aluminum conductors for any branch or feeder
circuits on the load side of the main switchgear or on the load side of the
main panel board or distribution box. (Ord. 1440, 11-23-2009)
3-3-2: ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE OF ELECTRICAL OFFICIAL:
The building inspector of the city shall be ex officio electrical official in
charge of enforcement of the code. During his temporary absence or disability,
the mayor shall designate an acting building inspector or ex officio electrical
official to enforce the code. (1972 Code)
3-3-3: DUTIES OF ELECTRICAL OFFICIAL:
It shall be the duty of the electrical official to enforce all laws relating to
the installation of electrical conductors and equipment as provided herein.
The electrical official of the city shall certify that the structure in
question has been constructed in accordance with the national electrical code
by placing a tag on the line located adjacent to the meter supplied by the
electrical utility outside the structure. The tag which the electrical official
places on the electric line shall authorize the public utility supplying
electric power to the structure that power can be supplied to the structure in
accordance with the national electrical code; failure by the property owner to
display such a tag on the electrical line shall prohibit the public utility
supplying electrical service to the structure from connecting the structure to
the main electrical lines of the public utility. (Ord. 759, 1-20-1992)
3-3-4: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
The electrical inspector, in the discharge of his official duties, and upon
proper identification, shall have authority to enter any building, structure or
premises at any reasonable hour. (1972 Code)
3-3-5: DEFINITION:
Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the electrical code, it shall be
held to mean the city of Spring Valley, Illinois. (1972 Code)
3-3-6: SAVINGS CLAUSE:
Nothing in this chapter or in the code hereby adopted shall be construed to
affect any suit or proceeding now pending in any court, or any rights acquired,
or liability incurred, nor any cause or causes of action accrued or existing,
under any act or ordinance, repealed hereby. Nor shall any right or remedy of
any character be lost, impaired or affected by this chapter. (1972 Code)
3-3-7: VALIDITY:
The invalidity of any section or provision of this chapter or of the code
hereby adopted shall not invalidate other sections or provisions thereof. (1972
Code)
3-3-8: PENALTIES:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the code hereby adopted
or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any
order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed
statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any
certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been
taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified
by the court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall
severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively, be
guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). The imposition of
one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to
continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such
violations or defects within a reasonable time; and when not otherwise
specified, each ten (10) days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall
constitute a separate offense. The application of the foregoing penalty shall
not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. (1972
Code)
3-3-9: GROUND ROD REQUIREMENTS FOR RESIDENTIAL ELECTRIC SERVICE:
Pursuant to the authority granted to the City of Spring Valley by the National
Fire Protection Association, National Electrical Code, the City of Spring
Valley hereby elects to require two ground rods for all residential electrical
service connections within the corporate limits of the City of Spring Valley.
After the adoption of this section, neither the Spring Valley Building
Inspector nor the Spring Valley Electrical Inspector shall sign off on any
electrical inspection for residential electrical service which does not include
two ground rods as required by this chapter. (Ord. 1773, 2-24-2020)
CHAPTER 4

3-4-1: ADOPTION OF PLUMBING CODE:
There is hereby adopted by the City of Spring Valley for the purposes of
establishing rules and regulations for control of fixtures, materials, design
and installation of plumbing systems, including permits and penalties, that
certain Plumbing Code known as the Illinois Plumbing Code, latest edition,
including any amendments, deletions or additions thereto incorporated into the
Illinois Plumbing Code after the passage of the ordinance codified herein or
any revisions or subsequent modifications thereof made after the passage of the
ordinance codified herein. If the Illinois Plumbing Code allows for more than
one option for construction or design, the most restrictive option shall apply,
unless permission to deviate from the most restrictive option is granted to the
applicant by the Spring Valley City Council, after review and recommendation by
the Spring Valley City Engineer, Spring Valley Building Inspector or the Spring
Valley Fire Chief, as appropriate. (Ord. 1408, 2-2-2009)
3-4-2: PLUMBING INSPECTOR:
There is hereby created the position of plumbing inspector who shall be
appointed by the Mayor by and with the advice and consent of the Council. The
appointee must be a plumber licensed and in good standing in the State of
Illinois. The Mayor by and with the advice and consent of the Council shall
designate an ex officio plumbing inspector to act in the temporary absence or
disability of the plumbing inspector. The appointee must also be a plumber
licensed and in good standing in the State of Illinois. The City of Spring
Valley shall pay the plumbing inspector up to the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00)
for each inspection performed by the Spring Valley plumbing inspector. (Ord.
1665, 2-13-2017)
3-4-3: DUTIES OF PLUMBING OFFICIAL:
It shall be the duty of the plumbing official to enforce all laws relating to
the installation of plumbing systems as herein stated. (1972 Code)
3-4-4: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
The plumbing official, in the discharge of his official duties, and upon proper
identification, shall have authority to enter any building, structure or
premises at any reasonable hour. (1972 Code)
3-4-5: DEFINITION:
Wherever the word "Municipality" is used in the Plumbing Code, it shall be held
to mean the City of Spring Valley, Illinois. (1972 Code)
3-4-6: VALIDITY:
The invalidity of any section or provision of this chapter or of the code
hereby adopted shall not invalidate other sections or provisions thereof. (1972
Code)
3-4-7: SAVINGS CLAUSE:
Nothing in this chapter or in the code hereby adopted shall be construed to
affect any suit or proceeding now pending in any court, or any rights acquired,
or liability incurred, nor any cause or causes of action accrued or existing,
under any act or ordinance, repealed hereby. Nor shall any right or remedy of
any character be lost, impaired or affected by this chapter. (1972 Code)
3-4-8: PENALTIES:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the code hereby adopted
or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any
order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed
statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any
certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been
taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified
by the court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall
severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively, be
guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). The imposition of
one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to
continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such
violations or defects within a reasonable time; and when not otherwise
specified, each ten (10) days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall
constitute a separate offense. The application of the foregoing penalty shall
not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. (1972
Code)

HOUSING CODE

CHAPTER 6
MOVING BUILDINGS
SECTION:
3-6-1: House Mover's License; Permit
3-6-2: Application For License; Bond
3-6-3: Cash Deposit Required
3-6-4: Application For Permit
3-6-5: Issuance Of Permit
3-6-6: Wooden Buildings; Moving Within Fire Limits Prohibited
3-6-7: Notice To Utility Companies Required
3-6-8: Warning Lights Required After Sunset
3-6-9: Injury To Property
3-6-10: Indebtedness To City
3-6-1: HOUSE MOVER'S LICENSE; PERMIT:
In order to regulate the use of the streets and public places within the city
by persons desiring to move buildings and other structures thereon it is hereby
provided that no person shall move any building, house or other structure along
or upon the public streets, alleys, ways or places within the city without
first having obtained a license as a house mover as herein provided, and
without also receiving a permit to move such building or other structure as
herein provided. (1972 Code)
3-6-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; BOND:
Any person desiring a license as a house mover shall make application for such
license to the clerk, and make payment of an annual license fee of twenty five
dollars ($25.00) and shall furnish a bond to the city in the sum of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00), conditioned as herein set forth, and after
approval of the bond by the council, the clerk shall issue to the applicant a
license as house mover expiring on May 1 next thereafter. The bond of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall be conditioned among other things that the
applicant for such license will pay for any and all damage which he, in any of
his operations as a house mover, shall cause to any tree, pavement, street or
sidewalk, or any other city property whatsoever, whether inflicted by himself
or by his agents or employees, and further conditioned to save and keep
harmless the city from any and all suits, judgments, costs, liabilities or
expenses whatsoever which may in anywise accrue or be alleged against the city
in consequence of the granting of such license or permit and/or any operations
thereunder, and conditioned further, that the applicant will in all things
comply with the provisions of this code, applicable thereto. (1972 Code)
3-6-3: CASH DEPOSIT REQUIRED:
No house mover shall remove any building, house or other structure, along or
upon any public street, alley or place in the city, without first having
obtained from the council a permit to remove the particular building or
structure in question, under the regulations hereinafter provided, and without
first depositing with the clerk a cash deposit in an amount equal to the cost
of caring for, splicing, removing and replacing any wires, poles or cables,
pipes or other property of the city, the caring for, splicing, removing and
replacing of which is necessary to facilitate the operations of the house
mover. Such estimate of cost shall be made by the superintendent of public
works. The cost shall be paid out of the cash deposit and any amount unexpended
from such deposit shall be returned to the depositor. If any deficiency results
under the deposit, the depositor must make up the difference. (1972 Code)
3-6-4: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Before any permit shall be granted, the person desiring same shall make
application in writing to the council at the office of the clerk stating the
building proposed to be removed, where located, and the place to which it is
proposed to be moved. (1972 Code)
3-6-5: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
The council, or someone designated by it, shall thereupon, if it sees fit,
issue a permit therefor, prescribing the route to be taken, and the maximum
time to be allowed for such removal, and any other conditions which to it shall
seem needful for the public good. The work of removal shall be done in such
manner as to meet the approval of the street commissioner. (1972 Code)
3-6-6: WOODEN BUILDINGS; MOVING WITHIN FIRE LIMITS PROHIBITED:
No wooden building, within or without the fire limits shall be moved to any
lot, or part of lot, located within the fire limits as defined by section
3-2-6 of this title. (1972 Code)
3-6-7: NOTICE TO UTILITY COMPANIES REQUIRED:
No building shall be allowed to be moved upon any street, alley or other public
place unless at least forty eight (48) hours' previous notice has been given to
any street railways, telephone or telegraph or electric light or power
companies whose right of way or wires or poles, the moving of the building will
interfere with. (1972 Code)
3-6-8: WARNING LIGHTS REQUIRED AFTER SUNSET:
Every person so moving a building hereunder, or who makes any sort of
excavation or piles any lumber or other material upon any of the public
streets, alleys or places within the city, shall in addition to the
requirements of the other provisions of this code, keep from sunset until dawn
a red light hung out upon or about such obstruction or excavation so as to give
ample warning thereof. (1972 Code)
3-6-9: INJURY TO PROPERTY:
No mover of any building shall be permitted to cut or injure any tree within
the city without the consent of the owner thereof, or if on city property,
without the consent of the street commissioner. (1972 Code)
3-6-10: INDEBTEDNESS TO CITY:
No permit to move any building or other structure shall be issued to any house
mover, nor shall the license of any house mover be renewed, in the event that
the house mover is in any way indebted to the city in any amount on account of
any expenses, costs, judgments, damages, liabilities or other indebtedness
whatsoever, occasioned or incurred by or on account of any of the operations of
the house mover upon or along the public streets, alleys, ways or places in the
city. (1972 Code)
CHAPTER 7
DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS
SECTION:
3-7-1: Definitions
3-7-2: Powers And Duties Of Building Inspector
3-7-3: Regulation Of Demolition Contractors
3-7-4: Regulation Of Property Owners
3-7-5: Fees And Permits; Nonresidential Demolition; Demolition Of Residential
Real Property With Value Greater Than Twenty Five Thousand Dollars
3-7-6: Fees And Permits; Demolition Of Residential Real Property With Value
Less Than Twenty Five Thousand Dollars
3-7-7: Demolition Inspections
3-7-8: Nonresidential Demolition; Residential Demolition Where Value Of
Property Demolished Exceeds Twenty Five Thousand Dollars
3-7-9: Residential Demolition; Value Of Property Demolished Is Less Than Twenty
Five Thousand Dollars
3-7-10: Violations, Penalties
3-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings
ascribed to them:
BUILDING INSPECTOR: The city of Spring Valley building inspector or his
authorized agent.
DEMOLITION: The removal, in whole or in part, of any structure or building, the
removal of demolition debris, or the installation of fill material and final
grading in connection with such removal.
DEMOLITION CONTRACTOR: Any person or firm engaged in the business of demolition
of buildings or structures by contract. (Ord. 1587, 10-27-2014)
3-7-2: POWERS AND DUTIES OF BUILDING INSPECTOR:
In addition to the other powers and duties prescribed in this chapter, the
building inspector shall have the right during reasonable hours, or at any time
when an extreme danger exists, to enter any premises for which a demolition
permit has been issued or applied for to determine the progress of work or to
determine if a safety hazard exists. He shall have the authority to order the
discontinuation or modification of any demolition work when he determines that
a hazardous condition may result from continued work. He shall approve or
disapprove all applications for demolition permits. He shall approve all bonds
required under this chapter. He shall submit an accounting of all fees
collected to the city clerk. (Ord. 1587, 10-27-2014)
3-7-3: REGULATION OF DEMOLITION CONTRACTORS:
Prior to issuance of any demolition permit, a demolition contractor shall
provide the building inspector with the following:
   (A)   License And Permit Bond: A license and permit bond specifically
covering demolition work and conditioned upon compliance with the provisions of
this chapter, such bond to be in the amount of twenty thousand dollars
($20,000.00).
   (B)   Insurance: A certificate of liability insurance containing general
liability coverage of at least one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). If it would
be necessary for the demolition contractor to place any equipment for the
demolition and/or removal of demolition debris and/or installation of fill
material and/or final grading on public right of way, the city of Spring Valley
will be listed as an additional insured under the general liability policy.
(Ord. 1587, 10-27-2014)
3-7-4: REGULATION OF PROPERTY OWNERS:
Owners of real property may demolish their own buildings or structures.
However, the building inspector shall not issue a demolition permit until the
owner has provided the following:
   (A)   Bond: A cash bond equal to fifty cents ($0.50) per one square foot of
ground floor area of all buildings named in the application for a demolition
permit. Such bond shall be conditioned upon compliance with this chapter. Such
bond shall be canceled and all monies returned to the owner upon completion of
the demolition to the reasonable satisfaction of the building inspector.
   (B)   Entry Agreement: An agreement signed by the owner granting permission
to employees or agents of the city to enter the named property to complete all
work required under this chapter if such work is uncompleted on the date of
expiration of the demolition permit. Any expenses incurred by the city as a
result of such entry and work shall be deducted from the bond. (Ord. 1587, 10-
27-2014)
3-7-5: FEES AND PERMITS; NONRESIDENTIAL DEMOLITION; DEMOLITION OF RESIDENTIAL
REAL PROPERTY WITH VALUE GREATER THAN TWENTY FIVE THOUSAND DOLLARS:
   (A)   Permits Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to demolish any
building or structure, or any structural part thereof, that is over four
hundred (400) square feet, or connected to electric, gas, water, or sewer
lines, or has one or more party walls, without having first obtained a
demolition permit from the building inspector. Application for a permit shall
be made on a form prescribed by the building inspector.
   (B)   Expiration Of Permits: Permits for demolition shall expire sixty (60)
days after issuance. The building inspector may, upon good cause shown, extend
such date of expiration for a successive thirty (30) day period.
   (C)   Denial Of Permit: The building inspector may refuse to issue a
demolition permit when the requirements of this chapter are not met or where a
permit has already been issued for a specific property and no significant
progress has been made toward complete demolition.
   (D)   Drawings Required: Applicants for a demolition permit shall provide
drawings indicating the height and location of buildings on the site, distance
from property lines and adjacent buildings, final grading, party walls,
protective canopies and such other information as may be reasonably requested
by the building inspector. The building inspector may, if he determines that
the safety of the persons or property will not be adversely affected, waive the
requirements of this subsection (D).
   (E)   Permit Fees: The building inspector shall collect fees for all
demolition permits according to the following schedule:
 
Estimated Cost            Fee
$1.00 to $500.00          $10.00
$500.01 to $2,000.00      $10.00 for first $500.00 plus $1.50 each additional
                          $100.00 or fraction of, to and including $2,000.00
$2,000.01 to $25,000.00   $32.50 for first $2,000.00 plus $6.00 each additional
                          $1,000.00 or fraction of, to and including $25,000.00
                          $170.00 for first $25,000.00 plus $4.50 each
$25,000.01 to $50,000.00  additional $1,000.00 or fraction of, to and including
                          $50,000.00
                          $283.00 for first $50,000.00 plus $3.00 each
$50,000.01 to $100,000.00 additional $1,000.00 or fraction of, to and including
                          $100,000.00
$100,000.01 and up        $433.00 for first $100,000.00 plus $2.50 each
                          additional $1,000.00 or fraction of
 
(Ord. 1587, 10-27-2014)
3-7-6: FEES AND PERMITS; DEMOLITION OF RESIDENTIAL REAL PROPERTY WITH VALUE
LESS THAN TWENTY FIVE THOUSAND DOLLARS:
   (A)   Permits Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to demolish any
building or structure, or any structural part thereof, that is over four
hundred (400) square feet, or connected to electric, gas, water, or sewer
lines, or has one or more party walls, without having first obtained a
demolition permit from the building inspector. Application for a permit shall
be made on a form prescribed by the building inspector.
   (B)   Expiration Of Permits: Permits for demolition shall expire sixty (60)
days after issuance. The building inspector may, upon good cause shown, extend
such date of expiration for a successive thirty (30) day period.
   (C)   Denial Of Permit: The building inspector may refuse to issue a
demolition permit when the requirements of this chapter are not met or where a
permit has already been issued for a specific property and no significant
progress has been made toward complete demolition.
   (D)   Drawings Required: Applicants for demolition permits for residential
real estate having a value of less than twenty five thousand dollars
($25,000.00) shall provide drawings indicating the height and location of
buildings on the site, the distance from the property lines and adjacent
buildings, final grading, party walls, protective canopies and such other
information as may be reasonably requested by the building inspector. The
building inspector may, if he determines that the safety of the persons or
property will not be adversely affected by his decision, waive any of the
specific requirements of this subsection in those cases where strict compliance
with the requirements of this subsection would constitute an unnecessary
hardship on the applicant.
   (E)   Permit Fees: The building inspector shall collect a permit fee of
twenty five dollars ($25.00) for all demolition permits for the demolition of
residential real property having a value of less than twenty five thousand
dollars ($25,000.00). (Ord. 1587, 10-27-2014)
3-7-7: DEMOLITION INSPECTIONS:
   (A)   Inspections Required: The building inspector shall cause an inspection
to be made of all demolitions upon the completion of the work and such other
stages of the work as he may determine to be necessary.
   (B)   Notification For Inspections: The person carrying out a demolition
shall notify the building inspector that the site is ready for final
inspection. The building inspector shall cause an inspection to be made within
twenty four (24) hours of such notification, nonworking days excluded.
   (C)   Discontinuance Of Demolition For Safety Reasons: If, after inspection,
the building inspector finds continued demolition will create a hazard to the
public, he shall order the demolition discontinued and recommend a safer method
of demolition be used. (Ord. 1587, 10-27-2014)
3-7-8: NONRESIDENTIAL DEMOLITION; RESIDENTIAL DEMOLITION WHERE VALUE OF
PROPERTY DEMOLISHED EXCEEDS TWENTY FIVE THOUSAND DOLLARS:
   (A)   General: All demolition work shall be carried out in a safe and
workmanlike manner to minimize hazard to adjacent property and the public.
   (B)   Subterranean Walls, Floors, Footings: All subterranean walls, floors
and footings shall be removed.
   (C)   Fill Material: All depressions, cavities, cisterns or wells shall be
filled with approved granular material to within six inches (6") of final
grade.
   (D)   Site Restoration: The final grading shall be such that no depressions
or cavities exist and stormwater cannot stand on the demolition site. Six
inches (6") of earth shall be installed over any depression, cavity, cistern or
well filled with fill material. Backfill shall be placed in layers of
approximately nine inches (9") thickness and mechanically compacted. Mechanical
compaction against foundation walls that are common to adjacent buildings or
structures shall be completed in an approved manner. Finish grading shall be
mounded approximately twelve inches (12") above existing grade in the center of
the excavation unless the excavation abuts an existing building.
   (E)   Removal Of Debris: All debris resulting from demolition shall be
removed from the site where demolition occurs in a timely manner. In no event
shall debris be used for fill material. No wood, frozen materials, putrescibles
or demolition material shall be used for backfill.
   (F)   Barricades, Fencing And Canopies: Where necessary to protect public
health and safety, the building inspector may require the erection of fencing,
barricades or protective canopies around the perimeter of the demolition site.
   (G)   Working Hours: No demolition work shall be conducted between the hours
of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M., unless previously
approved by the building inspector.
   (H)   Closing Of Streets: Streets, roadways and alleys adjacent to a
demolition site may be closed only after approval by the building inspector.
The building inspector shall, prior to approval of such closing, consult with
the fire chief, police chief and director of public works.
   (I)   Disconnection Of Utilities: It is the responsibility of the owner or
his agent to arrange the disconnection of all utilities to a demolition site
prior to demolition. All water, sewer and gas lines shall be properly capped
and sealed.
   (J)   Notice: Notice to adjoining owners must be given at least ten (10)
days prior to the beginning of the proposed demolition. Only when written
notice has been given by the applicant to the owners of adjoining lots, and to
the owners of wired or other facilities, of which the temporary removal is
necessitated by the proposed work, shall a permit be granted for the removal of
the building or structure. Said notice shall contain the address of the
structure to be demolished as well as the date demolition is scheduled to
begin. Said notice shall also include the demolition contractor's name,
address, and phone number.
   (K)   Party Walls: In the event the structure to be demolished has one or
more party walls, the applicant shall provide drawings sealed by a registered
architect or structural engineer indicating the measures to be taken to support
the adjacent structures after demolition. In the event adjacent structures do
not require additional support, the architect or engineer shall provide a
written statement stating such conclusion. The written consent of owners of
adjacent buildings to install necessary shoring or bracing shall be provided.
   (L)   State Permits: The applicant shall provide the building inspector with
a copy of all permits required by the state of Illinois and the Illinois
environmental protection agency for the demolition of the property, including,
but not by way of limitation, asbestos abatement permits, demolition permits
(if applicable), lead paint inspection permits, and any other permits or
regulations required by either the state of Illinois or the Illinois
environmental protection agency. (Ord. 1587, 10-27-2014)
3-7-9: RESIDENTIAL DEMOLITION; VALUE OF PROPERTY DEMOLISHED IS LESS THAN TWENTY
FIVE THOUSAND DOLLARS:
   (A)   General: All demolition work shall be carried out in a safe and
workmanlike manner to minimize hazard to adjacent property and the public.
   (B)   Additional Requirements: As a condition of issuing a demolition
permit, the Spring Valley building inspector may include in the demolition
permit any of the requirements contained in section
3-7-8 of this chapter dealing with nonresidential demolition requirements and
demolition requirements for residential demolition wherein the value of the
property demolished exceeds twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) as the
building inspector reasonably determines is necessary given the scope of the
proposed demolition. (Ord. 1587, 10-27-2014)
3-7-10: VIOLATIONS, PENALTIES:
   (A)   Violation Defined: It is a violation of this chapter for any person to
cause or allow demolition to occur on any property under his ownership or
control except in conformance with the provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   Penalty For Violation: Any person who violates, neglects or refuses to
comply with or who resists or opposes the enforcement of any provision of this
chapter or who shall proceed to engage in the demolition of any structure
without having first obtained a demolition permit therefor shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be
deemed committed for each day any violation of any provision of this chapter
shall continue.
   (C)   Penalty Does Not Excuse Violation: The imposition of a penalty
hereunder shall not excuse the violation nor shall it permit the continuance of
any such violation. (Ord. 1587, 10-27-2014)
CHAPTER 8
UNSAFE OR DANGEROUS BUILDINGS
SECTION:
3-8-1: Dangerous Buildings Generally
3-8-2: Definition Of Dangerous Building
3-8-3: Deciding Upon Questions Arising Under Ordinance Notice To Remedy Unsafe
Condition Of Buildings; Failure To Obey Notice
3-8-4: Notice Of Unsafe Condition Of Buildings; Means Of Service
3-8-5: Lis Pendens
3-8-6: Placarding Of Building Or Structure
3-8-7: Demolition Lien, Personal Judgment
3-8-8: Nuisance, Penalty
3-8-1: DANGEROUS BUILDINGS GENERALLY:
It shall be unlawful for any owner or agent thereof to keep or maintain any
building or structure or part thereof in any unsafe or dangerous condition. The
word "building", as used in this chapter shall describe any walled or roofed
structure including mobile homes, commercial establishments, dwellings and any
accessory structures.
The superintendent of public works or his designee is hereby authorized to
demolish, repair or cause the demolition or repair of dangerous and unsafe
buildings, uncompleted buildings, or abandoned buildings within the territorial
limits of the city. (Ord. 657, 9-8-1987)
3-8-2: DEFINITION OF DANGEROUS BUILDING:
For the purpose of this chapter, any building or structure which has any of the
following defects or is in any of the conditions hereinafter described shall be
deemed a "dangerous building" and any conditions hereinafter described shall be
deemed unsafe:
   (A)   Whenever any door, aisle, passageway, stairway or other means of exit
is not of sufficient width or size, or is not so arranged as to provide safe
and adequate means of exit in case of fire or panic for all persons housed or
assembled therein who would be required to or might use such door, aisle,
passageway, stairway or other means of exit;
   (B)   Whenever any portion thereof has been damaged by wind, flood, fire or
by any other cause in such a manner that the structural strength or stability
thereof is appreciably less than it was before the catastrophe and is less than
the minimum requirements of this chapter;
   (C)   Whenever any portion or member or appurtenance thereof is likely to
fail or to become detached or dislodged, or to collapse and thereby injure
persons or damage property;
   (D)   Whenever any portion thereof has settled to such an extent that walls
or other structural portions have materially less resistance to winds than is
required in the case of new construction;
   (E)   Whenever any building or structure or any part thereof, because of
dilapidation, deterioration, decay, faulty construction, or because of the
removal or movement of some portion of the ground necessary for the purpose of
supporting such building or portion thereof, or for other reason, is likely to
partially or completely collapse, or some portion of the foundation or
underpinning is likely to fall or give away;
   (F)   Whenever for any reason whatsoever, the building or structure or any
portion thereof is manifestly unsafe for the purpose for which it is used;
   (G)   Whenever the building or structure has been so damaged by fire, wind
or flood, or has become so dilapidated or deteriorated as to become an
attractive nuisance to children who might play in or about the building
structure to their danger;
   (H)   Whenever the building or structure has been so damaged by fire, wind
or flood, or has become so dilapidated or deteriorated as to afford a harbor
for vagrants, criminals, or immoral persons, or as to enable persons to resort
thereto for the purpose of committing a nuisance or unlawful or immoral acts;
   (I)   Whenever a building or structure used or intended to be used for
dwelling purposes, because of dilapidation, decay, damage or faulty
construction or arrangement is unsanitary or unfit for human habitation and is
likely to work injury to the health, safety or general welfare of those living
within;
   (J)   Whenever a building or structure is infested with rodents, insects,
pests or other vermin, or is likely to cause sickness or disease when so
determined by the health officer of the city;
   (K)   Whenever any building shall become vacant, dilapidated or open at door
or window, leaving the interior of the building exposed to the elements or
accessible to entrance by trespassers;
   (L)   Whenever any unoccupied building or structure is deemed a nuisance by
section
3-8-8 of this chapter and the structure or building has been secured by the
owner or his agents by covering up the windows and exits with lumber or
materials other than glazing material for a period of thirty (30) days or more,
thereby causing a blighting influence on a neighborhood. (Ord. 657, 9-8-1987)
3-8-3: DECIDING UPON QUESTIONS ARISING UNDER ORDINANCE NOTICE TO REMEDY UNSAFE
CONDITION OF BUILDINGS; FAILURE TO OBEY NOTICE:
The superintendent of public works or his designee shall have full power to
pass upon any question arising under the provisions of this chapter, subject to
the conditions, modifications and limitations contained in this chapter.
The superintendent of public works or his designee is hereby authorized to
demolish or repair or cause the demolition or repair of dangerous buildings or
uncompleted buildings or abandoned buildings within the territorial limits of
the city. (Ord. 657, 9-8-1987)
3-8-4: NOTICE OF UNSAFE CONDITION OF BUILDINGS; MEANS OF SERVICE:
When a building or structure within the city is found to be a "dangerous
building" or contains an unsafe condition, an inspector for the superintendent
of public works shall issue and serve a notice thereof upon all owners of
record or persons having an interest therein as shown by documents recorded in
the office of the Bureau County recorder of deeds and upon persons in apparent
possession of the premises.
The notice shall briefly and concisely specify the conditions and factors of
the building or structure which render it dangerous or unsafe. The notice shall
further specify that the owners make the building safe (by complete elimination
of any unsafe conditions) or commence demolition at owner's costs within
fifteen (15) days of said notice. The notice shall further specify that: a)
demolition shall commence no later than fifteen (15) days of said notice, and
b) a date for completion of demolition. The date for completion shall be
reasonably set in light of the nature of the building, weather conditions, and
other related factors. The fifteen (15) day time period shall commence upon
receipt of the notice.
The notice authorized by this section shall be served by either personal
service or by certified mail with return receipt. Personal service may be made
by either an inspector designated by the superintendent of public works or a
police officer of the city.
Where, upon diligent search, the identity or whereabouts of the owner or owners
of any such building, including the lienholders of record is not ascertainable,
notice mailed to the person or persons in whose name such real estate was last
assessed for general real estate taxes is sufficient notice under this section.
In the event the owner fails to comply with any time period set forth in the
notice, the corporation counsel is authorized to commence a civil action in the
circuit court of Bureau County seeking a court order authorizing demolition or
repair of the building or structure subject to the notice provided by this
section and to create the lien described in section
3-8-7 of this chapter. It shall not be a defense to this cause of action that
the building is boarded up or otherwise enclosed. It further shall not be
defense that the building is put in a safe condition during the pendency of the
civil action.
Joined as defendants in said cause shall be the owner of record and other
parties having an interest in the property as shown by documents recorded in
the office of the Bureau County recorder of deeds on the date of the filing of
the complaint for demolition. (Ord. 657, 9-8-1987)
3-8-5: LIS PENDENS:
Upon the commencement of the civil action set forth in section
3-8-4 of this chapter, a lis pendens designating the property upon which the
subject building is located shall be filed with the recorder of deeds. Failure
to file or the improper filing of the lis pendens does not, however, affect the
civil action for demolition. Any person obtaining or recording in said office
an interest in the property after such filing may become party to the civil
action only if he intervenes by order of the court. (Ord. 657, 9-8-1987)
3-8-6: PLACARDING OF BUILDING OR STRUCTURE:
Whenever any dwelling or building has been designated a "dangerous building" or
contains unsafe conditions, an inspector designated by the superintendent of
public works shall placard the building indicating that the condition is
dangerous and unsafe. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, cause to
remove or cover up in any way any placard designating a building structure a
"dangerous building". Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be
punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 657, 9-8-1987)
3-8-7: DEMOLITION LIEN, PERSONAL JUDGMENT:
The cost of demolition, repair, engineering and related expenses, and legal
proceedings incurred by the city in enforcing the provisions of this chapter
shall be recoverable from the owner or owners of the real estate and is a lien
thereon, which lien shall be superior to all prior existing liens and
encumbrances, except taxes, provided, however, that within sixty (60) days
after completion of the demolition or repair, the corporation counsel shall
file a notice of lien for the cost and expense incurred by the city, in the
office of the recorder of deeds of Bureau County. Upon payment of said cost of
demolition by the owner or any person who has an interest in the property, the
lien shall be released by the corporation counsel.
The lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in case of mortgages or
mechanics' liens. Suit to foreclose this lien shall be commenced by the
corporation counsel within three (3) years after the date of filing of notice
of lien.
If payment of the city's cost of demolition is not paid to the city within
fifteen (15) days of the filing of the notice of lien, the corporation counsel
may commence proceedings in the circuit court seeking a personal judgment from
the owner of the subject property at the time the complaint for demolition was
filed with the circuit clerk in the amount of said costs. The action authorized
by this paragraph shall be in addition, and without waiver of, any other
remedies. (Ord. 657, 9-8-1987)
3-8-8: NUISANCE, PENALTY:
Any unsafe, dilapidated and abandoned building, house, barn or other structure
situated within the limits of the city is, and the same is hereby declared to
be, a nuisance.
Any person maintaining a nuisance shall be punished by a fine of not less than
twenty five dollars ($25.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for each offense, and each and every day that such nuisance remains unabated
shall constitute a new and separate offense. (Ord. 657, 9-8-1987)
CHAPTER 9
PROPERTY MAINTENANCE AND OCCUPANCY CODE
SECTION:
3-9-1: Purpose
3-9-2: Scope And Applicability
3-9-3: Definitions
3-9-4: Property Maintenance Requirements; Maintenance Required
3-9-5: Responsibilities Of Owners And Occupants
3-9-6: Minimum Standards For Basic Facilities
3-9-7: Minimum Standards For Light And Ventilation
3-9-8: Minimum Thermal Standards
3-9-9: General Requirements Relating To The Safe And Sanitary Maintenance Of
Parts Of Dwellings And Dwelling Units
3-9-10: Maximum Density, Minimum Space, Use And Location Requirements
3-9-11: Rules And Regulations
3-9-12: Inspections
3-9-13: Notice Of Violations
3-9-14: Designation Of Building As Unfit For Human Use
3-9-15: Designation Of Building As Dangerous And A Public Nuisance
3-9-16: Emergency Cases
3-9-17: Penalties
3-9-18: Appeals
3-9-19: Records
3-9-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to protect the environment and the public
health, safety and welfare, and to prevent and control blight by establishing
regulations for the administration and enforcement procedures to the end that
buildings and real estate within the city are maintained in a safe and sanitary
condition, free of health, fire and safety hazards; including establishment of
minimum standards and requirements relating to the safe and sanitary
maintenance of said buildings and real estate; determination of the
responsibilities of owners, operators and occupants. The intent of this chapter
is not to regulate, alter or in any way affect the lifestyle, personal habits,
or domestic patterns of such owners, operators and occupants unrelated to the
public health, safety and welfare. (Ord. 823, 8-1-1994)
3-9-2: SCOPE AND APPLICABILITY:
Except where otherwise specified hereinafter, and as limited by the foregoing
statement of purpose, the provisions of this chapter shall apply uniformly to
the maintenance, use and occupancy of all buildings and structures, where
applicable, and shall apply uniformly to the alteration, repair, equipment, use
and occupancy and maintenance of all existing buildings and structures, within
the jurisdiction of the city. This chapter is not intended to make any other
code, ordinance, rule or resolution applicable which by its terms is not
applicable to the matters addressed herein. (Ord. 823, 8-1-1994)
3-9-3: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of
this chapter:
ACCESSORY BUILDING OR STRUCTURES: A detached building or structure in a
secondary or subordinate capacity from the main or principal building or
structure on the same premises.
APARTMENT: A dwelling unit having bathroom, kitchen facilities and sleeping
area.
APPROPRIATE AUTHORITY: That person within the governmental structure of the
corporate unit who is charged with the administration of the appropriate code.
APPROVED: Approved by the local and/or state authority having such
administrative authority.
ASHES: The residue from the burning of combustible materials.
ATTIC: Any story situated wholly or partly within the roof, and so designed,
arranged or built as to be used for business, storage, or habitation.
BASEMENT: A portion of a building located partly or wholly below grade and
having one-half (1/2) or more than one-half (1/2) of its clear floor to ceiling
height below the average grade of the adjoining ground.
BOARDING HOUSE: See definition of Rooming House.
BUILDING: A single fixed structure with walls, foundation and roof, such as a
house, factory, garage, apartment, etc.
BULK CONTAINER: Any metal garbage, rubbish, and/or refuse container having a
capacity of two (2) cubic yards or greater and which is equipped with fittings
for hydraulic and/or mechanical emptying, unloading and/or removal.
CELLAR: A portion of a building located partly or wholly below grade and having
one-half (1/2) or more than one-half (1/2) of its clear floor to ceiling height
below the average grade of the adjoining ground.
CENTRAL HEATING SYSTEM: A single system supplying heat to one or more dwelling
units or more than one rooming unit.
CHIMNEY: A vertical shaft of reinforced concrete, or other approved
noncombustible, heat resisting material enclosing one or more flues, for the
purpose of removing products of combustion from solid, liquid or gaseous fuel.
DILAPIDATED: No longer adequate for the purpose or use for which it was
originally intended.
DORMITORY: A building or a group of rooms in a building used for institutional
living and sleeping purposes by four (4) or more persons.
DWELLING: Any enclosed space wholly or partly used or intended to be used for
living, sleeping, cooking and eating, provided that "temporary housing" as
hereinafter defined shall not be classified as a dwelling.
DWELLING UNIT: A room or group of rooms located within a dwelling forming a
single habitable unit with facilities used or intended to be used by a single
family for living, sleeping, cooking and eating purposes.
EGRESS: An arrangement of exit facilities to assume a safe means of exit from
buildings.
ENFORCEMENT OFFICER: The person who is the inspector for the property
maintenance and occupancy code enforcement of the city of Spring Valley, and
any other so assigned code enforcement inspector or their superiors. This
person may also be the building inspector or assistant building inspector of
the city of Spring Valley.
EXTERMINATION: The control and elimination of insects, rodents or other pests
by eliminating their harborage places; by removing or making inaccessible
materials that may serve as their food; by poisoning, spraying, fumigating,
trapping or by any other recognized and legal pest elimination methods approved
by the local or state authority having such administrative authority.
FAIR MARKET VALUE: A price at which both buyers and sellers are willing to do
business.
FAMILY: One or more individuals occupying a single dwelling unit; provided
that, unless all such individuals who are related by blood, marriage, legal
adoption or are foster children, no such family shall contain over four (4)
unrelated persons; and not more than two (2) guests or roomers whether
gratuitous or nongratuitous may also be housed. The term "family", as regards
the number of persons residing within a dwelling unit, shall be further
regulated by the necessary minimum requirement to the land development code of
the city of Spring Valley whenever such standards are more restrictive.
FLUSH WATER CLOSET: A toilet bowl which is flushed with water which has been
supplied under pressure and equipped with a water sealed trap above the floor
level.
GARBAGE: The animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking, service and nonconsumption of food.
GRADE: The finished ground level adjacent to a required window.
HABITABLE ROOM: A room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be used for
living, sleeping, cooking or eating purposes, excluding bathrooms, water closet
compartments, laundries, furnace rooms, pantries, kitchenettes and utility
rooms of less than fifty (50) square feet of floor space, foyers or
communicating corridors, stairways, closets, storage spaces and workshops,
hobby and recreation areas.
HEATED WATER: Water heated to a temperature of not less than one hundred twenty
degrees Fahrenheit (120°F) at the outlet.
HEATING DEVICE: All furnaces, unit heaters, domestic incinerators, cooking and
heating stoves and ranges, and other similar devices.
HOTEL/MOTEL: Any building or buildings in which the public may, for a
consideration, obtain living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations.
The term includes inns, motels, tourist homes or courts and lodging homes.
HOUSEHOLD: One or more individuals living together in a single dwelling unit
and sharing common living, sleeping, cooking and eating facilities. (See also
definition of Family.)
IMPERVIOUS TO WATER: A clean, smooth floor, without cracks or (as to floors)
holes, and made of terrazzo, ceramic, wood, asphalt or rubber tile, smooth
concrete, linoleum or other similar material that is completely sealed so as to
be water resistant.
INFESTATION: The presence within or around a dwelling of any insects, rodents
or other pests.
KITCHEN: Any room used for the storage of foods, preparation of foods and
containing the following equipment: sink and/or other device for dishwashing,
stove, and other device for cooking, refrigerator or other device for cool
storage of food, cabinets and/or shelves for storage of equipment and utensils,
and counter or table for food preparation.
KITCHENETTE: A small kitchen or an alcove containing cooking facilities.
LAVATORY: A fixed washbowl equipped with plumbing. Kitchen sinks do not meet
this definition.
LEAD BASED PAINT: Any paint containing more lead than the level established by
the U.S. consumer product safety commission as being the "safe" level of lead
in residential paint and paint products.
LODGING HOUSE: See definition of Rooming House.
MULTIPLE DWELLING: Any single building or structure containing more than one
dwelling unit.
OCCUPANT: Any individual, over one year of age, living, sleeping, cooking, or
eating in, or having possession of, a dwelling unit or a rooming unit; except
that in dwelling units a guest shall not be considered an occupant.
OPERATOR: Any person who has charge, care, control or management of a building,
or part thereof, in which dwelling units or rooming units are let or offered
for rent or other consideration.
ORDINARY SUMMER TEMPERATURES: An outside air temperature ten degrees Fahrenheit
(10°F) below the highest recorded temperature in the locality for the prior ten
(10) year period.
ORDINARY WINTER CONDITIONS: See subsection
3-9-8(A) of this chapter.
OWNER: Any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others:
   (A)   Shall have legal title to any premises, dwelling or dwelling unit,
with or without accompanying actual possession thereof, or
   (B)   Shall have charge, care, or control of any premises, dwelling or
dwelling unit, as owner or agent of the owner, or an executor, administrator,
manager, trustee or guardian of the estate of the owner. Any such person thus
representing the actual owner shall be bound to comply with the provisions of
this chapter and of the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, to the
same extent as if he were the owner.
PERMISSIBLE OCCUPANCY: The maximum number of individuals permitted to reside in
a dwelling unit, rooming unit or dormitory.
PERSON: Includes any individual, firm, corporation, association, partnership,
cooperative or governmental agency.
PLUMBING: Includes all of the following supplied facilities and equipment: gas
pipes, gas burning equipment, water pipes, garbage disposal units, waste pipes,
