issued under this chapter; to administer oaths, issue subpoenas to compel the
attendance of witnesses and the production of relevant documents or other
evidence; to receive testimony and take proof; to make findings of fact and
determinations of law; to enter written orders and decisions;
   (I)   To represent the city on any appeal of any action taken under this
chapter;
   (J)   To prescribe penalties for violations of this chapter and state law
and enforce such penalties. Permissible penalties shall include:
      1.   A written reprimand;
      2.   A fine of up to $1,000.00 for each violation but not more than
$10,000.00 against any licensee during any license year;
      3.   To suspend any licensee’s license for not more than 30 days for any
violation;
      4.   To revoke any license issued under this article for cause.
   (K)   To keep and maintain in his office, or shall cause to be maintained
under his direction and supervision, books and records concerning applications
for licenses, investigations, minutes of meetings, records of hearings and
other relevant information relative to his duties, functions and
responsibilities under this article;
   (L)   To receive license fees, fines and other moneys under this chapter and
to promptly forward such funds to the city clerk;
   (M)   To cause legal proceedings to be initiated on behalf of the city
regarding the duties, functions and responsibilities under this chapter;
   (N)   To declare the existence of an emergency and thereafter to alter the
hours of operation of any licensee and take all other actions that may be
necessary or proper due to such emergency;
   (O)   To notify the Illinois Secretary of State where a club incorporated
under the General Not For Profit Corporation Act or a foreign corporation
functioning as a club in Illinois under a certificate of authority issued under
that Act has violated the Illinois Liquor Control Act or this chapter by
selling or offering for sale at retail alcoholic liquor without a license;
   (P)   To take any and all actions necessary and incidental to the
furtherance of his duties and functions as set forth in this chapter or by
state law.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-4: LOCAL LIQUOR COMMISSIONER TO ISSUE LICENSES:
   Upon receipt of a properly completed application and such other supporting
documents as the commissioner may require and after a complete and thorough
investigation the commissioner may issue a license under this chapter to any
person properly qualified and pursuant to the terms, conditions and
restrictions of this chapter. The chief of police will be provided a duplicate
of the record of retail liquor licenses as they are issued.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-5: HEARINGS:
   The commissioner may convene and conduct a public hearing into any matter
relating to this chapter whenever in his discretion he deems appropriate. In
addition, public hearings shall be held in the following instances:
   (A)   Upon receipt of an application for a new license or for renewal of an
existing license when the commissioner determines that receipt of formal
evidence is necessary or the applicant requests a hearing;
   (B)   Upon denial of an application for a new license, for renewal of an
existing license if the applicant requests a hearing;
   (C)   Upon complaint or report of a violation by a licensee under this
chapter or state law.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-6: HEARING PROCEDURES:
   The commissioner shall observe the following procedures in conducting
hearings under this chapter:
   (A)   At all times every licensee shall be afforded due process which shall
be construed to include the right to appear personally before the commissioner
or any hearing officer; the right to demand written specification of any
charges against him a reasonable time in advance of any hearing; the right to
employ and be represented by counsel during all proceedings; the right to
testify in his own behalf or refuse to testify; the right to present witnesses
in his behalf and to request that subpoenas be issued to compel the attendance
of witnesses; the right to hear the witnesses and evidence against him; the
right to cross-examine witnesses.
   (B)   Prior written notice shall be given to a licensee of any hearing under
this chapter.
   (C)   All witnesses that appear and testify shall be sworn.
   (D)   All hearings shall be informal in nature and strict rules of evidence
shall not apply to hearings under this article. Evidence determined by the
commissioner to be irrelevant, immaterial or unduly repetitious may be
excluded. Evidence may be admitted if it is of a type commonly relied upon by
reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs.
   (E)   The liquor commissioner will reduce all evidence to writing and
maintain an official record of the proceedings, by a certified court or
shorthand reporter at the city’s expense.
   (F)   Review of any proceedings conducted by the commissioner shall be
limited to a review of the official record of such proceedings. No new or
additional evidence shall be admitted or considered by the reviewing tribunal,
however; the commissioner may reopen any hearing to receive new evidence not
discovered or available at the original hearing.
   (G)   No transcript of any public hearing need be prepared except for
purposes of appeal or as required by the commissioner. In the event of an
appeal from any public hearing by a licensee, the licensee shall pay the cost
to transcribe the official record for purposes of such appeal.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-7: DECISIONS OF LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER AND PENALTIES:
   The commissioner shall observe the following procedures in conducting
hearings under this chapter:
   (A)   In all cases presented to the commissioner wherein a licensee is
alleged to have violated this article, state law or applicable rules and
regulations, the commissioner shall within five business days after the
conclusion of the public hearing reduce his findings and reasons to writing and
shall enter and serve upon the licensee a written order.
   (B)   In any case where the commissioner determines that a violation of this
chapter, state law or applicable rules and regulations, has occurred, the
commissioner may proscribe any of the following penalties:
      1.   Direct a written reprimand to the licensee and place a copy of such
reprimand on file in the licensee’s liquor license application file.
      2.   Impose a fine upon the licensee. Any fine imposed shall not exceed
$1,000.00 for each violation. Each day on which a violation continues shall
constitute a separate violation for which a separate fine may be assessed. No
licensee shall be fined more than $10,000.00 in the aggregate during any
license year.
      3.   Suspend the licensee’s liquor license for a period of not more than
30 days. In the case of a suspension, the suspension shall begin and end as
specified by the commissioner in his written order.
      4.   Revoke the licensee’s liquor license.
      5.   In the case of a class B licensee’s suspension or revocation of
license, all alcoholic liquor must be removed from the licensed premises within
24 hours of such action.
      6.   Revoke the licensee liquor license and have the same reissued as an
“RL” license.
      7.   In all cases where the commissioner determines that a penalty is
appropriate, the commissioner may consider the following criteria in deciding
the nature of the penalty, the amount of any fine or the length of time of any
suspension and whether revocation is warranted:
         a.   The nature of the violation;
         b.   The factual situation and circumstances as presented at the
public hearing;
         c.   Past action by the commissioner in similar situations;
         d.   Facts or circumstances in aggravation or mitigation regarding the
violation;
         e.   Prior violations committed by the same licensee during the three-
license years immediately preceding the year in which the violation occurs.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-8: APPEALS:
   Any decision of the commissioner imposing a penalty on any licensee may be
appealed by the licensee to the state liquor commission provided that written
notice of such appeal is filed with the commissioner and the state liquor
commission within 20 days after service of the commissioner’s written order
upon the licensee. The licensee shall request the commissioner to cause a full
written transcript of the public hearing to be prepared and sent to the state
liquor commission. The commissioner may require the licensee to pay the cost of
preparation of the transcript in advance.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-9: AUTHORITY TO CLOSE ESTABLISHMENTS WHEN IN VIOLATION:
   (A)   If, in the opinion of the local liquor control commissioner or city
council, the public peace is likely to be endangered by the keeping open of
establishments licensed to sell alcoholic liquor, it shall be lawful for the
local liquor commissioner to issue a proclamation, under the seal of the city,
commanding and enjoining all persons licensed by the city to sell alcoholic
liquor, and their servants and agents, to close their shops and places of
business for such time as the local liquor control commissioner shall deem
necessary.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to disobey a proclamation issued
under subsection (A), by keeping open his place of business, or by selling,
giving away, or allowing to be consumed, on or about his premises, any
alcoholic liquor.
   (C)   When a license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall
be granted to any person for the period of one year thereafter for the conduct
of the business of manufacturing, distributing or selling alcoholic liquor in
the premises described in such revoked license; except that any license that
has been revoked for a conviction of the Controlled Substances Act of 1970
(21USC 801 et seq.) or any applicable state statute that regulates the sale or
use of certain controlled substances in a licensed location, will have their
license immediately revoked, and will never hold another liquor license in the
city.
   (D)   Whenever any license hereunder has been revoked as provided for in
this chapter, the licensee shall incur a forfeiture of all monies that have
been paid for said license.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-10: EMERGENCY CLOSING:
   In all cases where, in the opinion of the commissioner, the public peace or
the health or safety of any person, is likely to be endangered by allowing any
licensed establishment to remain open, the commissioner may order any
establishment or establishments licensed under this article to close without
notice or a hearing. The liquor commissioner or his/her agents may, in the
event of a continued breach of the peace, civil disturbance or serious criminal
act, close or cause to be closed, any establishment licensed under this Act to
sell liquor for consumption on the premises. This closure shall be for the
balance of that days’ hours of operation. If said closure is done by the police
department or an agent of the liquor commissioner, a written report containing
the circumstances of the incident leading to the closure will be forwarded to
the commissioner on the next business day after closure. In such event the
commissioner shall enter a written order stating the reason for the closing and
the length thereof, which in no event shall be longer than seven days. In
addition, the commissioner shall provide any licensee affected by a closing
order an opportunity to be heard, as provided in section
5-18-4, during the period of the closing.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-11: AUTHORIZED AGENTS:
   The members of the Spring Valley Department of Police will act as agents of
the Spring Valley Liquor Control Commissioner, and have the authority and a
duty to enforce all aspects of this Act.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-12: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   (A)   No person shall sell or offer for sale at retail, or display for sale
within the corporate limits of the city, either personally or through an agent,
any alcoholic liquor without first obtaining a license as provided by this
chapter.
   (B)   No person after purchasing or obtaining any alcoholic liquor at retail
shall resell or offer for resale such alcoholic liquor, either directly or
indirectly in any manner, except pursuant to a license obtained as provided in
this chapter.
   (C)   Any person who violates subsection (A) shall be fined not less than
$250.00 nor more than $750.00. Any person who violates subsection (B) of this
section shall be fined not less than $500.00 nor more than $750.00.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-13: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   (A)   All applications for a license under this chapter shall be made in
writing, on forms provided for that purpose, to the commissioner, signed by the
applicant, if an individual; by all partners, if a general or limited
partnership; by all joint venturers, if a joint venture; by all members, if a
limited liability company; or by a duly authorized officer, if a business or
not-for-profit corporation. Every application shall be verified as to the truth
and accuracy of all statements and information contained therein in such manner
as the commissioner shall prescribe. The commissioner will forward a copy of
each application to the police department for examination, review and
investigation. Applications for a liquor license which are incomplete,
inaccurate or fail to contain the statements or information required shall be
rejected by the local liquor commissioner. The commissioner will require
inaccurate applications to be returned. Every application must be submitted and
filed with the commissioner, and shall contain the following information and
statements:
      1.   The name, age, Social Security number, driver’s license number, date
of birth, current residence address and telephone number of each individual
required to sign the application under this section.
      2.   In the case of a business or not-for-profit corporation, the objects
for which it was formed, the date and place of incorporation, and the names,
ages, Social Security numbers, driver’s license numbers, dates of birth, and
current residence addresses of every officer, director, shareholder holding
five percent or more of the stock, or member.
      3.   The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth and if a
naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization.
      4.   The location and description of the premises or place of business
which is to be operated under such license, and a statement that the applicant
owns such premises or has a lease thereon for the full term for which the
license is requested.
      5.   The class of license applied for by the applicant.
      6.   The length of time that the applicant has resided within the city;
or in the case of a general or limited partnership, the length of time that
each partner has resided within the city; or in the case of a limited liability
company, the length of time that each member has resided within the city; or in
the case of a business or not-for-profit corporation, the length of time that a
proposed resident manager has resided within the city.
      7.   A list of all governmental entities to which applicant has submitted
an application for a liquor license, the dates on which such applications were
submitted, the disposition of such applications, the amount of and reason for
any fine imposed upon applicant under any other liquor license held by him and
the dates, reason and length of any suspension or revocation of any other
liquor license held by applicant.
      8.   A list of all convictions of the applicant for all offenses, other
than a violation of any traffic law of this or any other state, except that
applicant shall also disclose any traffic conviction involving in any manner
drugs or alcoholic liquor and indicating the nature of the offense, date of
conviction and disposition.
      9.   A statement that the applicant will testify under oath and answer
all competent, relevant and material questions propounded to him at any hearing
conducted by the commissioner, or his designated representative, either before
or after the issuance of a license to him and that his failure to so testify
shall be sufficient reason to refuse to issue or renew any license or to
suspend or revoke any license that has been issued.
      10.   A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of
the State of Illinois or the United States, or any ordinance of the city, in
the conduct of this business.
      11.   Responses to all questions asked of applicant on any forms provided
to applicant by the city.
   (B)   In addition to and at the same time that applicant submits his
application for a license, he shall submit the following supporting documents:
      1.   In the case of a partnership, a copy of the partnership agreement.
      2.   In the case of a limited partnership, a copy of the certificate of
limited partnership and the partnership agreement.
      3.   In the case of a limited liability company, a copy of the articles
of organization.
      4.   In the case of a corporation, a copy of the certificate and articles
of incorporation.
      5.   For any leased premises, a copy of the lease and any assignment,
sublease or extension.
      6.   A completed request and release of liability for a criminal
background and credit check.
      7.   A copy of any assumed name certificates applicable to the
applicant’s business.
      8.   In the case of a foreign corporation, in addition to the other
documents, a copy of its certificate of authority to operate in the State of
Illinois.
      9.   A copy of the applicant’s certificate of registration under the
Retailers’ Occupation Tax Act.
      10.   A copy of any federal wagering stamp held by applicant.
      11.   Copies of any other documents requested by the commissioner to
support or clarify information contained in the application or any document
submitted with the application.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-14: RESTRICTIONS ON LICENSES:
   No license shall be issued to:
   (A)   A person who is not a resident of the city.
   (B)   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the city.
   (C)   A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
   (D)   A person convicted of:
      1.   Any felony under any federal or state law;
      2.   Having kept or keeping a house of ill fame;
      3.   Pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and
morality.
   (E)   A person whose license under the Illinois Liquor Control Act has been
revoked for cause.
   (F)   A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued under this article would not be eligible for such license upon a first
application.
   (G)   A partnership, if any partner thereof would not be eligible to receive
a license under this article for any reason other than residence or
citizenship.
   (H)   A limited liability company, if any member or manager thereof would
not be eligible to receive a license under this article for any reason other
than residence or citizenship.
   (I)   A corporation, if any officer, director, manager or any shareholder
owning in the aggregate more than five percent of the stock of such corporation
would not be eligible to receive a license under this article for any reason
other than residence or citizenship.
   (J)   A corporation unless it is incorporated under the laws of the state,
or if a foreign corporation, unless it is qualified to transact business in
this state.
   (K)   A limited partnership unless it is organized under the laws of the
state, or if not so organized, unless it has been admitted to transact business
in this state.
   (L)   A limited liability company unless it is organized under the laws of
the state, or if not so organized, unless it is admitted to transact business
in this state.
   (M)   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state
law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor, or who
has forfeited bond for failure to appear in court to answer charges for any
such violation.
   (N)   A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a
license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for
which the license is sought.
   (O)   Any law enforcing public official, including members of local liquor
control commissions, any mayor, alderperson, or member of the city council
president of a village board of trustees, any member of a village board of
trustees, or any president or member of a county board; and no such official
shall have a direct interest in the manufacture, sale, or distribution of
alcoholic liquor, except that a license may be granted to such official in
relation to premises that are not located within the territory subject to the
jurisdiction of that official if the issuance of such license is approved by
the State Liquor Control Commission and except that a license may be granted,
in a city or village with a population of 55,000 or less, to any alderperson,
member of a city council, or member of a village board of trustees in relation
to premises that are located within the territory subject to the jurisdiction
of that official if (i) the sale of alcoholic liquor pursuant to the license is
incidental to the selling of food, (ii) the issuance of the license is approved
by the State Commission, (iii) the issuance of the license is in accordance
with all applicable local ordinances in effect where the premises are located,
and (iv) the official granted a license does not vote on alcoholic liquor
issues pending before the board or council to which the license holder is
elected. Notwithstanding any provision of this paragraph to the contrary, an
alderperson or member of a city council or commission, a member of a village
board of trustees other than the president of the village board of trustees, or
a member of a county board other than the president of a county board may have
a direct interest in the manufacture, sale, or distribution of alcoholic liquor
as long as he or she is not a law enforcing public official, a mayor, a village
board president, or president of a county board. To prevent any conflict of
interest, the elected official with the direct interest in the manufacture,
sale, or distribution of alcoholic liquor shall not participate in any
meetings, hearings, or decisions on matters impacting the manufacture, sale, or
distribution of alcoholic liquor. Furthermore, the mayor of a city with a
population of 55,000 or less or the president of a village with a population of
55,000 or less may have an interest in the manufacture, sale, or distribution
of alcoholic liquor as long as the council or board over which he or she
presides has made a local liquor control commissioner appointment that complies
with the requirements of Section 4-2 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act.
   (P)   A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated
by the licensee.
   (Q)   A person convicted of a gambling offense as proscribed by any of
subsections (A)3. through (A)11. of section 28-1 of, or as proscribed by
Section 28-1.1 or 28-3 of, the Criminal Code of 1961 or the Criminal Code of
2012, or as proscribed by a statute replaced by any of the aforesaid statutory
provisions.
   (R)    A person or entity to whom a federal wagering stamp has been issued
by the federal government, unless the person or entity is eligible to be issued
a license under the Raffles and Poker Runs Act or the Illinois Pull Tabs and
Jar Games Act.
   (S)   Any applicant that owes any monies to the city, which have remained
unpaid for a period of more than 45 days, whether for bills, taxes, licenses or
otherwise.
   (T)   Any applicant that has had his license revoked by the local liquor
commission for cause cannot, in any way, be involved in the business of
manufacturing, distributing or selling alcoholic liquor in the city.
   (U)   A person who intends to sell alcoholic liquors for use or consumption
on his or her licensed retail premises who does not have liquor liability
insurance coverage for that premises in an amount that is at least equal to the
maximum liability amounts set out in subsection (A) of section 6-21 of the
Illinois Liquor Control Act.
   (V)   A person who is licensed by any licensing authority as a manufacturer
of beer, or any partnership, corporation, limited liability company, or trust
or any subsidiary, affiliate, or agent thereof, or any other form of business
enterprise licensed as a manufacturer of beer, having any legal, equitable, or
beneficial interest, directly or indirectly, in a person licensed in this state
as a distributor or importing distributor. For purposes of this paragraph (23),
a person who is licensed by any licensing authority as a “manufacturer of beer”
shall also mean a brewer and a non-resident dealer who is also a manufacturer
of beer, including a partnership, corporation, limited liability company, or
trust or any subsidiary, affiliate, or agent thereof, or any other form of
business enterprise licensed as a manufacturer of beer.
   (W)   A person who is licensed in this state as a distributor or importing
distributor, or any partnership, corporation, limited liability company, or
trust or any subsidiary, affiliate, or agent thereof, or any other form of
business enterprise licensed in this state as a distributor or importing
distributor having any legal, equitable, or beneficial interest, directly or
indirectly, in a person licensed as a manufacturer of beer by any licensing
authority, or any partnership, corporation, limited liability company, or trust
or any subsidiary, affiliate, or agent thereof, or any other form of business
enterprise, except for a person who owns, on or after the effective date of
this amendatory Act of the 98th General Assembly, no more than five percent of
the outstanding shares of a manufacturer of beer whose shares are publicly
traded on an exchange within the meaning of the Securities Exchange Act of
1934. For the purposes of this paragraph (20), a person who is licensed by any
licensing authority as a “manufacturer of beer” shall also mean a brewer and a
non-resident dealer who is also a manufacturer of beer, including a
partnership, corporation, limited liability company, or trust or any
subsidiary, affiliate, or agent thereof, or any other form of business
enterprise licensed as a manufacturer of beer.
   (X)   A criminal conviction of a corporation is not grounds for the denial,
suspension, or revocation of a license applied for or held by the corporation
if the criminal conviction was not the result of a violation of any federal or
state law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor,
the offense that led to the conviction did not result in any financial gain to
the corporation and the corporation has terminated its relationship with each
director, officer, employee, or controlling shareholder whose actions directly
contributed to the conviction of the corporation. The commission shall
determine if all provisions of this subsection (B) have been met before any
action on the corporation’s license is initiated.
   (Y)   The local liquor control commissioner shall not require applicants to
report the following information and shall not consider the following criminal
history records in connection with an application for a license under this
ordinance:
      1.   Juvenile adjudications of delinquent minors as defined in Section 5-
105 of the Juvenile Court Act of 1987, subject to the restrictions set forth in
Section 5-130 of the Juvenile Court Act of 1987.
      2.   Law enforcement records, court records, and conviction records of an
individual who was seventeen years old at the time of the offense and before
January 1, 2014, unless the nature of the offense required the individual to be
tried as an adult.
      3.   Records of arrest not followed by a conviction.
      4.   Convictions overturned by a higher court.
      5.   Convictions or arrests that have been sealed or expunged.
   (Z)   The local liquor control commissioner, upon a finding that an
applicant for a license was convicted of a felony or a violation of any federal
or state law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic
liquor, shall consider any evidence of rehabilitation and mitigating factors
contained in the applicant’s record, including any of the following factors and
evidence, to determine if the conviction will impair the ability of the
applicant to engage in the position for which a license is sought:
      1.   The lack of direct relation of the offense for which the applicant
was previously convicted to the duties, functions, and responsibilities of the
position for which a license is sought;
      2.   Whether five years since a felony conviction or three years since
release from confinement for the conviction, whichever is later, have passed
without a subsequent conviction;
      3.   If the applicant was previously licensed or employed in this state
or other states or jurisdictions, then the lack of prior misconduct arising
from or related to the licensed position or position of employment;
      4.   The age of the person at the time of the criminal offense;
      5.   Successful completion of sentence and, for applicants serving a term
of parole or probation, a progress report provided by the applicant’s probation
or parole officer that documents the applicant’s compliance with conditions of
supervision;
      6.   Evidence of the applicant’s present fitness and professional
character;
      7.   Evidence of rehabilitation or rehabilitative effort during or after
incarceration, or during or after a term of supervision, including, but not
limited to, a certificate of good conduct under Section 5-5.5-25 of the Unified
Code of Corrections or a certificate of relief from disabilities under Section
5-5.5-10 of the Unified Code of Corrections; and
      8.   Any other mitigating factors that contribute to the person’s
potential and current ability to perform the duties and responsibilities of the
position for which a license or employment is sought.
   (AA)   If the local liquor control commissioner refuses to issue a license
to an applicant, then the local liquor control commissioner shall notify the
applicant of the denial in writing with the following included in the notice of
denial:
      1.   A statement about the decision to refuse to issue a license;
      2.   A list of the convictions that the commission determined will impair
the applicant’s ability to engage in the position for which a license is
sought;
      3.   A list of convictions that formed the sole or partial basis for the
refusal; and
      4.   A summary of the appeal process or the earliest the applicant may
reapply for a license, whichever is applicable.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-15: SITE APPROVAL:
   (A)   No license shall be initially issued and no change of location shall
be granted under this article until the proposed location has been investigated
and approved. No location may be approved to be licensed and no license shall
be issued for any premises:
      1.   Within 100 feet of any church, school other than institution of
higher learning, hospital, home for the aged, indigent or veterans or their
spouses or children, or any military, or naval station and with such distance
to be measured from nearest property line to nearest property line.
      2.   Where the majority of the customers are minors or where the
principal place of business to be transacted consists of selling or providing
school books, school supplies, food, lunches or drinks to minors.
   (B)   The requirements of subsection (A)1. shall not apply to an application
for a hotel, club, restaurant where the principal business is not the sale of
alcoholic liquor, or for establishments that have been licensed prior to the
passage of this chapter.
   (C)   When applying for renewal of a license under this article every
licensee shall satisfy the commissioner that no change of circumstance has
occurred during the previous license year whereby the licensed premises would
violate subsection (A)1., and must comply with Section 5-18-18 of this Code.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-16: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
   Every applicant for a license under this chapter shall be required to
undergo a complete investigation of his background which shall include a
thorough examination of the applicant’s criminal history by appropriate law
enforcement officials and a thorough examination of the applicant’s financial
circumstances and credit history. A fingerprint check by appropriate law
enforcement officials is required. The applicant shall complete all forms, and
cooperate in every respect with the commissioner in such investigation. In the
case of a national corporation applicant, the local manager will comply with
this section. In the event a local manager is transferred or replaced, the new
manager will submit a letter to the local liquor commissioner advising of the
change in management and will submit to the investigative process, including
criminal history and fingerprint submission. Such letter will be delivered to
the liquor commissioner within 30 days of such change. Applicant will be
charged a fee to reimburse the city for all costs associated with the
investigation of the applicant. This fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of
any license.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-17: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
   Every license issued under this chapter shall be prominently displayed upon
the licensed premises by the licensee.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-18: TERM OF LICENSE:
   Every license issued hereunder, unless otherwise specifically provided in
the license, shall be valid from May 1 each year to April 30 of the following
year provided all provisions of this article have been complied with by the
licensee.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-19: RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
   Any licensee may apply to renew his license at expiration. The original
application filed by such licensee shall remain on file with the commissioner
and constitute an application for renewal provided that the licensee shall
execute an affidavit each year declaring that his original application and all
the information contained therein or supplied therewith is still true and
correct, or is still true and correct in part, and in that event, the licensee
shall specify in what respects the information contained in the original
application or supporting documents is no longer accurate and shall supply
correct information in that regard. Nothing contained in this section shall be
construed to prohibit the commissioner from requiring any licensee to file a
new application where the commissioner deems that such filing is necessary to
act upon the licensee’s request for renewal.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-20: INSURANCE/BOND:
   Every applicant for a license shall furnish to the commissioner with his
application, evidence of liquor liability insurance coverage for that premises
in an amount that is at least equal to the maximum liability amounts set out in
subsection 6-21(a) of the Illinois Liquor Control Act covering the licensee and
the owner of the premises for the entire term of the license. Evidence of
continued coverage shall be provided each year thereafter as a condition of
renewal of any license.
   (A)   Before any license shall be issued, the applicant shall file with the
local liquor control commission, a joint and several bond executed by good and
sufficient sureties which are residents of the county or by a stock surety
company writing business and authorized to do business in the state. The bond
shall be in the penal sum of $5,000.00, for each license, conditioned upon the
true and faithful compliance by the applicant with all ordinances of this city
and of the laws of the state that may be in force during the period the bond is
effective.
   (B)   Accompanying the bond required by subsection (1), shall be a sworn
statement of the assets and liabilities of the sureties signing the bond. If a
surety company executes the bond, a statement of its assets and liabilities
shall accompany the bond.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-21: SEPARATE LICENSE REQUIRED FOR EACH LOCATION:
   A separate license under this article must be issued for each location
desired by an applicant. No more than one license may be issued for any one
licensed premises.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-22: CHANGE OF LOCATION OR CLASSIFICATION:
   Any licensee desiring to change the location of his licensed premises or to
change the classification of his license under this article shall submit an
appropriate application for such change to the commissioner. An application for
change of location or change of classification shall be subject to the
requirements of this article and specifically to section
5-18-21 and applications for change of form of ownership shall meet the
requirements of section
5-18-22.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-23 :CHANGE OF FORM OF OWNERSHIP:
   Whenever any licensee changes the manner in which it conducts its business
at the licensed premises such licensee shall inform the commissioner of such
change. The licensee’s new business entity shall be required to meet the
requirements of this chapter in order to be eligible to continue to hold the
license issued to licensee.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-24: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
   (A)   Every license issued under this chapter shall be a purely personal
privilege and shall not constitute property, nor shall such license be subject
to attachment, garnishment or execution. No license issued under this chapter
shall be alienable or transferable, either voluntarily or involuntarily, or
subject to be encumbered or hypothecated.
   (B)   No license issued under this chapter shall be subject to transfer by
testate or intestate succession, but shall cease upon the death of the
licensee. Provided however that upon the death of any licensee, the executor or
administrators of such deceased licensee’s estate may continue to operate the
licensee’s business on the licensed premises under order of the appropriate
court and may exercise the privileges of any deceased licensee under such
license until its expiration or for a period of six months after the date of
the licensee’s death, whichever shall first occur.
   (C)   In the event of the bankruptcy or insolvency of any licensee, any
trustee or receiver appointed by an appropriate court for the estate of such
licensee may likewise continue to operate the business of the licensee on the
licensed promises until expiration of such license or for a period of six
months from the date of the licensee’s bankruptcy or insolvency, whichever
shall first occur.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-25: SALE OF LICENSED PREMISES:
   Whenever any licensee under this chapter has entered into a contract to sell
his business and to transfer the licensed premises to such purchaser, the
licensee shall notify the commissioner. The new owners shall file an
application and shall be subject in all respects to the requirements of this
chapter. If the new owner does not meet the qualifications for a license under
this chapter, nothing in this chapter guarantees the issuance of a license
after the sale of a licensed business.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-26: CONTINUOUS OPERATION:
   Any license issued under this chapter shall be kept in continuously in
effect and use in an operative business during the period for which it is
issued and when such business is abandoned, closed, or for any reason becomes
inoperative for a period of 60 days or more, the liquor commissioner, in his
discretion, may revoke the license.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-27: LICENSE CLASSIFICATIONS:
   All licenses issued under this chapter shall be of the classes specified in
this article.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-27.1: CLASS A:
   A Class A license shall entitle the licensee therein to sell at retail on
the premises specified alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises as well
as other retail sales of such liquor to be carried off the premises in a closed
and sealed container.
   (A)   Only persons whose primary business is the sale of alcoholic liquor
for consumption on the licensed premises as a bar, tavern, restaurant or
similar establishment shall be eligible;
   (B)   The privilege granted by such license shall be to sell alcoholic
liquor at retail by the drink, in pitchers or in open original containers for
consumption on the licensed premises only and to sell at retail in the original
package for consumption off of the license premises;
   (C)   Restrictions applicable to such licenses shall be that only persons 21
years of age or older shall be allowed to enter or remain upon the licensed
premises unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. This restriction
shall not apply to employees or independent contractors performing services
upon the licensed premises during times at which such persons are actually
engaged in their employment for the licensee, provided that all such persons so
employed must be at least 18 years of age.
   (D)   The annual single payment fee for initial issuance or renewal of a
class A license shall be $500.00.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-27.2: CLASS A-1 CRAFT DISTILLERY:
   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in the aforesaid section 5-18-26.1,
Class A, a Class A-1 license shall entitle the licensee therein to all of the
rights and privileges of a Class A license in addition to authorizing the
licensee to operate as a craft distillery.
   A Class A-1 craft distillery license also authorizes the on-site
manufacturing, production and storage of alcohol in quantities not to exceed
100,000 gallons (or higher limits in the event higher limits are authorized
under State of Illinois statutes). Sales of alcohol manufactured outside the
facility are prohibited. Such craft distillery license shall be issued subject
to the following conditions:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for a Class A-1 licensee to sell a sealed
container of alcohol for off-premises consumption unless the container is
greater than or equal to 200 milliliters in volume.
   (B)   Class A-1 licensees shall have at least one Bassett-certified person
on premises whenever alcohol is available for on-site consumption. On-site
consumption for a Class A-1 licensee shall permit consumption in the licensee’s
premises and on the property in which the licensee premises is located.
   (C)   A Class A-1 licensee must also obtain a valid craft distiller license
from the State of Illinois.
   (D)   The annual single payment fee for initial issuance or renewal of a
Class A-1 license shall be $500.00. (Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-27.3: CLASS A-2 BREWER’S LICENSE:
   A Class A-2 brewer’s license shall authorize the on-site manufacturing,
storage, retail sale, and consumption of beer products on the licensed
premises. Issuance of a Class A-2 brewer’s license pursuant to this section
shall not relieve the licensee of any responsibility for complying with all
applicable local, state, and federal regulations. A Class A-2 brewer’s license
shall be issued subject to the following conditions:
   (A)   A Class A-2 licensee shall obtain and maintain all applicable state
and federal licenses pertaining to the manufacture, storage, retail sale, and
consumption of beer products.
   (B)   A Class A-2 licensee shall have at least one Bassett-certified person
on premises whenever alcohol is available for on-site consumption on the
licensed premises.
   (C)   The annual fee for the initial issuance or renewal of a Class A-
2 brewer’s license shall be $450.00.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-27.4: CLASS B:
   A Class B license shall entitle the licensee therein to sell at retail on
the premises specified alcoholic liquor, not for consumption on the premises
where sold.
   (A)   Only persons whose business is the sale of alcoholic liquor in and for
consumption off of the licenses premises shall be eligible;
   (B)   No employee, clerk or other person shall sell alcoholic beverages
unless they are at least 18 years of age during hours allowed by this chapter.
   (C)   Cold or chilled beer or wine shall not be sold by the single can or
bottle if less than 16 fluid ounces in size.
   (D)   Drive-up windows for the sale or purchase of alcohol are prohibited.
   (E)   The annual single payment fee for initial issuance or renewal of a
Class B license shall be $500.00, provided, however, the Class B license fee
for any retail establishment containing over 10,000 square feet shall be
$1,000.00.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-27.5: CLASS C-CLUB LICENSE:
   A Class “C” club license shall be issued by the commissioner subject to the
following requirements:
   (A)   Only not for profit corporations organized for fraternal, civic,
veterans, athletic or some other common objective and for whom the sale of
alcoholic liquor to members and guests is an ancillary purpose of such
organization shall be eligible;
   (B)   The privilege granted by such license shall be to sell alcoholic
liquor by the drink or in open original containers for consumption on the
licensed premises only.
   (C)   The facility must have seating for one hundred (100) people or less.
   (D)   The annual single payment fee for initial issuance or renewal of a
class C club license shall be $500.00.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-27.6: CLASS D:
   A Class D license which shall entitle the licensee to sell alcoholic liquors
at retail for consumption on the premises only.
   (A)   Only persons whose primary business is the operation of a video gaming
terminal and the sale of alcoholic liquors represents less than 40 percent of
total sales shall be eligible for a Class D license.
   (B)   The privilege granted by such license shall be to sell alcoholic
liquors by the drink or in open original containers for consumption on the
licensed premises only.
   (C)   The annual single payment fee for initial issuance or renewal of a
class D license shall be $500.00.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-27.7: CLASS E:
   A Class E Beer Garden Supplemental license shall entitle the licensee to
sell alcoholic liquors at retail for consumption on a beer garden.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for a licensee holding a Class E beer garden
license to hold a supplemental beer garden license without also holding a valid
Class A or C liquor license.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-27.8: CLASS “SE” SPECIAL EVENT PERMITS:
   Class “SE” permits shall be issued by the commissioner subject to the
following requirements:
   (A)   Only persons who qualify as special event retailers shall be eligible;
   (B)   The privilege granted by such permit shall be to sell beer and wine by
the drink or in open original containers for consumption on the specially
designated permit premises only;
   (C)   Class “SE” permits shall be subject to the following restrictions:
      1.   Such permit shall be issued only for a special community, civic,
educational, fraternal, political, religious or similar events;
      2.   The permit location may be a temporary structure, tent, or outdoor
location provided that ingress and egress to the permit area is subject to
control to assure compliance with the requirements of this chapter;
      3.   No person under the age of 21 years shall be allowed to enter or
remain upon the permitted premises, unless accompanied by a parent or legal
guardian. This restriction shall not apply to employees or independent
contractors performing services upon the licensed premises during times at
which such persons are actually engaged in their employment for the licensee,
provided that all such persons so employed must be at least 18 years of age;
      4.   No permit of this class shall be issued for a period in excess of
five consecutive days in any one-month. This permit shall not permit the sale
of alcoholic liquor in any place where the same is otherwise prohibited by law;
      5.   A special event permit can allow exemptions to section 5-18-26.6(2)
in that beer may be possessed and/or consumed on a public sidewalk, street,
parking lot or city park when the event is established in one of these
particular areas;
      6.   Person(s) requesting a special event permit must comply with the
city application process.
      7.   The annual single payment fee for initial issuance or renewal of a
class SE permit shall be $10.00 per day.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-27.9: CLASS “RL” RESTRICTED LICENSE:
   The restricted license shall allow the licensee to sell alcoholic liquor in
the same manner as originally licensed (i.e. class A, B, etc.), however, the
hours of operation shall be restricted as defined in subsection
5-18-28(D).
   A business will hold a Class “RL” license until such time as the licensee is
free from violations of this article for a period of one full license year.
   The fee for initial issuance or renewal of a Class “RL” license shall be
equal to the sum of the original license issued.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-28: LICENSE FEES:
   The fees for the initial issuance and renewal of liquor licenses authorized
under this chapter shall be as follows:
CLASS       FEE
CLASS “A$500.00
CLASS “A-1$500.00
CLASS “A-2$450.00
CLASS “B$500.00 provided, however, the Class B license fee for any retail
            establishment containing over 10,000 square feet shall be $1,000.00
CLASS “C$500.00
CLASS “D$500.00
CLASS “SE$10.00/day
CLASS “RLFee equal to original license issued
 
   Should the license applied for be denied, the fee shall be returned to the
applicant, minus any costs incurred by the city to complete background checks,
fingerprints, and all fees incurred by the city in processing the application.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-29: HOURS OF OPERATION:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person operating a premises licensed for
the sale of alcoholic liquor to allow the premises to remain open during 2:00
a.m. to 6:00 a.m. on any day.
   (B)   At closing time, all sales and consumption of alcoholic liquor will
cease and all persons, except employees, must depart the premises.
   (C)   No person shall enter upon the licensed premises between the closing
hour set forth in this section and 6:00 a.m. except the licensee and his
agents.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person operating a premises licensed for
the sale of alcoholic liquor with a Class “RL” license to allow the premises to
remain open during the following times:
      1.   From 1:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. on any day other than Saturday and
Sunday.
      2.   From 2:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday.
   (E)   A premises licensed for the sale of alcoholic liquor, where the
primary business is not the sale of alcoholic liquor, may remain open past the
hours in subsection (A) or (D); however, no alcoholic liquor shall be sold on
the premises after the closing times in subsection (A) or (D).
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-30: CONDITIONS FOR OPERATING A BEER GARDEN:
   No beer garden shall be permitted, maintained or operated except in
conformity with the following regulations:
   (A)   The beer garden area shall be particularly described and adjacent to,
and operated as part of, premises licensed to sell beer or alcoholic beverages
for consumption on the premises.
   (B)   Beer gardens shall be no greater in area than one and one-half the
other floor space of the licensed premises.
   (C)   Beer gardens shall be limited to one person for each ten square feet
and shall have separately posted the maximum capacity.
   (D)   At any part of the beer garden not blocked by a building, there shall
be maintained or constructed a hedge or fence not less than three feet high
surrounding the beer garden area. The fence shall contain the required fire
exit or exits. Each gate or exit shall be not less than three feet high, shall
swing to egress, shall be equipped with proper hardware, and shall swing free
and clear of public sidewalks. The beer garden fence shall comply with all city
ordinances regarding vision clearance and required distances from corners.
   (E)   All electrical wiring shall comply with the national, state and city
electrical codes.
   (F)   All combustible rubbish shall be stored in noncombustible covered
containers.
   (G)   The noise emanating from any beer garden shall not violate any
regulations of the Municipal Code or ordinances pertaining to noise.
   (H)   The licensee or his agent shall be responsible for preventing
violations of the section.
   (I)   No license shall be granted that violates any other provisions of the
liquor code including but not limited to location restrictions, days of
restricted sales, and other standards of operation.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-31: QUALIFICATIONS OF EMPLOYEES:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or for any agent of such
licensee to knowingly employ in any licensed premises any person who is
afflicted with, or who is a carrier of, any contagious, infectious or sexually
transmitted disease; and it shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted
with, or a carrier of, any such disease to work in or about any premises or to
engage in the handling, preparation or distribution of any alcoholic liquor.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or for any agent of such
licensee to employ for work on the licensed premises any person who has been
convicted of murder, attempted murder, a felony sexual offense or any felony
for any law concerning the sale or possession of controlled substance as
defined in the Illinois Criminal Code, for a period of five years preceding
such employment.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or for any agent of any licensee
to employ, with or without compensation, in any way directly or indirectly, any
person under 18 years of age for the purpose of drawing, pouring or mixing any
alcoholic beverages or to tend bar; and it shall be unlawful for any person
under 18 years of age to draw, pour or mix any alcoholic beverage or to tend
bar on any licensed premises.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or for any agent of any licensee
to employ, with or without compensation, in any way directly or indirectly, any
person under 18 years of age to sell or consummate the sale of any alcoholic
liquor or to serve any alcoholic liquor to any other person for consumption;
and it shall be unlawful for any person under 18 years of age to sell or
consummate the sale of any alcoholic liquor or to serve any alcoholic liquor to
any other person for consumption upon any licensed premises.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-32: OCCUPANCY:
   (A)   All premises licensed under the ordinance for consumption of alcoholic
liquor on such premises shall be inspected by the fire chief, or his designated
representative, to determine and fix the maximum permitted occupancy of such
premises. The licensee shall arrange with the fire chief for an inspection and
determination of occupancy prior to conducting any business in the licensed
premises. Existing licensees shall make arrangements to be inspected and
occupancy determined not later than six months from the date of passage of this
chapter.
   (B)   Occupancy limit shall be determined by dividing the net building area
by a factor of 15.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or for any agent of any licensee
to allow the posted occupancy limit of any licensed establishment to be
exceeded. At any time when the commissioner or any law enforcement officer
reasonably believes that the occupancy limit of any licensed premises has been
exceeded, the fire department shall be notified. The fire chief, or his
designated representative, may determine the occupancy on such premises on such
occasion by any reasonable means, including requiring the temporary and orderly
evacuation of the premises in order to obtain a count of the persons present.
   (D)   The fire chief, after finalizing his inspection of the premise, shall
issue a certificate, signed and dated, in a size of eight inch by ten inch with
one inch block letters, that clearly states the maximum occupancy of the
premise. This certificate is to be prominently displayed in plain view at each
entrance to the establishment and above the bar area.
   (E)   The penalty for a violation of this section shall be a fine of not
less than $100.00 nor more than $750.00.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-33: PERSONS PERMITTED TO ENTER ON LICENSED PREMISES:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee holding a Class “A”, “C”, “RL”,
or “SE” license to permit or suffer any person under 21 years of age, unless
accompanied by a parent or legal guardian, to enter, and after entering, to
remain upon the licensed premises at any time. This restriction shall not apply
to employees or independent contractors performing services upon the licensed
premises during times at which such persons are actually engaged in their
employment for the licensee, provided that all such persons so employed must be
at least 18 years of age.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person under 21 years of age, unless
accompanied by a parent or legal guardian, to enter, or after entering to
remain, upon any licensed premises licensed under Class “A”, “C”, “RL”, or “SE”
of this chapter.
   This restriction shall not apply to employees or independent contractors
performing services upon the licensed premises during times at which such
persons are actually engaged in employment for the licensee, provided that all
such persons so employed must be at least 18 years of age.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-34: PURCHASED, ACCEPTANCE, POSSESSION OR CONSUMPTION OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR
BY MINORS:
   (A)   Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of any alcoholic liquor
is prohibited because of age shall not:
      1.   Purchase or accept a gift of such alcoholic liquor.
      2.   Have such alcoholic liquor in his possession.
      3.   Consume such alcoholic liquor.
   (B)   Notwithstanding, the other provisions of this section it shall not be
a violation of this article for any person under 21 years of age to possess and
dispense, or consume, any alcoholic liquor in the performance of a religious
ceremony or service;
   (C)   The penalty for a violation of this section shall be a fine of not
less than $250.00 nor more than $750.00.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-35: SALE AND DELIVERY OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR TO MINORS AND CERTAIN OTHER
PERSONS:
   (A)   No licensee nor any agent of such licensee shall sell, give, or
deliver, or permit or suffer the sale, gift or delivery of alcoholic liquor to
any person under 21 years of age, or to any intoxicated person or to any person
known by him or her to be under legal disability or in need of mental
treatment.
   (B)   No person, after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor,
shall sell, give or deliver such alcoholic liquor to another person under 21
years of age, except in the performance of a religious ceremony or service.
   (C)   The fact that a person under 21 years of age is found in possession of
alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises of any licensee under this chapter
shall be prima facie evidence that the licensee or an agent of the licensee
permitted or suffered the sale, gift or delivery of such alcoholic liquor to
such person.
   (D)   The penalty for a violation of this section shall be a fine of not
less than $250.00 nor more than $750.00.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-36: PROOF OF AGE; MISREPRESENTATION OF AGE:
   (A)   Any licensee or agent of any licensee may refuse to sell or serve
alcoholic liquor to any person unable to produce adequate written evidence of
identity and of the fact that he or she is over 21 years of age.
   (B)   At any time that a licensee or any agent of a licensee believes or has
reason to believe that a sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor is prohibited to
any person due to such person’s age, he shall, before making the sale or
delivery, demand presentation of two permanent forms of positive
identification, issued by a public official in the performance of his official
duties: one of which forms of identification shall contain a photograph of the
prospective recipient and proof of age and the other form of identification
shall show the same name.
   (C)   It shall be an affirmative defense that the licensee or his agent did
the following:
      1.   Demanded presentation of identification;
      2.   Was provided written evidence of identification as provided in this
section;
      3.   Reasonably relied upon the written evidence of identification
produced.
   It shall not be a defense to a charge under this section that a licensee or
his agent was shown and accepted a false or fraudulent identification which he
knew to be false or fraudulent.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession, or to
present or offer to any licensee or his agent, any written, printed or
photostatic evidence of age and identity which is false, fraudulent, or not
actually his own for the purpose of entering any licensed premises where access
to such premises is restricted to persons 21 years of age or older under this
chapter.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession any
altered, false or fraudulent written, printed or photostatic evidence of age or
identity or any written, printed or photostatic evidence of age or identity of
another person for the purpose of purchasing or attempting to purchase or
procuring or attempting to procure alcoholic liquor.
   (F)   The penalty for a violation of this section shall be a fine of not
less than $250.00 nor more than $750.00.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-37: ASSISTING MINOR IN MISREPRESENTATION OF AGE OR IDENTITY:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to give, sell or furnish to any
person under 21 years of age any altered, false or fraudulent written, printed
or photostatic evidence of age and identity.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to give, sell or furnish to any
person under 21 years of age any written, printed or photostatic evidence of
age and identity of any other person for the purpose of misrepresenting the age
and identity of the person under 21 years of age.
   (C)   The penalty for a violation of this section shall be a fine of not
less than $250.00 and not more than $750.00. Every licensee under this chapter
and every employee or agent of such licensee who as a part of his duties or
employment with the licensee tends bar, sells, serves or dispenses any
alcoholic liquor or checks identifications of patrons shall receive training in
properly identifying persons and in recognizing false or fraudulent
identification. Training which meets the requirements of this section shall be
training offered or approved by the state. All persons so trained shall receive
supplementary training at least once every three years.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-38: REGULATIONS ON LICENSEES AND LICENSED PREMISES:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or his agent to solicit any
other person to purchase the solicitor a drink or drinks on any licensed
premises.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or his agent to serve, give,
deliver or in any manner participate in placing any alcoholic liquor in any
motor vehicle except in the original package and with the seal unbroken.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or his agent to sell any
alcoholic liquor in return for any payment not authorized by state law.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or his agent or anyone on the
licensee’s behalf to announce the presence of law enforcement officers in or on
the licensed premises, unless requested to do so by a law enforcement officer.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or his agent or anyone acting on
the licensee’s behalf to use any radio, police scanner or other electronic
device for the purpose of intercepting police radio transmissions and
thereafter warning any person on the licensed premises or notifying any other
licensee or his agent of any inspection, check or other action by the police on
any licensed premises.
   (F)   Every licensee and each of his agents shall promptly report to the
police department any crime or other illegal activity occurring on or about the
licensed premises of which any of them have knowledge. No licensee nor any
agent of any licensee shall fail or refuse to aid and cooperate with the police
department in the investigation of any crime or illegal activity or withhold
any information.
   (G)   Every licensee shall maintain on each licensed premises at least one
telephone in proper working order and readily accessible to the bartender or
other responsible person in charge of the licensed premises for purposes of
reporting to the police department incidents that occur on or about the
licensed premises, including but not limited to 9-1-1, medical, police and/or
fire assistance.
   (H)   Every licensed premises, including places of storage, shall be kept
and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition at all times and shall comply
with all federal, state and local laws governing health and safety. This also
includes the place of storage for materials and equipment used in the sale of
alcoholic liquor.
   (I)   Sanitary measures for cleaning and caring for all glasses, dishes,
utensils and equipment shall be provided for by all licensees.
   (J)   No playing of dice, or any gambling devices or games of chance, punch
boards or slot machines shall be permitted or used in any premises licensed for
the sale of alcoholic liquors except when authorized under the laws of the
State of Illinois.
   (K)   No person shall operate, keep, own, use, exhibit, rent or lease or
allow or permit the operation, keeping, owning, using, exhibition, renting or
leasing of gambling devices on a premises licensed for the sale of alcoholic
liquor except as otherwise authorized under the laws of the State of Illinois,
including, but not limited to, the Bingo License and Tax Act, 230 ILCS 25/1 et
seq., Illinois Lottery Law, 20 ILCS 1605/1 et seq., the Raffles Act, 230 ILCS
15/0.01 et seq., the Charitable Games Act, 230 ILCS 30/1 et seq., the Illinois
Pull Tabs and Jar Games Act, 230 ILCS 20/1 et seq., the Riverboat Gambling Act,
230 ILCS 10/1 et seq., and/or the Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.
   (L)   Licensees may advertise alcoholic liquor by means of signs on any
sidewalk within the 100 and 200 blocks of East and West St. Paul Street.
   (M)   Failure to comply to all ordinances and orders of the city may result
in a review by the local liquor commissioner and possible suspension of the
license.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-39: WARNING SIGNS REQUIRED:
   Premises licensed under this article where alcoholic liquor is sold there
shall be displayed at all times in a prominent place that is easily viewable by
the public, a printed card which shall be supplied by the city clerk. Of which
the size will not be less than eight and one-half inches by 11 inches, and
printed with a white background and black type and shall read substantially as
follows:
“WARNING TO PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF TWENTY-ONE YEARS. You are subject to a
minimum fine of $100.00 and a maximum fine of $750.00 under the Ordinances of
the City of Spring Valley, Illinois, if you purchase alcoholic liquor or
misrepresent your age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic
liquor, or be present in or loiter in any tavern or place where alcoholic
liquor is sold unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.”
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-40: LIABILITY OF OWNER OF PREMISES AND LICENSEE IN CERTAIN INSTANCES:
   (A)   If the owner of any licensed premises, or any person from whom the
licensee derives the right to possession of such premises or the agent of such
owner or person, shall knowingly permit the licensee to use the licensed
premises in violation of this chapter, such person shall be deemed guilty of a
violation of this article to the same extent as the licensee and shall be
subject to the same penalties provided for in this chapter.
   (B)   Every act or omission of whatever nature constituting a violation of
any provisions of this article by any agent of any licensee, shall be deemed to
be the act of such licensee or employer. The licensee or employer shall be
punishable to the same extent and in the same manner as if the act or omission
had been done or omitted by the licensee personally.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-41: ABSOLUTE LIABILITY OFFENSES:
   The violation of the following is hereby declared absolute liability
offenses and subject to the general penalty provisions of this chapter:
   (A)   The sale of alcoholic liquor by the holder of a license or permit in
violation of the provisions of the license or permit; and
   (B)   Except in those provisions where a mental state is specifically
required, the violation of any prohibition or requirement contained in this
chapter.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-42: ENTERTAINMENT RESTRICTIONS:
   (A)   No licensee shall engage in or permit any of the following on any
licensed premises:
      1.   Any person to engage in any topless or bottomless act,
demonstration, dance or exhibition;
      2.   Any act of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality,
oral copulation, flagellation or any other sexual act which is prohibited by
law;
      3.   Any act of actual or simulated touching, fondling or caressing of
the breast, buttocks, anus, vulva or genitals;
      4.   The display of films or photographs depicting acts, the live
performance of which is prohibited by subsections 1., 2. or 3. above.
      5.   Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent a licensee
from showing any film or video feed having been classified with a rating not
greater than “R” by the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) or similar
commercial film industry organization, or which would otherwise meet such
rating standards based on its content.
   (B)   No person shall engage in any of the acts prohibited in subsection (A)
above on any licensed premises.
   (C)   No licensees or their agent(s) shall permit any person to remain on
the licensed premises who violates any of the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-43: HAPPY HOURS PROHIBITED:
   (A)   All licensees shall maintain a schedule of prices charged for all
drinks of alcoholic liquor served and consumed on any licensed premises or part
thereof.
   (B)   Any licensee who operates more than one licensed establishment or who
on any licensed premises operates more than one location where alcoholic liquor
is sold shall maintain a separate schedule of prices for all drinks on each
premises or location.
   (C)   No licensee or his agent shall:
      1.   Sell more than one drink of alcoholic liquor for the price of one
drink of alcoholic liquor;
      2.   Sell, offer to sell or serve to any person an unlimited number of
drinks of alcoholic liquor during any set period of time for a fixed price,
except at private functions not open to the general public or as provided in
235 ILCS 5/6-28;
      3.   Increase the volume of alcoholic liquor contained in a drink, or the
size of a drink of alcoholic liquor, without increasing proportionately the
price regularly charged for the drink on that day;
      4.   Encourage or permit, on the licensed premises, any game or contest
which involves drinking alcoholic liquor or the awarding of drinks of alcoholic
liquor as prizes for such game or contest on the licensed premises; or
      5.   Advertise or promote in any way, whether on or off the licensed
premises, any of the practices prohibited under subsections (C)1. through 4.
   A violation of this Section shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of
the retailer’s license as provided by 235 ILCS 5/6-28.
   (D)   Nothing in subsection (C) shall be construed to prohibit a licensee
from:
      1.   Offering free food or entertainment at any time;
      2.   Including drinks of alcoholic liquor as part of a meal package;
      3.   Including drinks of alcoholic liquor as part of a hotel package;
      4.   Negotiating drinks of alcoholic liquor as part of a contract between
a hotel or multi-use establishment and another group for the holding of any
function, meeting, convention or trade show;
      5.   Providing room service to persons renting rooms at a hotel;
      6.   Selling pitchers, or the equivalent, including but not limited to
buckets, carafes, or bottles of alcoholic liquor which are customarily sold in
such manner and delivered to two or more persons at one time; or
      7.   Increasing prices of drinks of alcoholic liquor in lieu of, in whole
or in part, a cover charge to offset the cost of special entertainment not
regularly scheduled.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-44: TRAINING REQUIRED:
   (A)   All liquor licensees serving alcohol must have a minimum of one
alcohol server on-duty that has completed Beverage Alcohol Sellers and Servers
Education and Training (“BASSET”) and obtained BASSET certification.
   (B)   For purposes of this section, “alcohol servers” means persons who sell
or serve open containers of alcoholic beverages at retail and anyone whose job
description entails the checking of identification for the purchase of open
containers of alcoholic beverages at retail or for entry into the licensed
premises including all liquor managers and management personnel at the premises
license for sale of alcoholic beverage for on-premises consumption.
   (C)   BASSET certification shall be obtained from a program licensed by the
State of Illinois Liquor Control Commission and meeting the requirements of 235
ILCS 5/6-27.1 and 77 Ill. Adm. Code 3500, as amended from time to time.
   (D)   A copy of a valid BASSET certification for the on-duty alcohol server
(s) shall be available at the license premises for inspection by the city
police department, the local liquor control commissioner or his designee.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-45: ADOPTION OF STATE LAW BY REFERENCE:
   Each and every part, provision and section of the Liquor Control Act of 1934
(235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.), as amended, and regulations promulgated hereunder
which relate in any manner to the sale at retail of alcoholic liquor, is hereby
adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter, to the same extent and
with the same legal effect as if fully set forth herein except as otherwise
specifically changed or amended in this chapter. Any violation of such
applicable and accepted provisions of said Act shall be deemed a violation of
this chapter and be subject to the penalties provided herein.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-46: SET-UP ESTABLISHMENTS PROHIBITED:
   It is unlawful for any person to operate a set-up establishment in the city.
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-47: ADULT RESPONSIBILITY:
   (A)   No person 21 years of age or older who owns, possesses, operates,
supervises or controls any premises within the city shall knowingly permit any
person under 21 years of age to possess or consume any alcoholic liquor on such
premises.
   (B)   It shall be an affirmative defense to any action under this section
that the person 21 years of age or older asked for, was shown and reasonably
reliable upon a driver’s license or other written evidence of age and identity
as described in section 6-108.
   (C)   It shall not be a violation of this section to allow a person under 21
years of age to possess, dispense or consume alcoholic liquor as part of a
religious ceremony or service.
   (D)   The penalty for a violation of this section shall be a fine of not
less than $150.00 nor more than $750.00.
   (E)   No parent shall give or deliver alcoholic liquor to his or her child
if that child is of nonage for the child’s consumption, unless the consumption
of alcoholic liquor is in the performance of a religious service or ceremony
under the direction, supervision and approval of the parent of such child in
the privacy of a home.
   (F)   No parent or other person shall intentionally, knowingly, recklessly
or negligently give or deliver alcoholic liquor to, or permit possession of
alcoholic liquor by his or her child, or any other person under the age of 21,
unless such child or person under the age of 21 is making a delivery of such
alcoholic liquor in pursuance of his employment as allowed.
   (G)   No parent or other person shall intentionally, knowingly, recklessly
or negligently give, deliver, invite or permit the consumption of alcoholic
liquor by any person of nonage on or about any premises owned, leased or
controlled by such parent or person except as otherwise allowed by subsection
(E).
   (H)   Parents shall restrain or prevent their children from consuming
alcoholic liquor where the parent knows, or in the exercise of ordinary care
should know, of a substantial probability that his or her child is or will
consume alcoholic liquor under circumstances which would violate the provisions
of this chapter, the Illinois Liquor Control Act, or any other ordinances,
statutes or amendments thereto.
   (I)   Parents who know, or in the exercise of ordinary care should know, of
a substantial probability that their child has consumed or will consume
alcoholic liquor in violation of this chapter, the Illinois Liquor Control Act,
or any other ordinances, statues or amendments thereto, shall restrain or
prevent their child from operating or driving a motor vehicle on the public
streets and ways of the city in violation of any ordinance, law or statute.
   (J)   Parents who know, or in the exercise of ordinary care should know, of
a substantial probability that their child has consumed or will consume
alcoholic liquor in violation of this chapter, the Illinois Liquor Control Act,
or any other ordinances, statues or amendments thereto, shall restrain or
prevent their child from committing acts which constitute vandalism, theft,
disorderly conduct or the unjustifiable use of force in violation of any
ordinance, law or statute.
   (K)   No parent or other person shall rent, or otherwise permit the use of
any hotel or motel sleeping rooms, or suites, when such person knows, or in the
exercise of ordinary care, should know of a substantial probability that such
space will be used by persons of nonage for the consumption or possession,
either actual or constructive, of alcoholic liquor, except as otherwise allowed
by subsection (E).
(Ord. 1890, 5-6-2024)
5-18-48: RESTRICTIONS ON THE GENERAL PUBLIC:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to peddle alcoholic liquor anywhere within the
city.
   (B)   Except as provided in subsection (D), no driver may transport, carry,
possess or have any alcoholic liquor within the passenger area of any motor
vehicle upon a highway in this state except in the original container and with
the seal unbroken.
   (C)   Except as provided in subsection (D), no passenger may carry, possess
or have any alcoholic liquor within any passenger area of any motor vehicle
upon a highway in this state except in the original container and with the seal
unbroken.
   (D)   This section shall not apply to the passengers in a limousine when it
is being used for purposes for which a limousine is ordinarily used, the
passengers on a chartered bus when it is being used for purposes for which
chartered buses are ordinarily used or on a motor home or mini motor home as
defined in 625 ILCS 5/1-145.01. However, the driver of any such vehicle is
prohibited from consuming or having any alcoholic liquor in or about the
driver’s area. Any evidence of alcoholic consumption by the driver shall be
prima facie evidence of such driver’s failure to obey this section. For the
purposes of this section, a limousine is a motor vehicle of the first division
