CHAPTER 8
VEHICLE EQUIPMENT
SECTION:
9-8-1: Flag Or Light At End Of Load
9-8-2: Mufflers
9-8-3: Spilling Contents Of Load Upon Streets
9-8-4: Horns
9-8-5: Lights
9-8-6: Obstructions To Operator's View, Driving Mechanism
9-8-7: Prohibition Of The Use Of Mechanical Exhaust Braking Devices
9-8-1: FLAG OR LIGHT AT END OF LOAD:
Whenever the load on any vehicle shall extend more than four feet (4') beyond
the rear of the bed or body thereof, there shall be displayed at the end of
such load in such position as to be clearly visible at all times from the rear
of such vehicle a red flag not less than twelve inches (12") both in length and
width, except that between one-half (1/2) hour after sunset and one-half (1/2)
hour before sunrise there shall be displayed at the end of such load a red
light plainly visible under normal atmospheric conditions at least two hundred
feet (200') from the rear of the vehicle. (1972 Code)
9-8-2: MUFFLERS:
   (A)   No person shall drive a motor vehicle on a highway unless such motor
vehicle is equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant
operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise and annoying smoke.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to use a muffler cutout on any motor vehicle on a
highway. (1972 Code)
9-8-3: SPILLING CONTENTS OF LOAD UPON STREETS:
No vehicle shall be driven or moved on a highway unless such vehicle is so
constructed or loaded as to prevent its contents from dripping, sifting,
leaking or otherwise escaping therefrom. (1972 Code)
9-8-4: HORNS:
   (A)   A person driving a vehicle within the city must have same properly
equipped with a horn, bell or other device for signaling by sound, to give
warning of its approach; no horn, bell or other signaling device to be used
except as necessary to give warning.
   (B)   Siren signaling devices shall not be used on any vehicle except those
operated by the police department, fire department and authorized public
utility vehicles when on emergency calls. (1972 Code)
9-8-5: LIGHTS:
When upon any public highway in the city during the period from one hour after
sunset to sunrise, every motor bicycle shall carry one lighted lamp and every
motor vehicle two (2) lighted lamps showing white lights, or lights of a yellow
or amber tint, visible at least two hundred feet (200') in the direction toward
which each motor bicycle or motor vehicle is proceeding, and each motor vehicle
or trailer shall also exhibit at least one lighted lamp which shall be so
situated as to throw a red light visible in the reverse direction. No motor
vehicle or motor bicycle, except those used for fire apparatus, police patrols
or ambulances shall have any lamps which show a red or green light in the
direction in which the motor vehicle or motor bicycle is proceeding. On
approaching another vehicle proceeding in an opposite direction, and when
within not less than two hundred fifty feet (250') of same, any person in
charge of a motor bicycle or motor vehicle equipped with electric headlights
shall dim, dip or extinguish such headlights. (1972 Code)
9-8-6: OBSTRUCTIONS TO OPERATOR'S VIEW, DRIVING MECHANISM:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to drive the same
when such vehicle is so loaded, or when there are in the front seat of the
vehicle such number of persons, as to obstruct the view of the operator to the
front or sides, or to interfere with the operator's control over the driving
mechanism of the vehicle.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any passenger in a vehicle to ride in such a
position as to interfere with the operator's view ahead, or to the sides or to
interfere with the operator's control over the driving mechanism of the
vehicle. (1972 Code)
9-8-7: PROHIBITION OF THE USE OF MECHANICAL EXHAUST BRAKING DEVICES:
   (A)   No person shall operate, or cause to be used or operated, within the
city any mechanical exhaust device designed to aid in the braking or
deceleration of any vehicle by converting engine power to compressed air.
   (B)   It shall be affirmative defense that the person operating, or causing
to be used or operated, such mechanical exhaust device in circumstances where
it was necessary to avoid injury or an accident.
   (C)   Any person violating the terms and provisions of this section shall be
subject to penalties as provided in section
9-13-1 of this title.
   (D)   The city shall provide notice of the prohibition created by this
section by posting clearly visible signs on all truck routes at or near the
entrances to the city, utilizing city signs off of state right of way or on
state right of way with Illinois department of transportation authority.
   (E)   Any motion, order, resolution, or ordinance, or part thereof, in
conflict with the terms and provisions of this section shall be and hereby is
to extent of any such conflict hereby superseded and waived.
   (F)   If any sentence, clause or other part of this section shall be found
to be void, invalid, or unconstitutional, then such finding shall not affect
the remaining portions of this section. (Ord. 1042, 9-4-2001)
CHAPTER 9
MISCELLANEOUS DRIVING RULES
SECTION:
9-9-1: Unattended Vehicles
9-9-2: Coasters, Roller Skates, Similar Devices
9-9-3: Clinging To Moving Vehicles
9-9-4: Driving Through Processions
9-9-5: Starting Parked Vehicle
9-9-6: Crossing Fire Hose
9-9-7: Riding On Handlebars
9-9-8: Zones Of Quiet
9-9-9: Safety Zone
9-9-10: Golf Carts
9-9-1: UNATTENDED VEHICLES:
No person having control or charge of a motor vehicle shall allow such vehicle
to stand on any street unattended without first setting the brakes thereon and
stopping the motor of the vehicle, and when standing upon a perceptible grade,
without turning the wheels of the vehicle to the curb or the side of the street
or highway. (1972 Code)
9-9-2: COASTERS, ROLLER SKATES, SIMILAR DEVICES:
It shall be unlawful for any person rollerskating, or riding in or by means of
any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device to go upon any roadway except while
crossing a street on a crosswalk. (1972 Code)
9-9-3: CLINGING TO MOVING VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person traveling upon any bicycle, motorcycle,
coaster, sled, roller skates or any toy vehicle to cling to, or attach himself
or his vehicle to any other moving vehicle upon any roadway. (1972 Code)
9-9-4: DRIVING THROUGH PROCESSIONS:
It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to drive between the
vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in
motion; provided, that said vehicles are conspicuously designated. (1972 Code)
9-9-5: STARTING PARKED VEHICLE:
The driver of a parked vehicle about to start shall give moving vehicles the
right of way and the driver of a parked vehicle shall give a timely and visible
warning in some unmistakable manner before starting. (1972 Code)
9-9-6: CROSSING FIRE HOSE:
No vehicle shall be driven over any unprotected hose of the fire department
when laid down on any street, private driveway or track to be used at any fire
or alarm of fire, without the consent of the fire chief or fire department
official in command. (1972 Code)
9-9-7: RIDING ON HANDLEBARS:
It shall be unlawful for the operator of any bicycle or motorcycle, when upon
the streets, to carry any other person upon the handlebars, frame or tank of
any such vehicle, or for any person to so ride upon any such vehicle. (1972
Code)
9-9-8: ZONES OF QUIET:
The chief of police may declare any street or alley within two hundred feet
(200') of a hospital, school or church a zone of quiet, and in this zone, when
so declared, there shall be no ringing of bells, sounding of horns, gongs or
whistles or itinerant music. (1972 Code)
9-9-9: SAFETY ZONE:
It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle at any time to drive the
same over or through a "safety zone" as defined in this title. (1972 Code)
9-9-10: GOLF CARTS:
   (A)   Subject to the subsequent provisions of this section, the city shall
allow the operation of golf carts on municipal streets, roads and highways
within the corporate limits of the city where the city has exclusive
jurisdiction over the street, road or highway. Nothing contained in this
section shall allow the operation of a golf cart on U.S. Route 6 or Illinois
Route 89 within the corporate limits of the city.
   (B)   Any golf cart operated on a street, road or highway within the
corporate limits of the city must, at a minimum, have the following safety
equipment: brakes, steering apparatus, tires, a rearview mirror, red
reflectorized warning devices in the front and rear, slow moving emblem 1  on
the rear of the golf cart, a headlight that emits a white light visible from a
distance of five hundred feet (500') to the front, a taillamp that emits a red
light visible from at least one hundred feet (100') from the rear, brake
lights, and turn signals. When operated on a roadway, a golf cart shall have
its headlight and taillamps lighted as required by section 12-201 of the
Illinois vehicle code.
   (C)   No person shall operate a golf cart on the streets, roads or highways
within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a permit from
the police department. In order to obtain a permit from the police department
to operate a golf cart on the streets, roads and highways of the city, the
person applying for the permit must possess a valid Illinois driver's license,
provide proof of liability insurance in the minimum amounts set forth under the
mandatory insurance provisions contained in the Illinois vehicle code and the
Illinois insurance code, and prove that they have a physical handicap or
disability which would entitle the person to a handicap license registration
plate under the provisions set forth for issuing said plates in the Illinois
vehicle code. (Ord. 924, 2-15-1999)
 
Notes
1 1. As required of other vehicles in section 12-709 of the Illinois vehicle
  code.
CHAPTER 10
PARKING METER REGULATIONS
SECTION:
9-10-1: Parking Meter Zones Created
9-10-2: Installation Of Meters
9-10-3: Regulations
9-10-4: Placement; Operation Of Meters
9-10-5: Curb Markings; Spaces Designated
9-10-6: Deposit Of Coins Required
9-10-7: Lawful Occupancy Of Space; Overtime Parking
9-10-8: Injury To Meters
9-10-9: Deposit Of Unlawful Coin
9-10-10: Violations; Report Of Police Officers
9-10-11: Appearance; Payment Of Fine
9-10-12: Purpose; Disposition Of Coins
9-10-13: Meter Collectors; Bond Required
9-10-1: PARKING METER ZONES CREATED:
Parking meter zones as defined herein are hereby created on the following
streets of the city:
Greenwood Street from Erie Street to St. Paul Street; and from St. Paul Street
to Devlin Street.
Spalding Street from Erie Street to Devlin Street.
St. Paul Street from Power Street to Terry Street. (Ord., 12-6-1976)
9-10-2: INSTALLATION OF METERS:
In the parking meter zones the mayor shall cause parking meters to be installed
in such numbers and at such places as may be necessary to the regulations,
control and inspection of the parking of vehicles therein, including the
reservation of loading zones for commercial vehicles and shall cause parking
meter spaces to be designated as hereinafter provided. (1972 Code)
9-10-3: REGULATIONS:
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle or to permit a vehicle to remain
parked in any parking meter zone without use of a parking meter except on
Sundays and legal holidays in the state of Illinois during the periods
hereinafter designated:
Monday from nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to eight o'clock (8:00) P.M.
Tuesday from nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to five thirty o'clock (5:30) P.M.
Wednesday from nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to five thirty o'clock (5:30) P.M.
Thursday from nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to twelve o'clock (12:00) noon
Friday from nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to eight o'clock (8:00) P.M.
Saturday from nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to five thirty o'clock (5:30) P.M. (1972
Code)
9-10-4: PLACEMENT; OPERATION OF METERS:
The parking meters installed in the parking meter zones as established and
provided for in section
9-10-1 of this chapter shall be placed upon the curb immediately adjacent to
the individual parking places hereinafter described. Each parking meter shall
be placed or set in such manner as to show or display by a signal that the
parking space adjacent to such meter is or is not legally in use. Each parking
meter installed shall indicate by a proper legend the legal parking time
established by the city and when operated shall indicate on and by its dial and
pointer the duration of the period of legal parking and on the expiration of
such period, shall indicate illegal or overparking. (1972 Code)
9-10-5: CURB MARKINGS; SPACES DESIGNATED:
The mayor shall have markings painted or placed upon the curb and/or upon the
street adjacent to each parking meter for the purpose of designating the
parking space for which the meter is to be used and each vehicle parking
adjacent to any parking meter shall park within the lines or markings so
established. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter to park any
vehicle across any such line or marking or to park the vehicle in such position
that the same shall not be entirely within the area so designated by such lines
or markings.
When a parking space in any parking meter zone is parallel with the adjacent
curb or sidewalk, any vehicle parked in such parking space shall be parked so
that the foremost part of the vehicle shall be alongside of and next to the
parking meter. When a parking space in any parking meter zone is diagonal to
the curb or sidewalk any vehicle parked in such parking space shall be parked
with the foremost part of such vehicle directed at and next to the meter. (1972
Code)
9-10-6: DEPOSIT OF COINS REQUIRED:
When any vehicle shall be parked in any space adjacent to which a parking meter
is located in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, the operator of
the vehicle shall, upon entering the parking space, immediately deposit or
cause to be deposited a one cent ($0.01) or five cent ($0.05) coin of the
United States, in the parking meter, and put the meter in operation, and
failure to deposit such coin and put the meter in operation shall constitute a
violation of this chapter and shall subject the person to the penalty
prescribed hereinafter. (1972 Code)
9-10-7: LAWFUL OCCUPANCY OF SPACE; OVERTIME PARKING:
Upon placing the meter in operation as aforesaid, the parking space may be
lawfully occupied by the vehicle for a period of twelve (12) consecutive
minutes for each one cent ($0.01) coin of the United States deposited therein
up to one hundred twenty (120) minutes, or for a period of sixty (60)
consecutive minutes for each five cent ($0.05) coin of the United States
deposited therein up to one hundred twenty (120) minutes and payment of the
aforesaid amounts for the foregoing periods shall be made for parking in the
areas set forth hereinbefore. If any vehicle shall remain parked in any such
parking space beyond the parking time limit as fixed by the coins deposited in
the meter for such parking space, the parking meter shall by its dial and
pointer indicate such illegal parking and in that event, the vehicle shall be
considered parked overtime and beyond the period of legal parking time and
shall constitute a violation of this chapter and the owner or operator thereof
shall be punished as hereinafter set forth. (1972 Code)
9-10-8: INJURY TO METERS:
It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this chapter for any
person to deface, injure, tamper with, open or wilfully break, destroy or
impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed under the provisions of
this chapter. (1972 Code)
9-10-9: DEPOSIT OF UNLAWFUL COIN:
It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this chapter to
deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter, any slug, device or
metallic substitute, or any other substitute for a one cent ($0.01) or five
cent ($0.05) coin of the United States. (1972 Code)
9-10-10: VIOLATIONS; REPORT OF POLICE OFFICERS:
It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city, acting in accordance
with instructions issued by the chief of police to report:
   (A)   The number of each parking meter which indicates that the vehicle
occupying the parking space adjacent to such parking meter is or has been
parking in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   The state license number of such vehicle.
   (C)   The time the vehicle is parking in violation of any of the provisions
of this chapter.
   (D)   Any other facts or knowledge of which is necessary to a thorough
understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. Each such police
officer shall also attach to such vehicle a notice to the owner or operator
thereof that such vehicle has been parked in violation of a provision of this
chapter instructing such owner or operator to report to the police department
in regard to such violation. Each such owner or operator may within twenty four
(24) hours of the time when such notice was attached to such vehicle pay to the
officer in charge the sum of twenty five cents ($0.25) at the police station or
deposit twenty five cents ($0.25) in the collection box as a penalty for and in
full satisfaction of such violation; provided further, that one recheck, if the
vehicle continues to remain parked in violation the officer shall attach a
second notice, and the owner or operator may within twenty four (24) hours of
the time when such second notice was attached to the vehicle: pay to the
officer in charge the sum of one dollar ($1.00) at the police station or
deposit one dollar ($1.00) in the collection box as a penalty for such second
violation. The failure of the owner or operator to make such payment within
twenty four (24) hours shall render the owner or operator subject to the
penalties provided in this code.
Each such police officer shall also attach to the vehicle a notice to the owner
or operator thereof that such vehicle has been parked in violation of a
provision of this chapter instructing the owner or operator to report to the
police department in regard to such violation. (1972 Code)
9-10-11: APPEARANCE; PAYMENT OF FINE:
Each owner or operator may, within twenty four (24) hours of the time when the
notice was attached to such vehicle pay to the desk sergeant at the police
station as a penalty, for and in full satisfaction of the violation, the sum of
fifty cents ($0.50). The failure of the owner or operator to make such payment
within twenty four (24) hours, shall render the owner or operator subject to
the general penalties provided for by this code. (1972 Code)
9-10-12: PURPOSE; DISPOSITION OF COINS:
The coins required to be deposited in parking meters as provided herein are
hereby levied and assessed as fees to provide for the proper regulation and
control of traffic upon the streets, and also the cost of supervision and
regulation of the parking of vehicles in the parking meter zones created
hereby, and to cover the cost of purchasing, leasing, acquiring, installation,
operation, maintenance, supervision, regulation and control of the parking
meters described herein. (1972 Code)
9-10-13: METER COLLECTORS; BOND REQUIRED:
The mayor shall designate such collectors and methods as are necessary to
properly collect all coins deposited in the meter boxes. Collectors shall be
only such employees as are now or hereafter duly bonded in a sum of not less
than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the faithful performance of their
duties. All money so collected shall be deposited with the clerk; provided,
however, a separate fund shall be maintained at all times of such money so
deposited. (1972 Code)
CHAPTER 11
SPEED
SECTION:
9-11-1: Speed Restrictions
9-11-2: Special Speed Limits While Passing Schools
9-11-3: Traffic Not To Be Obstructed
9-11-4: Special Speed Limits In City Park Areas
9-11-5: Speed Limits Enacted For Certain Areas
9-11-1: SPEED RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful to drive any motor vehicle on any street not under the
jurisdiction of the Illinois state department of public works and buildings, or
the county, in an urban district within the city at a speed in excess of thirty
(30) miles per hour, or in an alley at a speed in excess of fifteen (15) miles
per hour.
Provided, that if the mayor and city council by ordinance, set other limits as
provided by statute 1  after an engineering or traffic survey, then such limits
shall govern the rate of speed on the streets indicated in such ordinance.
Appropriate signs shall be posted showing such speed limits. (1972 Code)

9-11-2: SPECIAL SPEED LIMITS WHILE PASSING SCHOOLS:
No person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of twenty (20) miles
per hour while passing a school zone or while traveling upon any public
thoroughfare on or across which children pass going to and from a school during
school days when schoolchildren are present, said school zone shall include any
public thoroughfare hereafter designated as a school zone by the council,
including areas of traffic to and from schools located within the corporate
limits of the city. Appropriate signs shall be posted to indicate this
restriction. Said zones shall include the following:
Dakota Street from Cornelia Street to Power Street.
Dakota Street from Lawrence Avenue to Ladd Road.
Dakota Street from Strong Avenue to Terry Street.
Erie Street from Barton Street to Power Street.
John Mitchell Avenue from Dakota Street to Devlin Street.
Ladd Road from Fourth Street to Dakota Street.
Mary Street from Dakota Street to Erie Street.
Richards Street from Dakota Street to Fourth Street.
Strong Avenue from Dakota Street to Fourth Street. (1972 Code)
9-11-3: TRAFFIC NOT TO BE OBSTRUCTED:
No vehicle shall be operated or allowed to remain upon the street in such a
manner as to form an unreasonable obstruction to the traffic thereon. (1972
Code)
9-11-4: SPECIAL SPEED LIMITS IN CITY PARK AREAS:
No person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of twenty (20) miles
per hour while passing any city park area, except in the area of Kirby Park
where no person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of fifteen
(15) miles per hour. Appropriate signs shall be posted to indicate this
restriction. (1972 Code)
9-11-5: SPEED LIMITS ENACTED FOR CERTAIN AREAS:
   (A)   No person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of twenty
(20) miles per hour on the following designated streets:
   Hickory Road.
Marquette Road from Dakota Street to the south corporate limits of the city.
Oakridge Drive.
Ramblewood Lane.
St. Paul Street from the intersection of Cornelia Street to the intersection of
Gallagher Street.
Timber Ridge Drive. (Ord., 4-18-1977; amd. Ord. 427, 11-20-1978; Ord. 818, 7-5-
1994)
   (B)   No person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of twenty
five (25) miles per hour on the following designated streets:
Dakota Street from John Mitchell Avenue to Marquette Road.
Greenwood Street from Dakota Street to the Peru-Princeton Road.
Power Street from Dakota Street to Fifth Street.
St. Paul Street from the intersection of Cornelia Street to the intersection of
Power Street. (Ord., 6-20-1977; amd. Ord. 818, 7-5-1994)
Appropriate signs shall be posted by the superintendent of public works to
indicate the aforesaid speed restrictions. (Ord., 6-20-1977)
   (C)   No person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of fifteen
(15) miles per hour on John F. Kennedy Drive between Strong Street extended and
Richards Avenue extended. (Ord. 828, 10-3-1994)
   (D)   No person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of forty
five (45) miles per hour on County Road 1500 North Avenue from Illinois Route
89 east to the village of Dalzell city limits. (Ord. 1043, 9-4-2001)
   (E)   No person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of twenty
(20) miles per hour on the following streets located within the corporate
limits of the city of Spring Valley: Mary Jane Lane, Janie Avenue, Sandy Drive
and Tyler Huge Road. (Ord. 1588, 11-24-2014)
CHAPTER 12
BICYCLES
SECTION:
9-12-1: Effect Of Regulations
9-12-2: Traffic Laws Apply To Persons Riding Bicycles
9-12-3: Requirement Of License
9-12-4: License Application
9-12-5: Licenses Issued
9-12-6: Transfer Of Bicycle Ownership
9-12-7: Attachment Of License
9-12-8: Inspection Of Bicycles
9-12-9: Equipment On Bicycles
9-12-10: Operation Of Bicycles
9-12-11: Bicycle Dealers
9-12-12: Penalty
9-12-13: License Not To Be Mutilated
9-12-14: Suspension And Removal
9-12-1: EFFECT OF REGULATIONS:
It is a misdemeanor for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform
any act required in this chapter. The parent of any child and the guardian of
any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to
violate any of the provisions of this chapter. The regulations applicable to
bicycles shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon a highway or public
way or upon any path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles subject to
those exceptions stated herein.
For the purposes of sections
9-12-2,
9-12-10,
9-12-12, and
9-12-14 of this chapter, a "bicycle" shall be defined as any device propelled
by human power upon which any person may ride having two (2) tandem wheels,
except scooters and similar devices, and specifically including skateboards and
in-line skates. For all other sections of this chapter, a "bicycle" shall be
defined as any device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride
having two (2) tandem wheels either of which is more than sixteen inches (16")
in diameter. (Ord. 892, 8-18-1997)
9-12-2: TRAFFIC LAWS APPLY TO PERSONS RIDING BICYCLES:
Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be subject to the provisions
of the traffic ordinances of the city applicable to the driver of a vehicle
except as to special regulations of this chapter and except as to those
provisions of the ordinances which, by their nature, can have no application.
(1972 Code)
9-12-3: REQUIREMENT OF LICENSE:
No bicycle shall be ridden on the streets of the city or public way by the
owner or any other person unless properly licensed. (1972 Code)
9-12-4: LICENSE APPLICATION:
Application for license to own and operate a bicycle shall be made to the chief
of police upon a form to be provided by the chief of police. The application
shall be accompanied by a fee of twenty five cents ($0.25) to be paid at the
time of issuance of the license, which fee shall be in full payment of said
license for one year. (1972 Code)
9-12-5: LICENSES ISSUED:
The chief of police shall have authority to issue, upon written application,
bicycle licenses, which shall be effective for one year. All such licenses
shall be dated May 1 of the year issued, except the license issued on August 1,
1972, shall expire on April 30, 1973. The license issued shall bear the year
1972 on it. The chief of police shall register all licenses issued and shall
keep records of all fees collected for issuance of such licenses. Said records
shall be public records. All license fees collected by the chief of police
shall be turned over to the city clerk, who, in turn, shall turn same over to
the city treasurer. (1972 Code)
9-12-6: TRANSFER OF BICYCLE OWNERSHIP:
Upon the sale or transfer of a licensed bicycle, the licensee thereof shall
remove and surrender to the chief of police the attached license, or may have
such license assigned gratis to another bicycle owned by him. (1972 Code)
9-12-7: ATTACHMENT OF LICENSE:
Upon the issuance of a license, such license shall be firmly attached to the
frame of the bicycle in such a position as to be plainly visible from the rear.
The removal of any such license except by proper authority or upon transfer of
ownership shall be a violation of this chapter. (1972 Code)
9-12-8: INSPECTION OF BICYCLES:
Under the supervision of the chief of police, each bicycle shall be inspected
before licensing and the chief of police shall have the authority to refuse to
issue a license for any such bicycle found to be in an unsafe mechanical
condition. (1972 Code)
9-12-9: EQUIPMENT ON BICYCLES:
   (A)   Brakes On Bicycles: Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake
adequate to control the movement of and to stop such bicycle whenever
necessary.
   (B)   Lamps And Reflectors On Bicycles: Every bicycle shall be equipped with
a lamp on the front exhibiting a white light visible from a distance of at
least five hundred feet (500') to the front and with a red reflector on the
rear. Every such reflector shall be so designed and maintained as to be visible
at night one hundred feet (100') from such bicycle when directly in front of a
motor vehicle displaying lawfully lighted headlamps. A lamp exhibiting a red
light visible from a distance of one hundred feet (100') to the rear may be
used in addition or in lieu of rear reflector, except that any bicycle not used
after sunset and before sunrise need not be equipped with said lights, but it
shall be a violation of this chapter to operate any bicycle after sunset and
before sunrise without such equipment.
   (C)   Audible Signal: At the option of the owner, it is permissible to have
a horn or bell, but no siren or whistle is allowed on a bicycle. (1972 Code)
9-12-10: OPERATION OF BICYCLES:
   (A)   Riding On Bicycles: A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other
than upon or astride the permanent and regular seat attached thereto, nor carry
any other person upon such bicycle other than upon a firmly attached and
regular seat thereon, nor shall any person ride upon a bicycle other than as
above authorized. No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time
than the number for which it is designed and equipped.
   (B)   Right Of Way On Sidewalks: Pedestrians shall have the right of way at
all times over bicycles and a person riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk or
sidewalk crossing shall either turn off the sidewalk when meeting or passing
pedestrians or shall dismount until the pedestrians have passed. No bicycle
shall be ridden at any time on a public sidewalk in front of any place of
business or in front of any public building. No person of the age of twelve
(12) years or older shall ride a bicycle at any time on a public sidewalk in
front of a private residence except those persons actually delivering messages,
mail, newspapers, magazines, advertising matter or merchandise.
   (C)   Speed Of Bicycles: No person riding a bicycle shall ride faster than
is reasonable and proper in regard to the safety of the rider and others.
   (D)   Clinging To Vehicles: Any person riding upon any bicycle shall not
attach the same or himself to any moving vehicle upon a roadway.
   (E)   Riding In A Group: Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not
ride more than two (2) abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside
for the exclusive use of bicycles.
   (F)   Carrying Articles: No person riding a bicycle shall carry any package,
bundle or article which prevents the rider from keeping both hands upon the
handlebars.
   (G)   Trick Riding: No rider of a bicycle shall remove both hands from the
handlebars, or feet from the pedals, or practice any acrobatic or fancy riding
on any street; nor shall any person operating a bicycle upon a public highway
participate in any race for speed or endurance contest with any other vehicle,
except under permit from, and under the supervision of, the chief of police.
   (H)   Parking Bicycles: No person shall park a bicycle upon a roadway.
Bicycles parked in an alley, in a public driveway, on a sidewalk, or on a
public path must be in such a position as not to interfere with the safety or
movement of the vehicular or pedestrian traffic. (1972 Code)
9-12-11: BICYCLE DEALERS:
All persons engaged in the business of buying or selling new or secondhand
bicycles are required to make a written report each month to the chief of
police giving the name and address of the person from or to whom each bicycle
is purchased or sold, the description thereof, the frame number thereof, and
the number of the license found thereon. (1972 Code)
9-12-12: PENALTY:
Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be
punished by a fine of not less than two dollars ($2.00) nor more than five
dollars ($5.00) or by revocation of such person's license for a period not to
exceed six (6) months or by both such fine and license revocation. (1972 Code)
9-12-13: LICENSE NOT TO BE MUTILATED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully or maliciously destroy,
mutilate or alter the number of any bicycle license pursuant to this chapter.
Within seven (7) days after any bicycle registered hereunder shall change
ownership or be dismantled and taken out of operation, the person in whose name
the bicycle has been registered shall report such information to the chief of
police. It shall also be unlawful for any person to remove, destroy, mutilate
or alter any license tag, seal or registration card during the time in which
such license tag, seal or registration card shall operate. (1972 Code)
9-12-14: SUSPENSION AND REMOVAL:
The chief of police shall have authority to suspend the registration of and
remove the license from any bicycle operated contrary to any state law or city
ordinance, such suspension and removal to continue for a period not to exceed
ten (10) days. Such suspension and removal shall be in addition to other
penalties provided hereunder. The police department is hereby authorized to
seize and impound a bicycle of any person who shall violate any of the
provisions of this chapter and require said violator to acquaint himself or
herself with the rules of the road or of this chapter pertaining to the
violation for which the bicycle was impounded before the same is released.
(1972 Code)
CHAPTER 13
PENALTY
SECTION:
9-13-1: Penalty
9-13-2: Arrests
9-13-3: Prima Facie Proof
9-13-4: Parking Fines
9-13-1: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this title, except as provided in section
9-13-4 of this chapter, shall be fined not less than twenty dollars ($20.00)
nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 883, 6-2-
1997)
9-13-2: ARRESTS:
Any person arrested for a violation of any provision of this title shall be
released upon proper bail being furnished as required by law. (1972 Code)
9-13-3: PRIMA FACIE PROOF:
The fact that an automobile which is illegally operated or parked is registered
in the name of a person shall be considered prima facie proof that such person
was in control of the automobile at the time of such violation. (1972 Code)
9-13-4: PARKING FINES:
Any person violating the following provisions of this title shall be fined as
set forth below. Any person disputing the validity of a ticket issued pursuant
to any of the following sections of this title shall be entitled to an
administrative hearing before the chief of police at which time said individual
may present evidence to the chief of police limited to the following issues: a)
whether the violation alleged in the ticket in fact occurred; b) whether the
individual received notification of the parking citation; and c) whether the
individual made the payments called for in this section within the time periods
provided for herein.
   (A)   Any person violating any of the provisions of sections
9-5-1 through
9-5-12 of this title shall be fined twenty dollars ($20.00) for each offense
and, if said fine is not paid within seven (7) days after the date of the
issuance of the parking citation the fine shall be forty dollars ($40.00) for
each offense.
   (B)   Any person violating sections
9-5-13 and
9-5-14 of this title shall be fined fifty dollars ($50.00) for each offense
and, if said fine is not paid within seven (7) days after the issuance of the
parking citation, the fine shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each
offense.
   (C)   Any person violating section
9-16-1 of this title shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) and, if said
fine is not paid within seven (7) days after the date of the issuance of the
parking citation, the fine shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each
offense.
   (D)   Any person who shall fail to pay a parking fine provided for herein,
or request an administrative hearing as set forth herein, within seven (7) days
after the date of the issuance of the parking citation, shall be deemed to be
in violation of this code and shall be subject to being served with a
nontraffic complaint in Bureau County circuit court requiring the defendant to
appear in Bureau County circuit court. (Ord. 883, 6-2-1997)
CHAPTER 14
CONTROL OF UNWARRANTED NOISES
SECTION:
9-14-1: Operation Of Motors Restricted
9-14-2: Horns, Signaling Devices
9-14-3: Test Procedures To Conform
9-14-4: Test Procedures, Maximum Noise
9-14-5: Nuisances Declared
9-14-6: Violation; Penalty
9-14-1: OPERATION OF MOTORS RESTRICTED:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor for a
consecutive period longer than two (2) minutes while such vehicle is standing
on private property and located within one hundred fifty feet (150') of
property zoned and used for residential purposes except where such vehicle is
standing within a completely enclosed structure.
This section shall not apply to buses operated for the transportation of
passengers while standing in established bus turnarounds, bus terminals, bus
parking lots and bus storage yards.
   (B)   No person shall sell, or offer for sale, use or operate a new motor
vehicle that produces a maximum noise exceeding the following noise limit at a
distance of fifty feet (50') from the centerline of travel under test
procedures established by section
9-14-3 of this chapter:
 
Vehicle                                 Manufacture           Limit
Motorcycle                              After January 1, 1976 70 dB(A)
Passenger cars and other motor vehicles After January 1, 1976 70 dB(A)
Truck                                   After January 1, 1976 75 dB(A)
 
The manufacturer, distributor, importer or designated agent shall certify in
writing to the commissioner that his vehicles sold within the city comply with
the provisions of this section.
   (C)   No person shall operate within the speed limits specified in this
section either a motor vehicle or combination of vehicles of a type subject to
registration at any time or under any condition of grade, load, acceleration or
deceleration in such manner as to exceed the following noise limit for the
category of motor vehicle, based on a distance of not less than fifty feet
(50') from the centerline of travel under the procedures established by section
9-14-4 of this chapter.
 
Type Of Vehicle                       Noise Limit In Relation To Posted Speed
                                      Limit 35 MPH Or Less
Motorcycle after January 1, 1976      70 dB(A)
Truck after January 1, 1976           75 dB(A)
Any other motor vehicle after January 70 dB(A)
1, 1976
 
   (D)   No person shall modify or change the exhaust muffler, intake muffler
or any other noise abatement device of a motor in a manner such that the noise
emitted by the motor vehicle is increased above that emitted by the vehicle as
originally manufactured. Procedures used to establish compliance with this
paragraph shall be those used to establish compliance of a new motor vehicle
with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord., 12-15-1975)
9-14-2: HORNS, SIGNALING DEVICES:
No person shall sound any horn or audible signal device of any motor vehicle of
any kind while not in motion, nor shall such horn or signal device be sounded
under any circumstances except as required by law, nor shall it be sounded for
any unnecessary or unreasonable period of time. (1972 Code)
9-14-3: TEST PROCEDURES TO CONFORM:
Test procedures to determine whether maximum noise emitted by new motor
vehicles sold or offered for sale meet the noise limits stated in subsection
9-14-1(B) of this chapter shall be in substantial conformity with standards and
recommended practice established by the Society Of Automotive Engineers, Inc.,
including SAE standard J331; SAE recommended practice J184; SAE recommended
practice J366 and SAE standard J986. (1972 Code)
9-14-4: TEST PROCEDURES, MAXIMUM NOISE:
Test procedures to determine whether maximum noise emitted by motor vehicles in
use meet the noise limits stated in subsection
9-14-1(C) of this chapter shall be in substantial conformity with standards and
recommended practice established by the Society Of Automotive Engineers, Inc.,
including, SAE standard J986; SAE standard J331; recommended practice J366 and
recommended practice J184. (1972 Code)
9-14-5: NUISANCES DECLARED:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to impair any cause of action, or
legal remedy therefor, of any person or the public for injury or damage arising
from the emission or release into the atmosphere or ground from any source
whatever or noise or earthshaking vibration in such place or manner, or at such
levels, so as to constitute a common law nuisance. (1972 Code)
9-14-6: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person found guilty of violating, disobeying, omitting, neglecting, or
refusing to comply with, or resisting or opposing the enforcement of any of the
provisions of this chapter, except when otherwise specifically provided, upon
conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifteen dollars
($15.00) nor more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the first offense,
and not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for the second and each subsequent offense, in any one hundred eighty
(180) day period, or shall be punishable as a misdemeanor by incarceration in
the county jail for a term not to exceed six (6) months under the procedure set
forth in section 1-2-1.1 of the Illinois municipal code 1  as amended, or by
both fine and imprisonment. A separate and distinct offense shall be regarded
as committed each day of which such person shall continue or permit such
violation, or failure to comply as permitted to exist after notification
thereof. (1972 Code)

1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1.1.
CHAPTER 15
TRUCK ROUTES
SECTION:
9-15-1: Definitions
9-15-2: Trucks To Be Operated Only On Truck Routes
9-15-3: Exceptions
9-15-4: Truck Routes Established
9-15-5: Deviations From Truck Routes To Reach Destination Points
9-15-6: Enforcement
9-15-7:    Permitting
9-15-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter the following terms shall have the meaning
given herein:
TRUCK: Any vehicle designed or operated for the transportation of property, and
whose body weight or whose combined body and load weight exceeds eight thousand
(8,000) pounds and whose body and load length exceeds twenty five feet (25').
TRUCK ROUTE: A way over certain streets, as designated herein, over and along
which trucks coming into and going out of the city must operate. (Ord. 851, 1-
15-1996; amd. Ord. 1857, 9-7-2022)
9-15-2: TRUCKS TO BE OPERATED ONLY ON TRUCK ROUTES:
All trucks within the city shall be operated only over and along the truck
routes herein established and on the other designated streets over which truck
travel is permitted. (Ord., 4-4-1977)
9-15-3: EXCEPTIONS:
This chapter shall not prohibit:
   (A)   Delivery Truck: Operation of trucks upon any street which is necessary
to the conduct of business at a destination point, provided streets upon which
such traffic is permitted are used until reaching a street that provides the
shortest distance to a truck route from the point of destination or origin
within the city, as the case may be.
Delivery Trucks: The operation of a delivery truck upon any street to a point
for the delivery of property or a point of origin for picking up property when
such operation shall be on a street providing.
   (B)   Emergency Vehicles: The operation of emergency vehicles upon any
street in the city.
   (C)   Public Utilities: The operation of trucks owned or operated by the
city, public utilities, any contractor or material man, while engaged in the
repair, maintenance or construction of streets, street improvements, or street
utilities within the city.
   (D)   Detoured Trucks: The operation of trucks upon any officially
established detour in any case where such truck could lawfully be operated upon
the street for which such detour is established. (Ord., 4-4-1977; amd. Ord.
1857, 9-7-2022)
9-15-4: TRUCK ROUTES ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established within the city the following truck routes:
   (A)   U.S. Route 6.
   (B)   State Route 89.
   (C)   In addition to those streets in the city constituting a part of a
truck route as established herein, all state of Illinois marked highways and no
other streets shall be used for truck traffic. (Ord., 4-4-1977)
9-15-5: DEVIATIONS FROM TRUCK ROUTES TO REACH DESTINATION POINTS:
   (A)   Outside Origin:
      1.   One Inside Destination Point: All trucks entering the city for a
destination point in the city shall proceed only over an established truck
route and shall deviate only at the intersection with the city street, upon
which such traffic is permitted, nearest to the destination point. Upon leaving
the destination point, a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the
shortest permissible route.
      2.   Multiple Inside Destination Points: All trucks entering the city for
multiple destination points shall proceed only over established truck routes
and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street, upon which such
traffic is permitted, nearest to the first destination point. Upon leaving the
first destination point a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by
the shortest permissible route and proceed on the established truck route and
shall deviate only at the intersection with the city street nearest to the next
destination point. Upon leaving the last destination point, a deviating truck
shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route.
   (B)   Inside Origin:
      1.   Outside Destination Point: All trucks, on a trip originating in the
city, and traveling in the city for a destination point outside the city shall
proceed by the shortest direction permitted to a truck route as herein
established.
      2.   Inside Destination Points: All trucks, on a trip originating in the
city and traveling in the city for destination points in the city shall proceed
to a designated truck route by the shortest permissible route and proceed
according to the procedure designated in subsection (A)2 of this section.
   (C)   Outside Origin, Outside Destination:
      1.   All trucks, on a trip originating outside of the city and traveling
within the city to a destination point outside of the city shall remain on
designated truck routes without deviation. (Ord., 4-4-1977; amd. Ord. 540, 4-
19-1982; Ord. 1857, 9-7-2022)
9-15-6: ENFORCEMENT:
   (A)   The superintendent of public works and the chief of police of the city
shall cause all truck routes to be clearly posted to give notice that this
section is in effect and shall further cause signs to be placed at the
following:
No. 3 Coal Mine Road and State Route 29, Millers Cemetery Road and State Route
29, Ladd Road at U.S. Route 6 and State Route 29, Greenwood Street at the Peru-
Princeton Road and at the intersection of Dakota Street, Briarcliff Road at
State Route 29, Marquette Highway at Rock Island Street, and State Route 89 at
the viaduct over the railroad tracks on the south end of Spring Valley,
necessary to give notice that this section is in effect.
      1.   No truck signs shall be posted at the intersection of U.S. Routes 6
and 89 and County Road 1500 N. (commonly referred to as Golf Course Road) and
the intersection of Peru-Princeton Road and North Greenwood Street.
   (B)   Any police officer in the city shall have the authority to require any
person driving or in control of any commercial vehicle not proceeding over a
truck route or street over which truck traffic is permitted to proceed to any
public or private scale available for the purpose of weighing and determining
whether this chapter and the statutes of the State of Illinois governing motor
vehicles have been complied with.
   (C)   The city clerk shall keep and maintain accurate maps setting out truck
routes and streets upon which truck traffic is permitted; the maps shall be
kept on file in the office of the city clerk and shall be available to the
public. (Ord., 4-4-1977; amd. Ord. 540, 4-19-1982; Ord. 1857, 9-7-2022)
9-15-7: PERMITTING:
   (A)   Permits: The owner or operator of any vehicle not otherwise exempt as
provided herein may apply in writing to the municipal officers for a permit to
operate on a posted way or bridge notwithstanding the restrictions described in
this chapter. The municipal officers may issue a permit only upon all of the
following findings:
      1.   No other route is reasonably available to the applicant;
      2.   It is a matter of economic necessity and not mere convenience that
the applicant use the way or bridge; and
      3.   The applicant has tendered cash, a bond or other suitable security
running to the City in an amount sufficient, in their judgment, to repair any
damage to the way or bridge which may reasonably result from the applicants use
of the same.
Even if the corporate authorities or their designated agent make the foregoing
findings, they need not issue a permit if they determine the applicant's use of
the way or bridge could reasonably be expected to create or aggravate a safety
hazard or cause substantial damage. They may also limit the number of permits
issued or outstanding as may, in their judgment, be necessary to preserve and
protect the roadways.
   (B)   Factors To Consider:
      1.   The gross registered weight of the vehicle;
      2.   The current and anticipated condition of the way or bridge;
      3.   The number and frequency of vehicle trips proposed;
      4.   The cost and availability of materials and equipment for repairs;
      5.   The extent of use by other exempt vehicles; and
      6.   Such other circumstances as may, in their judgment, may be relevant.
The municipal officers may issue permits subject to reasonable conditions,
including, but not limited to restriction on the actual load weight and the
number of frequency of vehicle trips, which shall be clearly noted on the
permit.
   (C)   Administration And Enforcement: This rule shall be administered and
may be enforced by the City Clerk, Chief of Police, or their designee.
   (D)   Penalties: Any violation of this section shall be a civil infraction
subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each violation shall be deemed a separate
offense. In addition to any fine, the City may seek restitution for the cost of
repairs to any damaged way or bridge and reasonable attorney's fees and costs.
(Ord. 1857, 9-7-2022)
CHAPTER 16
HANDICAPPED PARKING
SECTION:
9-16-1: Designated Spaces
9-16-2: Private Property Handicapped Parking Designated
9-16-3: Penalty
9-16-1: DESIGNATED SPACES:
The city council hereby designates certain parking areas located within the
corporate limits of the city as handicapped parking spaces. It shall be
unlawful for any person not having a handicapped license plate issued by the
Illinois secretary of state's office to park in any parking space designated
for handicapped parking. (Ord. 828, 10-3-1994)
9-16-2: PRIVATE PROPERTY HANDICAPPED PARKING DESIGNATED:
It shall be unlawful for any person not having a handicapped license plate
issued by the Illinois secretary of state's office to park in any parking space
designated for handicapped parking by either St. Margaret's Hospital, Township
High School district 502 or Spring Valley elementary district 99. (Ord. 828,
10-3-1994)
9-16-3: PENALTY:
Any person who violates this chapter by parking in a handicapped parking space
without first obtaining handicapped license plates issued by the Illinois
secretary of state's office, shall be subject to a fine of two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00). (Ord. 1386, 9-15-2008)
CHAPTER 17
VEHICLE WEIGHT RESTRICTIONS
SECTION:
9-17-1: Definitions
9-17-2: Weight Limits
9-17-3: Applicable Highways And Roads
9-17-4: Exceptions
9-17-5: Maximum Weight Restrictions
9-17-6: Excess Weight Permit
9-17-7: Prohibited; Fine
9-17-8: Sign Location
9-17-9: Violation; Fine
9-17-10: Deposit Of Fines
9-17-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to all provisions contained in this
chapter:
AGRICULTURAL COMMODITIES: Cultivated plants or agricultural produce grown
including, but is not limited to, corn, soybeans, wheat, oats, grain, sorghum,
canola, and rice. Livestock including, but not limited to, hogs, equine, sheep,
and poultry. Ensilage and fruits and vegetables.
IMPLEMENT OF HUSBANDRY: Every vehicle designed and adapted exclusively for
agricultural, horticultural, or livestock raising operations, including farm
wagons, wagon trailers or like vehicles used in connection therewith, or for
lifting or carrying an implement of husbandry, provided that no farm wagon,
wagon trailer or like vehicle having a gross weight of more than thirty six
thousand (36,000) pounds shall be included hereunder.
TANDEM AXLE: Any two (2) or more consecutive axles whose centers are more than
forty inches (40") and not more than seventy two inches (72") apart, measured
to the nearest inch between any two (2) adjacent axles in the series.
VEHICLE: Every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be
transported or drawn upon a highway.
VEHICLE WEIGHT: The total of the weight of the vehicle, plus the weight of the
load thereon. (Ord. 1413, 3-16-2009)
9-17-2: WEIGHT LIMITS:
The superintendent of public works of the city of Spring Valley shall erect, or
cause to be erected and maintained, signs designating by word or symbol the
provisions of this section. For a period not to exceed ninety (90) days in any
one calendar year, when city highways and roads by reason of deterioration,
rain, snow, or other climate conditions, will be seriously damaged or destroyed
unless the permissible weight of vehicles therein is restricted. The vehicle
weight limits on certain city roads, specifically designated in this chapter,
shall be as follows:
   (A)   Weight limits per axle shall not exceed:
Eight thousand (8,000) pounds per single axle with two (2) tires.
Ten thousand (10,000) pounds per single axle with four (4) tires.
Twenty thousand (20,000) pounds per tandem axle.
In no event shall gross vehicle weight exceed forty thousand (40,000) pounds.
   (B)   Weight limits of high flotation applicators shall not exceed:
Nine thousand (9,000) pounds per axle with one tire.
Eighteen thousand (18,000) pounds per axle with two (2) tires. (Ord. 1413, 3-
16-2009)
9-17-3: APPLICABLE HIGHWAYS AND ROADS:
This chapter shall fully apply to the following described highways and roads
within the corporate limits of the city of Spring Valley:
Northview Drive, a.k.a. 1360th North, west of its intersection with Illinois
Route 89.
Peru-Princeton Road, a.k.a. 1350th North, east of its intersection with
Illinois Route 89.
Spring Creek Road, a.k.a. 1500 North Road.
The Old North Road. (Ord. 1413, 3-16-2009)
9-17-4: EXCEPTIONS:
The following exceptions shall apply to the provisions contained in this
chapter:
   (A)   Implements of husbandry that are tillage implements, refuse trucks,
school buses, fire apparatus and other emergency vehicles are exempt.
   (B)   The city superintendent of public works is hereby authorized to lift
and waive any weight limits on city highways and roads for a period of time
that he reasonably deems safe and necessary, when the temperature has not
exceeded twenty five degrees Fahrenheit (25°F) for a period of at least forty
eight (48) consecutive hours. (Ord. 1413, 3-16-2009)
9-17-5: MAXIMUM WEIGHT RESTRICTIONS:
The following weight restrictions shall apply on the roads designated in this
chapter:
   (A)   The maximum gross weight of any vehicle in a combination having five
(5) or more axles upon any city highway or road shall be seventy three thousand
two hundred eighty (73,280) pounds as provided for in 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/15-111.
   (B)   The maximum wheel and axle loads and the maximum gross weights of
vehicles and combination of vehicles upon city highways or roads shall be as
provided for in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-111 insofar as said section
addresses nondesignated highways. (Ord. 1413, 3-16-2009)
9-17-6: EXCESS WEIGHT PERMIT:
Upon application in writing and for good cause shown, or upon showing an undue
hardship or showing that said vehicle cannot reasonably be dismantled or
disassembled, the city superintendent of public works may issue a special
permit, at his discretion, in writing, authorizing the applicant to operate or
move a vehicle of excess maximum weight temporarily upon a city highway or
road. However, the city superintendent of public works may require such
applicant to indemnify the city against any damage to road surfaces. Also, the
city superintendent of public works may require such personal undertaking, or
other securities as may be deemed necessary, to compensate for any damage to
the city highway or road prior to granting said permit. (Ord. 1413, 3-16-2009)
9-17-7: PROHIBITED; FINE:
The city superintendent of public works is hereby authorized to permit the
operation of trucks or commercial vehicles on any city highway or road during
any period or periods that he determines that such highway or road by reason of
deterioration, rain, snow or other climate conditions will be seriously damaged
or destroyed unless the use of said highways or roads by trucks or other
commercial vehicles is prohibited during the period or periods in question.
When the city superintendent of public works acts pursuant to this section, he
shall erect and maintain signs designating the provisions of this section.
Whenever any vehicle is operated on any highway or road closed pursuant to the
provisions of this section, the owner of said vehicle shall be fined in an
amount not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) in addition to any penalty
imposed pursuant to the penalty provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1413, 3-16-
2009)
9-17-8: SIGN LOCATION:
The city superintendent of public works shall erect and maintain signs
designating the weight restrictions imposed by this chapter at the beginning
and end of each highway or road affected. (Ord. 1413, 3-16-2009)
9-17-9: VIOLATION; FINE:
Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of this
chapter, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of such
violations, and either the owner or driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted
for such violation. Any person, firm or corporation convicted of any violation
of this chapter shall be fined according to the following schedule:
Pounds Overweight Fine
0 to 2,000        $50.00 unless the overweight can be shifted or removed to
                  conform to all legal weight limits
Pounds Overweight Fine
0 to 2,000        $50.00 unless the overweight can be shifted or removed to
                  conform to all legal weight limits
2,001 to 2,500    $135.00
2,501 to 3,000    165.00
3,001 to 3,500    260.00
3,501 to 4,000    300.00
4,001 to 4,500    425.00
4,501 to 5,000    475.00
5,001 or more     The fine shall be computed at the rate of $75.00 for each
                  increment of 400 pounds overweight or fractions thereof
 
In addition, any person, firm or corporation convicted of three (3) or more
violations of this chapter within any twelve (12) month period shall be fined
an additional amount of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more
than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the third and each subsequent
conviction within the twelve (12) month period; provided, however, that with
regard to a firm or corporation, a third or subsequent conviction shall mean a
third or subsequent conviction attributable to any employee-driver. Any driver
of a vehicle who refuses to stop and submit his vehicle and load after being
directed to do so by an officer, or removes or causes the removal of the load
or part of it prior to weighing, shall be fined not less than five hundred
dollars ($500.00), nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). In any event
any of the foregoing penalty provisions are declared invalid, the owner or
driver shall nevertheless be deemed guilty and shall be fined in an amount not
to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 1413, 3-16-2009)
9-17-10: DEPOSIT OF FINES:
Any fines collected for violations of this chapter shall be deposited into the
general fund of the city of Spring Valley. (Ord. 1413, 3-16-2009)
CHAPTER 18
GOLF CARTS/NEIGHBORHOOD VEHICLES
SECTION:
9-18-1: Definitions; Where Permitted
9-18-2: Compliance With Illinois Vehicle Code
9-18-3: Permits
9-18-4: Additional Requirements
9-18-5: Violations
9-18-6: Impoundment
9-18-7: Operation
9-18-1: DEFINITIONS; WHERE PERMITTED:
   (A)   Definitions:
    CITY STREETS: Any of the streets within the boundaries of the city of
Spring Valley which have a posted maximum speed of thirty (30) miles per hour
and is not a state highway.
   GOLF CART: A vehicle specifically designed and intended for the purposes of
transporting one or more persons and their golf clubs, supervising the play of
golf or maintaining the condition of the grounds on a public or private golf
course.
   NEIGHBORHOOD VEHICLE: Any road ready electric or gas powered four (4) wheel
vehicle which has a maximum possible speed of twenty five (25) miles per hour.
This term includes reference to golf carts.
   (B)   Where Permitted: The operation of golf carts/neighborhood vehicles
(maximum 25 miles per hour) shall be permitted on streets under the
jurisdiction of the city of Spring Valley and/or with its intersection
controlled by a traffic light or four-way stop sign upon or across any highway
under the jurisdiction of the state of Illinois as set forth in section 11-
1426.1 of the Illinois vehicle code 1 . (Ord. 1546, 9-30-2013, eff. 11-1-2013)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/11-1426.1.
9-18-2: COMPLIANCE WITH ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE:
   (A)   The operation of golf carts/neighborhood vehicles within the city
shall be in accordance with all provisions of the Illinois vehicle code 1 ,
including, without limitation, section 11-1426.1 thereof 2 . All golf carts/
neighborhood vehicles must have, at a minimum: 1) the equipment and other items
set forth in section 11-1426.1(e) of the Illinois vehicle code 3  and 2) a type
1 or type 2 seat belt assembly conforming to 59 CFR 571.209 at each designated
seating position.
   (B)   No golf carts/neighborhood vehicles may be operated on a roadway
unless it is "road ready" and equipped as follows:
      1.   Brakes and brake light;
      2.   Steering wheel apparatus;
      3.   Tires;
      4.   Rearview mirrors;
      5.   Approved "slow moving" emblem on the rear of the vehicle 4 ;
      6.   Red reflector warning devices in front and rear; (Ord. 1546, 9-30-
2013, eff. 11-1-2013)
      7.   Headlights that emit a white light visible from at least one hundred
feet (100') from the front, which must be illuminated when in operation;
      8.   Tail lamps that emit a red light visible from at least one hundred
feet (100') from the rear, which must be illuminated when in operation; (Ord.
1577, 8-18-2014)
      9.   A golf cart/neighborhood vehicle must have its headlights and tail
lamps lighted at all times when in operation as required by section 12-201 of
the Illinois vehicle code;
      10.   Windshields;
      11.   Horn with two hundred fifty feet (250') of hearing distance;
      12.   Requirement of lap seat belt for drivers and passengers; and
      13.   Any additional requirements which may be amended.
   (C)   Each driver and passenger of a golf cart/neighborhood vehicle operated
on a street within the city shall wear a properly adjusted and fastened seat
belt; except that a child less than eight (8) years of age shall be protected
in the same manner as such children are required to be protected when riding in
motor vehicles under the child passenger protection act 5 . (Ord. 1546, 9-30-
2013, eff. 11-1-2013)
 
Notes
1 2. 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.
2 3. 625 ILCS 5/11-1426.1.
3 1. 625 ILCS 5/11-1426.1(e).
4 2. 625 ILCS 5/12-709.
5 3. 625 ILCS 25/1 et seq.
9-18-3: PERMITS:
   (A)   No person shall operate a golf cart/neighborhood vehicle within the
city without first obtaining a permit, or being listed as an additional
operator under a permit, as provided herein. Permits shall expire on April 30
of each year. The cost of the permit shall be as set forth in this chapter.
Applications for a permit shall be made on a form supplied by the city, shall
be executed by the applicant and each additional operator and shall contain the
following: (Ord. 1577, 8-18-2014)
      1.   Name and address of applicant;
      2.   Name and address of any additional operators;
      3.   Name of liability insurance carrier and policy number;
      4.   The serial number, make, model and description of golf cart/
neighborhood vehicle;
      5.   Signed waiver of liability by applicant releasing the city of Spring
Valley and its employees, and agreeing to indemnify and hold the city harmless
from any and all future claims resulting from the operation of their golf cart/
neighborhood vehicle on the Spring Valley streets;
      6.   Such other information as the city may require; and
      7.   No permit shall be granted unless the following conditions are met:
         (a)   The vehicle must be inspected and approved by the police
department;
         (b)   A physically handicapped applicant or operator must submit a
certificate signed by a physician, certifying that the applicant is able to
safely operate a golf cart/neighborhood vehicle on city streets;
         (c)   The applicant must provide evidence of insurance in compliance
with the provisions of the Illinois statutes regarding minimum liability
insurance for passenger motor vehicles to be operated on the roads of the state
of Illinois;
         (d)   The applicant must provide a copy of the driver's license of the
applicant and each operator.
         (e)   All city permit fees are paid and up to date.
   (B)   Permits may be renewed upon demonstration of compliance with the
requirement for initial issuance of a permit and the payment of the permit fee.
The cost of the permit is fifty dollars ($50.00). (Ord. 1546, 9-30-2013, eff.
11-1-2013)
9-18-4: ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS:
The following requirements shall apply to the operation of golf carts/
neighborhood vehicles within the city of Spring Valley:
   (A)   The applicant and all operators must be at least eighteen (18) years
of age.
   (B)   A city decal evidencing that a permit has been obtained shall be
prominently displayed on the rear of the golf cart/neighborhood vehicle. (Ord.
1546, 9-30-2013, eff. 11-1-2013)
9-18-5: VIOLATIONS:
The city of Spring Valley may choose to immediately suspend or revoke a permit
granted hereunder upon a finding that the holder thereof has violated any
provision of this chapter or there is evidence that permittee cannot safely
operate a qualified golf cart/neighborhood vehicle on designated roadways.
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
petty offense and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred
dollars ($500.00). Any second or subsequent offense shall result in the
revocation of the permit for a period of not less than one year nor more than
three (3) years. To the extent that any violation of this chapter also
constitutes a violation of a criminal statute of the state of Illinois, then
the violator shall be subject to criminal prosecution. (Ord. 1546, 9-30-2013,
eff. 11-1-2013)
9-18-6: IMPOUNDMENT:
Golf carts/neighborhood vehicles shall be subject to impoundment to the same
extent as other vehicles as set forth in title 6, chapter 12, "Impoundment And
Towing Of Vehicles", of this code. (Ord. 1546, 9-30-2013, eff. 11-1-2013)
9-18-7: OPERATION:
The operator of a golf cart/neighborhood vehicle on public roadways must obey
all traffic laws of the state of Illinois and the city of Spring Valley.
Golf carts/neighborhood vehicles may not be operated on streets and highways
and roads under the jurisdiction of the Illinois department of transportation
including State Highway 6 (Dakota Street) and Highway 89 (Spalding Street)
except to cross the street or highways at approved intersections.
A person operating or who is in actual physical control of a golf cart/
neighborhood vehicle as described herein on a roadway while under the influence
of alcohol, other drug or drugs, intoxicating compound or compounds or any
combination thereof is subject to sections 11-500 through 11-502 of the
Illinois Compiled Statutes 1 . (Ord. 1546, 9-30-2013, eff. 11-1-2013)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/11-500 - 11-502.
